(CAPULET and his COUSIN sit down) How long is it now since you and I last wore masks at a party like this?$NEWLINE$(music plays and they dance,$NEWLINE$stands apart)$NEWLINE$. (to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to his$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$and his$NEWLINE$sit down)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAPULETS' COUSIN$NEWLINE$By'r Lady, thirty years.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET'S COUSIN$NEWLINE$I swear, it must be thirty years.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$What, man, ’tis not so much, ’tis not so much.$NEWLINE$'Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio,$NEWLINE$Come Pentecost as quickly as it will,$NEWLINE$Some five and twenty years, and then we masked.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$What, man? It’s not that long, it’s not that long. It’s been since Lucentio’s wedding. Let the years fly by as fast as they like, it’s only been twenty-five years since we wore masks.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET'S COUSIN$NEWLINE$'Tis more, ’tis more. His son is elder, sir.$NEWLINE$His son is thirty.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET'S COUSIN$NEWLINE$It’s been longer, it’s been longer. Lucentio’s son is older than that, sir. He’s thirty years old.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Will you tell me that?$NEWLINE$His son was but a ward two years ago.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Are you really going to tell me that? His son was a minor only two years ago.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(to a SERVINGMAN) What lady is that which doth enrich the hand$NEWLINE$(to a$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Of yonder knight?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(to a SERVINGMAN) Who is the girl on the arm of that lucky knight over there?$NEWLINE$(to a$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$I know not, sir.
paragraphs.translated: SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$I don’t know, sir.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!$NEWLINE$It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night$NEWLINE$Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope’s ear,$NEWLINE$Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear.$NEWLINE$So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows$NEWLINE$As yonder lady o'er her fellows shows.$NEWLINE$The measure done, I’ll watch her place of stand,$NEWLINE$And, touching hers, make blessèd my rude hand.$NEWLINE$Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight!$NEWLINE$For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, she shows the torches how to burn bright! She stands out against the darkness like a jeweled earring hanging against the cheek of an African. Her beauty is too good for this world; she’s too beautiful to die and be buried. She outshines the other women like a white dove in the middle of a flock of crows. When this dance is over, I’ll see where she stands, and then I’ll touch her hand with my rough and ugly one. Did my heart ever love anyone before this moment? My eyes were liars, then, because I never saw true beauty before tonight.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—$NEWLINE$(to his PAGE) Fetch me my rapier, boy.—$NEWLINE$(to his$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$What, dares the slave$NEWLINE$Come hither, covered with an antic face,$NEWLINE$To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?$NEWLINE$Now, by the stock and honor of my kin,$NEWLINE$To strike him dead I hold it not a sin.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$I can tell by his voice that this man is a Montague. (to his PAGE) Get me my sword, boy.—What, does this peasant dare to come here with his face covered by a mask to sneer at and scorn our celebration? Now, by the honor of our family, I do not consider it a crime to kill him.$NEWLINE$(to his$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$—

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Why, how now, kinsman? Wherefore storm you so?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Why, what’s going on here, nephew? Why are you acting so angry?

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe,$NEWLINE$A villain that is hither come in spite$NEWLINE$To scorn at our solemnity this night.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Uncle, this man is a Montague—our enemy. He’s a scoundrel who’s come here out of spite to mock our party.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Young Romeo is it?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Is it young Romeo?

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$'Tis he, that villain Romeo.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$That’s him, that villain Romeo.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Content thee, gentle coz. Let him alone.$NEWLINE$He bears him like a portly gentleman,$NEWLINE$And, to say truth, Verona brags of him$NEWLINE$To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.$NEWLINE$I would not for the wealth of all the town$NEWLINE$Here in my house do him disparagement.$NEWLINE$Therefore be patient. Take no note of him.$NEWLINE$It is my will, the which if thou respect,$NEWLINE$Show a fair presence and put off these frowns,$NEWLINE$An ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Calm down, gentle cousin. Leave him alone. He carries himself like a dignified gentleman, and, to tell you the truth, he has a reputation throughout Verona as a virtuous and well-behaved young man. I wouldn’t insult him in my own house for all the wealth in this town. So calm down. Just ignore him. That’s what I want, and if you respect my wishes, you’ll look nice and stop frowning because that’s not the way you should behave at a feast.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$It fits when such a villain is a guest.$NEWLINE$I’ll not endure him.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$It’s the right way to act when a villain like him shows up. I won’t tolerate him.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$He shall be endured.$NEWLINE$What, goodman boy! I say, he shall. Go to.$NEWLINE$Am I the master here, or you? Go to.$NEWLINE$You’ll not endure him! God shall mend my soul,$NEWLINE$You’ll make a mutiny among my guests.$NEWLINE$You will set cock-a-hoop. You’ll be the man!
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$You will tolerate him. What, little man? I say you will. What the—Am I the boss here or you? What the—You won’t tolerate him! God help me! You’ll start a riot among my guests! There will be chaos! It will be your fault, you’ll be the rabble-rouser!$NEWLINE$will

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Why, uncle, ’tis a shame.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$But, uncle, we’re being disrespected.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Go to, go to.$NEWLINE$You are a saucy boy. Is ’t so, indeed?$NEWLINE$This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what.$NEWLINE$You must contrary me. Marry, ’tis time.—$NEWLINE$Well said, my hearts!—You are a princox, go.$NEWLINE$Be quiet, or—More light, more light!—For shame!$NEWLINE$I’ll make you quiet.—What, cheerly, my hearts!
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Go on, go on. You’re an insolent little boy. Is that how it is, really? This stupidity will come back to bite you. I know what I’ll do. You have to contradict me, do you? I’ll teach you a lesson. (to the GUESTS) Well done, my dear guests! (to TYBALT) You’re a punk, get away. Keep your mouth shut, or else— (to SERVINGMEN) more light, more light! (to TYBALT) You should be ashamed. ’ll shut you up. (to the guests) Keep having fun, my dear friends!$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to the guests)

paragraphs.original: Music plays again, and the guests dance
paragraphs.translated: The music plays again, and the guests dance

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Patience perforce with willful choler meeting$NEWLINE$Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.$NEWLINE$I will withdraw, but this intrusion shall$NEWLINE$Now seeming sweet, convert to bitterest gall.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$The combination of forced patience and pure rage is making my body tremble. I’ll leave here now, but Romeo’s prank, which seems so sweet to him now, will turn bitter to him later.

paragraphs.original: Exit TYBALT$NEWLINE$TYBALT
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT exits.$NEWLINE$TYBALT

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(taking JULIET’s hand) If I profane with my unworthiest hand$NEWLINE$(taking$NEWLINE$’s hand)$NEWLINE$This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this:$NEWLINE$My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand$NEWLINE$To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(taking JULIET’s hand) Your hand is like a holy place that my hand is unworthy to visit. If you’re offended by the touch of my hand, my two lips are standing here like blushing pilgrims, ready to make things better with a kiss.$NEWLINE$(taking$NEWLINE$’s hand)$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,$NEWLINE$Which mannerly devotion shows in this,$NEWLINE$For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch,$NEWLINE$And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Good pilgrim, you don’t give your hand enough credit. By holding my hand you show polite devotion. After all, pilgrims touch the hands of statues of saints. Holding one palm against another is like a kiss.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Don’t saints and pilgrims have lips too?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Yes, pilgrim—they have lips that they’re supposed to pray with.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.$NEWLINE$They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Well then, saint, let lips do what hands do. I’m praying for you to kiss me. Please grant my prayer so my faith doesn’t turn to despair.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Saints don’t move, even when they grant prayers.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Then move not, while my prayer’s effect I take.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Then don’t move while I act out my prayer.

paragraphs.original: Kisses her$NEWLINE$Kisses her
paragraphs.translated: He kisses her.$NEWLINE$He kisses her

paragraphs.original: Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.
paragraphs.translated: Now my sin has been taken from my lips by yours.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Then have my lips the sin that they have took.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Then do my lips now have the sin they took from yours?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged!$NEWLINE$Give me my sin again.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Sin from my lips? You encourage crime with your sweetness. Give me my sin back.

paragraphs.original: They kiss again
paragraphs.translated: They kiss again

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$You kiss by th' book.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$You kiss like you’ve studied how.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Madam, your mother craves a word with you.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Madam, your mother wants to talk to you.

paragraphs.original: JULIET moves away$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET moves away$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What is her mother?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Who is her mother?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Marry, bachelor,$NEWLINE$Her mother is the lady of the house,$NEWLINE$And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous.$NEWLINE$I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.$NEWLINE$I tell you, he that can lay hold of her$NEWLINE$Shall have the chinks.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Indeed, young man, her mother is the lady of the house. She is a good, wise, and virtuous lady. I nursed her daughter, whom you were just talking to. Let me tell you, the man who marries her will become very wealthy.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(aside) Is she a Capulet?$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$O dear account! My life is my foe’s debt.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(to himself) Is she a Capulet? Oh, this is a heavy price to pay! My life is in the hands of my enemy.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$(to ROMEO) Away, begone. The sport is at the best.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$(to ROMEO) Come on, let’s go. Right when things are the most fun is the best time to leave.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Ay, so I fear. The more is my unrest.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Yes, but I’m afraid I’m in more trouble than ever.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.$NEWLINE$We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.—$NEWLINE$Is it e'en so? Why, then, I thank you all.$NEWLINE$I thank you, honest gentlemen. Good night.—$NEWLINE$More torches here!—Come on then, let’s to bed.$NEWLINE$Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late.$NEWLINE$I’ll to my rest.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$No gentlemen, don’t get ready to go now. We have a little dessert coming up. (they whisper in his ear) Is that really true? Well, then, I thank you both. I thank you, honest gentlemen. Good night. Bring more torches over here! Come on, let’s all get to bed. (to his COUSIN) Ah, my man, I swear, it’s getting late. I’m going to get some rest.$NEWLINE$(they whisper in his ear)$NEWLINE$(to his$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: All but JULIET and NURSE move to exit$NEWLINE$JULIET$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except JULIET and NURSE begins to exit.$NEWLINE$JULIET$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Come hither, Nurse. What is yond gentleman?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Come over here, nurse. Who is that gentleman?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$The son and heir of old Tiberio.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$He is the son and heir of old Tiberio.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What’s he that now is going out of door?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Who’s the one who’s going out the door right now?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Marry, that, I think, be young Petruchio.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Well, that one, I think, is young Petruchio.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What’s he that follows here, that would not dance?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Who’s the one following over there, the one who wouldn’t dance?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$I know not.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$I don’t know his name.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Go ask his name.—If he be married.$NEWLINE$My grave is like to be my wedding bed.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Go ask. (the nurse leaves) If he’s married, I think I’ll die rather than marry anyone else.$NEWLINE$(the nurse leaves)

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$His name is Romeo, and a Montague,$NEWLINE$The only son of your great enemy.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$(returning) His name is Romeo. He’s a Montague. He’s the only son of your worst enemy.$NEWLINE$(returning)

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$(aside) My only love sprung from my only hate!$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Too early seen unknown, and known too late!$NEWLINE$Prodigious birth of love it is to me,$NEWLINE$That I must love a loathèd enemy.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$(to herself) The only man I love is the son of the only man I hate! I saw him too early without knowing who he was, and I found out who he was too late! Love is a monster for making me fall in love with my worst enemy.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$What’s this? What’s this?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$What’s this? What’s this?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$A rhyme I learned even now$NEWLINE$Of one I danced withal.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Just a rhyme I learned from somebody I danced with at the party.

paragraphs.original: One calls within “Juliet!”
paragraphs.translated: Somebody calls, “Juliet!” from offstage.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Anon, anon!$NEWLINE$Come, let’s away. The strangers all are gone.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Right away, right away. Come, let’s go. The strangers are all gone.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CHORUS$NEWLINE$CHORUS
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS enters.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie,$NEWLINE$And young affection gapes to be his heir.$NEWLINE$That fair for which love groaned for and would die$NEWLINE$With tender Juliet matched, is now not fair.$NEWLINE$Now Romeo is beloved and loves again,$NEWLINE$Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks,$NEWLINE$But to his foe supposed he must complain,$NEWLINE$And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks.$NEWLINE$Being held a foe, he may not have access$NEWLINE$To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear.$NEWLINE$And she as much in love, her means much less$NEWLINE$To meet her new beloved anywhere.$NEWLINE$But passion lends them power, time means, to meet,$NEWLINE$Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.
paragraphs.translated: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Now Romeo’s old feelings of desire are dying, and a new desire is eager to take their place. Romeo groaned for the beautiful Rosaline and said he would die for her, but compared with tender Juliet, Rosaline doesn’t seem beautiful now. Now someone loves Romeo, and he’s in love again—both of them falling for each others' good looks. But he has to make his speeches of love to a woman who’s supposed to be his enemy. And she’s been hooked by someone she should fear. Because he’s an enemy, Romeo has no chance to see Juliet and say the things a lover normally says. And Juliet’s just as much in love as he, but she has even less opportunity to meet her lover. But love gives them power, and time gives them the chance to meet, sweetening the extreme danger with intense pleasure.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS exits.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ROMEO alone$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO enters alone.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Can I go forward when my heart is here?$NEWLINE$Turn back, dull earth, and find thy center out.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Can I go away while my heart stays here? I have to go back to where my heart is.

paragraphs.original: Moves away Enter BENVOLIO with MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO moves away. BENVOLIO and MERCUTIO enter.$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Romeo, my cousin Romeo! Romeo!
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$(calling) Romeo, my cousin, Romeo, Romeo!$NEWLINE$(calling)

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$He is wise,$NEWLINE$And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$He’s a smart boy. I bet he slipped away and went home to bed.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.$NEWLINE$Call, good Mercutio.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$He ran this way and jumped over this orchard wall. Call to him, Mercutio.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Nay, I’ll conjure too!$NEWLINE$Romeo! Humours, madman, passion, lover!$NEWLINE$Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh!$NEWLINE$Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied.$NEWLINE$Cry but “Ay me!” Pronounce but “love” and “dove.”$NEWLINE$Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,$NEWLINE$One nickname for her purblind son and heir,$NEWLINE$Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so true$NEWLINE$When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.—$NEWLINE$He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not.$NEWLINE$The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.—$NEWLINE$I conjure thee by Rosaline’s bright eyes,$NEWLINE$By her high forehead and her scarlet lip,$NEWLINE$By her fine foot, straight leg, and quivering thigh,$NEWLINE$And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,$NEWLINE$That in thy likeness thou appear to us.
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$I’ll conjure him as if I were summoning a spirit. Romeo! Madman! Passion! Lover! Show yourself in the form of a sigh. Speak one rhyme, and I’ll be satisfied. Just cry out, “Ah me!” Just say “love” and “dove.” Say just one lovely word to my good friend
Venus. Just say the nickname of her blind son Cupid, the one who shot arrows so well in the old story.—Romeo doesn’t hear me. He doesn’t stir. He doesn’t move. The silly ape is dead, but I must make him appear.—I summon you by Rosaline’s bright eyes, by her high forehead and her red lips, by her fine feet, by her straight legs, by her trembling thighs, and by the regions right next to her thighs. In the name of all of these things, I command you to appear before us in your true form.$NEWLINE$Venus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$If he hears you, you’ll make him angry.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$This cannot anger him. 'Twould anger him$NEWLINE$To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle$NEWLINE$Of some strange nature, letting it there stand$NEWLINE$Till she had laid it and conjured it down.$NEWLINE$That were some spite. My invocation$NEWLINE$Is fair and honest. In his mistress' name$NEWLINE$I conjure only but to raise up him.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$What I’m saying can’t anger him. He would be angry if I summoned a strange spirit for her to have sex with—that’s what would make him angry. The things I’m saying are fair and honest. All I’m doing is saying the name of the woman he loves to lure him out of the darkness.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Come, he hath hid himself among these trees,$NEWLINE$To be consorted with the humorous night.$NEWLINE$Blind is his love and best befits the dark.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Come on. He’s hidden behind these trees to keep the night company. His love is blind, so it belongs in the dark.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.$NEWLINE$Now will he sit under a medlar tree$NEWLINE$And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit$NEWLINE$As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.—$NEWLINE$O Romeo, that she were! Oh, that she were$NEWLINE$An open arse, and thou a poperin pear.$NEWLINE$Romeo, good night. I’ll to my truckle bed.$NEWLINE$This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep.—$NEWLINE$Come, shall we go?
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$If love is blind, it can’t hit the target. Now he’ll sit under a
medlar tree and wish his mistress were one of those fruits that look like female genitalia. Oh Romeo, I wish she were an open-arse, and you a Popperin pear to “pop her in.” Good night, Romeo. I’ll go to my little trundle bed. This open field is too cold a place for me to sleep. (to BENVOLIO) Come on, should we go?$NEWLINE$medlar$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$were$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Go, then, for ’tis in vain$NEWLINE$To seek him here that means not to be found.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Let’s go. There’s no point in looking for him if he doesn’t want to be found.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO and MERCUTIO exit.$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO returns$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO returns.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$He jests at scars that never felt a wound.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$It’s easy for someone to joke about scars if they’ve never been cut.

paragraphs.original: JULIET appears in a window above$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET enters on the balcony.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: But soft! What light through yonder window breaks?$NEWLINE$It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.$NEWLINE$Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon,$NEWLINE$Who is already sick and pale with grief,$NEWLINE$That thou, her maid, art far more fair than she.$NEWLINE$Be not her maid since she is envious.$NEWLINE$Her vestal livery is but sick and green,$NEWLINE$And none but fools do wear it. Cast it off!$NEWLINE$It is my lady. Oh, it is my love.$NEWLINE$Oh, that she knew she were!$NEWLINE$She speaks, yet she says nothing. What of that?$NEWLINE$Her eye discourses. I will answer it.—$NEWLINE$I am too bold. 'Tis not to me she speaks.$NEWLINE$Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,$NEWLINE$Having some business, do entreat her eyes$NEWLINE$To twinkle in their spheres till they return.$NEWLINE$What if her eyes were there, they in her head?$NEWLINE$The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars$NEWLINE$As daylight doth a lamp. Her eye in heaven$NEWLINE$Would through the airy region stream so bright$NEWLINE$That birds would sing and think it were not night.$NEWLINE$See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.$NEWLINE$Oh, that I were a glove upon that hand$NEWLINE$That I might touch that cheek!
paragraphs.translated:
But wait, what’s that light in the window over there? It is the east, and Juliet is the sun. Rise up, beautiful sun, and kill the
jealous moon. The moon is already sick and pale with grief because you, Juliet, her maid, are more beautiful than she.$NEWLINE$jealous moon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Don’t be her maid, because she is jealous. Virginity makes her look sick and green. Only fools hold on to their virginity. Let it go. Oh, there’s my lady! Oh, it is my love. Oh, I wish she knew how much I love her. She’s talking, but she’s not saying anything. So what? Her eyes are saying something. I will answer them. I am too bold. She’s not talking to me. Two of the brightest stars in the whole sky had to go away on business, and they’re asking her eyes to twinkle in their places until they return. What if her eyes were in the sky and the stars were in her head?—The brightness of her cheeks would outshine the stars the way the sun outshines a lamp. If her eyes were in the night sky, they would shine so brightly through space that birds would start singing, thinking her light was the light of day. Look how she leans her hand on her cheek. Oh, I wish I was the glove on that hand so that I could touch that cheek.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Ay me!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh, my!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(aside) She speaks.$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$O, speak again, bright angel! For thou art$NEWLINE$As glorious to this night, being o'er my head,$NEWLINE$As is a wingèd messenger of heaven$NEWLINE$Unto the white, upturnèd, wondering eyes$NEWLINE$Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him$NEWLINE$When he bestrides the lazy-puffing clouds$NEWLINE$And sails upon the bosom of the air.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(to himself) She speaks. Oh, speak again, bright angel. You are as glorious as an angel tonight. You shine above me, like a winged messenger from heaven who makes mortal men fall on their backs to look up at the sky, watching the angel walking on the clouds and sailing on the air.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou Romeo?$NEWLINE$Deny thy father and refuse thy name.$NEWLINE$Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,$NEWLINE$And I’ll no longer be a Capulet.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$(not knowing ROMEO hears her) Oh, Romeo, Romeo, why do you have to be Romeo? Forget about your father and change your name. Or else, if you won’t change your name, just swear you love me and I’ll stop being a Capulet.$NEWLINE$(not knowing$NEWLINE$hears her)

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(aside) Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(to himself) Should I listen for more, or should I speak now?$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$'Tis but thy name that is my enemy.$NEWLINE$Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.$NEWLINE$What’s Montague? It is nor hand, nor foot,$NEWLINE$Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part$NEWLINE$Belonging to a man. O, be some other name!$NEWLINE$What’s in a name? That which we call a rose$NEWLINE$By any other word would smell as sweet.$NEWLINE$So Romeo would, were he not Romeo called,$NEWLINE$Retain that dear perfection which he owes$NEWLINE$Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name,$NEWLINE$And for that name, which is no part of thee$NEWLINE$Take all myself.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$(still not knowing ROMEO hears her) It’s only your name that’s my enemy. You’d still be yourself even if you stopped being a Montague. What’s a Montague anyway? It isn’t a hand, a foot, an arm, a face, or any other part of a man. Oh, be some other name! What does a name mean? The thing we call a rose would smell just as sweet if we called it by any other name. Romeo would be just as perfect even if he wasn’t called Romeo. Romeo, lose your name. Trade in your name—which really has nothing to do with you—and take all of me in exchange.$NEWLINE$(still not knowing$NEWLINE$hears her)

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I take thee at thy word.$NEWLINE$Call me but love, and I’ll be new baptized.$NEWLINE$Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(to JULIET) I trust your words. Just call me your love, and I will take a new name. From now on I will never be Romeo again.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night,$NEWLINE$So stumblest on my counsel?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Who are you? Why do you hide in the darkness and listen to my private thoughts?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$By a name$NEWLINE$I know not how to tell thee who I am.$NEWLINE$My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself$NEWLINE$Because it is an enemy to thee.$NEWLINE$Had I it written, I would tear the word.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I don’t know how to tell you who I am by telling you a name. I hate my name, dear saint, because my name is your enemy. If I had it written down, I would tear up the paper.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words$NEWLINE$Of that tongue’s uttering, yet I know the sound.$NEWLINE$Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I haven’t heard you say a hundred words yet, but I recognize the sound of your voice. Aren’t you Romeo? And aren’t you a Montague?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Neither, fair maid, if either thee dislike.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I am neither of those things if you dislike them.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?$NEWLINE$The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,$NEWLINE$And the place death, considering who thou art,$NEWLINE$If any of my kinsmen find thee here.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Tell me, how did you get in here? And why did you come? The orchard walls are high, and it’s hard to climb over them. If any of my relatives find you here they’ll kill you because of who you are.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$With love’s light wings did I o'erperch these walls,$NEWLINE$For stony limits cannot hold love out,$NEWLINE$And what love can do, that dares love attempt.$NEWLINE$Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I flew over these walls with the light wings of love. Stone walls can’t keep love out. Whatever a man in love can possibly do, his love will make him try to do it. Therefore your relatives are no obstacle.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$If they do see thee they will murder thee.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$If they see you, they’ll murder you.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye$NEWLINE$Than twenty of their swords. Look thou but sweet,$NEWLINE$And I am proof against their enmity.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Alas, one angry look from you would be worse than twenty of your relatives with swords. Just look at me kindly, and I’m invincible against their hatred.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I would not for the world they saw thee here.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I’d give anything to keep them from seeing you here.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I have night’s cloak to hide me from their eyes,$NEWLINE$And but thou love me, let them find me here.$NEWLINE$My life were better ended by their hate$NEWLINE$Than death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$The darkness will hide me from them. And if you don’t love me, let them find me here. I’d rather they killed me than have to live without your love.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$By whose direction found’st thou out this place?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Who told you how to get here below my bedroom?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$By love, that first did prompt me to inquire.$NEWLINE$He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes.$NEWLINE$I am no pilot. Yet, wert thou as far$NEWLINE$As that vast shore washed with the farthest sea,$NEWLINE$I would adventure for such merchandise.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Love showed me the way—the same thing that made me look for you in the first place. Love told me what to do, and I let love borrow my eyes. I’m not a sailor, but if you were across the farthest sea, I would risk everything to gain you.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Thou know’st the mask of night is on my face,$NEWLINE$Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek$NEWLINE$For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.$NEWLINE$Fain would I dwell on form. Fain, fain deny$NEWLINE$What I have spoke. But farewell compliment!$NEWLINE$Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say “ay,”$NEWLINE$And I will take thy word. Yet if thou swear’st$NEWLINE$Thou mayst prove false. At lovers' perjuries,$NEWLINE$They say, Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,$NEWLINE$If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully.$NEWLINE$Or if thou think’st I am too quickly won,$NEWLINE$I’ll frown and be perverse and say thee nay,$NEWLINE$So thou wilt woo. But else, not for the world.$NEWLINE$In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond,$NEWLINE$And therefore thou mayst think my 'havior light.$NEWLINE$But trust me, gentleman, I’ll prove more true$NEWLINE$Than those that have more coying to be strange.$NEWLINE$I should have been more strange, I must confess,$NEWLINE$But that thou overheard’st, ere I was 'ware,$NEWLINE$My true love’s passion. Therefore pardon me,$NEWLINE$And not impute this yielding to light love,$NEWLINE$Which the dark night hath so discovered.
paragraphs.translated:
JULIET$NEWLINE$You can’t see my face because it’s dark out. Otherwise, you’d see me blushing about the things you’ve heard me say tonight. I would be happy to keep up good manners and deny the things I said. But forget about good manners. Do you love me? I know you’ll say “yes,” and I’ll believe you. But if you swear you love me, you might turn out to be lying. They say
Jove laughs when lovers lie to each other. Oh Romeo, if you really love me, say it truly. Or if you think it’s too easy and quick to win my heart, I’ll frown and play hard-to-get, as long as that will make you try to win me, but otherwise I wouldn’t act that way for anything. In truth, handsome Montague, I like you too much, so you may think my behavior is loose. But trust me, gentleman, I’ll prove myself more faithful than girls who act coy and play hard-to-get. I should have been more standoffish, I confess, but you overheard me talking about the love in my heart when I didn’t know you were there. So excuse me, and do not assume that because you made me love you so easily my love isn’t serious.$NEWLINE$Jove$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Lady, by yonder blessèd moon I vow,$NEWLINE$That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops—
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Lady, I swear by the sacred moon above, the moon that paints the tops of fruit trees with silver—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O, swear not by the moon, th' inconstant moon,$NEWLINE$That monthly changes in her circle orb,$NEWLINE$Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Don’t swear by the moon. The moon is always changing. Every month its position in the sky shifts. I don’t want you to turn out to be that inconsistent too.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What shall I swear by?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What should I swear by?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Do not swear at all.$NEWLINE$Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,$NEWLINE$Which is the god of my idolatry,$NEWLINE$And I’ll believe thee.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Don’t swear at all. But if you have to swear, swear by your wonderful self, which is the god I worship like an idol, and then I’ll believe you.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$If my heart’s dear love—
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$If my heart’s dear love—

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Well, do not swear. Although I joy in thee,$NEWLINE$I have no joy of this contract tonight.$NEWLINE$It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden,$NEWLINE$Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be$NEWLINE$Ere one can say “It lightens.” Sweet, good night.$NEWLINE$This bud of love, by summer’s ripening breath,$NEWLINE$May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.$NEWLINE$Good night, good night! As sweet repose and rest$NEWLINE$Come to thy heart as that within my breast.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Well, don’t swear. Although you bring me joy, I can’t take joy in this exchange of promises tonight. It’s too crazy. We haven’t done enough thinking. It’s too sudden. It’s too much like lightning, which flashes and then disappears before you can say, “it’s lightning.” My sweet, good night. Our love, which right now is like a flower bud in the summer air, may turn out to be a beautiful flower by the next time we meet. I hope you enjoy the same sweet peace and rest I feel in my heart.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, are you going to leave me so unsatisfied?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$What satisfaction could you possibly have tonight?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Th' exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I would be satisfied if we made each other true promises of love.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I gave thee mine before thou didst request it,$NEWLINE$And yet I would it were to give again.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I pledged my love to you before you asked me to. Yet I wish I could take that promise back, so I had it to give again.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Wouldst thou withdraw it? For what purpose, love?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$You would take it back? Why would you do that, my love?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$But to be frank, and give it thee again.$NEWLINE$And yet I wish but for the thing I have.$NEWLINE$My bounty is as boundless as the sea,$NEWLINE$My love as deep. The more I give to thee,$NEWLINE$The more I have, for both are infinite.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Only to be generous and give it to you once more. But I’m wishing for something I already have. My generosity to you is as limitless as the sea, and my love is as deep. The more love I give you, the more I have. Both loves are infinite.

paragraphs.original: NURSE calls from within$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE calls from offstage.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: I hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu.—$NEWLINE$Anon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true.$NEWLINE$Stay but a little. I will come again.
paragraphs.translated: I hear a noise inside. Dear love, goodbye—Just a minute, good Nurse. Sweet Montague, be true. Stay here for a moment. I’ll come back.

paragraphs.original: Exit JULIET, above$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET exits.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$O blessèd, blessèd night! I am afeard,$NEWLINE$Being in night, all this is but a dream,$NEWLINE$Too flattering sweet to be substantial.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, blessed, blessed night! Because it’s dark out, I’m afraid all this is just a dream, too sweet to be real.

paragraphs.original: Enter JULIET, above$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET enters on her balcony.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.$NEWLINE$If that thy bent of love be honorable,$NEWLINE$Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow$NEWLINE$By one that I’ll procure to come to thee$NEWLINE$Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite,$NEWLINE$And all my fortunes at thy foot I’ll lay$NEWLINE$And follow thee my lord throughout the world.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Three words, dear Romeo, and then it’s good night for real. If your intentions as a lover are truly honorable and you want to marry me, send me word tomorrow. I’ll send a messenger to you, and you can pass on a message telling me where and when we’ll be married. I’ll lay all my fortunes at your feet and follow you, my lord, all over the world.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$(from within) Madam!$NEWLINE$(from within)
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$(offstage) Madam!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I come, anon.—But if thou mean’st not well,$NEWLINE$I do beseech thee—
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$(to the NURSE) I’ll be right there! (to ROMEO) But if you don’t have honorable intentions, I beg you—$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$(from within) Madam!$NEWLINE$(from within)
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$(offstage) Madam!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$By and by, I come.—$NEWLINE$To cease thy strife and leave me to my grief.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow will I send.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Alright, I’m coming!—I beg you to stop trying for me and leave me to my sadness. Tomorrow I’ll send the messenger.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$So thrive my soul—
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$My soul depends on it—

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$A thousand times good night!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$A thousand times good night.

paragraphs.original: Exit JULIET, above$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET exits.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$A thousand times the worse to want thy light.$NEWLINE$Love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books,$NEWLINE$But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Leaving you is a thousand times worse than being near you. A lover goes toward his beloved as enthusiastically as a schoolboy leaving his books, but when he leaves his girlfriend, he feels as miserable as the schoolboy on his way to school.

paragraphs.original: Moves to exit Reenter JULIET, above$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO starts to leave. JULIET returns, on her balcony.$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Hist! Romeo, hist!—Oh, for a falconer’s voice,$NEWLINE$To lure this tassel-gentle back again!$NEWLINE$Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud,$NEWLINE$Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies,$NEWLINE$And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine,$NEWLINE$With repetition of “My Romeo!”
paragraphs.translated:
JULIET$NEWLINE$Hist, Romeo! Hist! Oh, I wish I could make a
falconer’s call, so I could bring my little falcon back again. I’m trapped in my family’s house, so I must be quiet. Otherwise I would rip open the cave where
Echo sleeps. I would make her repeat his name until her voice grew more hoarse than mine by repeating, “My Romeo!”$NEWLINE$falconer’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Echo$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$It is my soul that calls upon my name.$NEWLINE$How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night,$NEWLINE$Like softest music to attending ears!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$My soul is calling out my name. The sound of lovers calling each others names through the night is silver-sweet. It’s the sweetest sound a lover ever hears.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Romeo!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Romeo!

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$My nyas?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$My baby hawk?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What o'clock tomorrow$NEWLINE$Shall I send to thee?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$What time tomorrow should I send a messenger to you?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$By the hour of nine.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$By nine o'clock.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I will not fail. 'Tis twenty year till then.$NEWLINE$I have forgot why I did call thee back.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I won’t fail. From now until then seems like twenty years. I have forgotten why I called you back.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Let me stand here till thou remember it.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Let me stand here until you remember your reason.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I shall forget, to have thee still stand there,$NEWLINE$Remembering how I love thy company.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I’ll forget it, and you’ll have to stand there forever. I’ll only remember how much I love your company.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$And I’ll still stay, to have thee still forget,$NEWLINE$Forgetting any other home but this.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I’ll keep standing here, even if you keep forgetting. I’ll forget that I have any home besides this spot right here.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$'Tis almost morning. I would have thee gone.$NEWLINE$And yet no further than a wanton’s bird,$NEWLINE$That lets it hop a little from his hand$NEWLINE$Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,$NEWLINE$And with a silken thread plucks it back again,$NEWLINE$So loving-jealous of his liberty.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$It’s almost morning. I want to make you go, but I’d only let you go as far as a spoiled child lets his pet bird go. He lets the bird hop a little from his hand and then yanks him back by a string.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I would I were thy bird.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I wish I was your bird.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Sweet, so would I.$NEWLINE$Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.$NEWLINE$Good night, good night! Parting is such sweet sorrow$NEWLINE$That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$My sweet, so do I. But I would kill you by petting you too much. Good night, good night. Parting is such sweet sorrow that I’ll say good night until tonight becomes tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: Exit JULIET, above$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET exits.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.$NEWLINE$Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest.$NEWLINE$Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell,$NEWLINE$His help to crave and my dear hap to tell.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I hope you sleep peacefully. I wish I were Sleep and Peace, so I could spend the night with you. Now I’ll go see my priest, to ask for his help and tell him about my good luck.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FRIAR LAWRENCE, with a basket$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE enters by himself, carrying a basket.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,$NEWLINE$Checkering the eastern clouds with streaks of light,$NEWLINE$And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels$NEWLINE$From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels.$NEWLINE$Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,$NEWLINE$The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry,$NEWLINE$I must upfill this osier cage of ours$NEWLINE$With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.$NEWLINE$The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.$NEWLINE$What is her burying, grave that is her womb.$NEWLINE$And from her womb children of divers kind$NEWLINE$We sucking on her natural bosom find,$NEWLINE$Many for many virtues excellent,$NEWLINE$None but for some and yet all different.$NEWLINE$Oh, mickle is the powerful grace that lies$NEWLINE$In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.$NEWLINE$For naught so vile that on the earth doth live$NEWLINE$But to the earth some special good doth give.$NEWLINE$Nor aught so good but, strained from that fair use$NEWLINE$Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.$NEWLINE$Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied,$NEWLINE$And vice sometime by action dignified.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$The smiling morning is replacing the frowning night. Darkness is stumbling out of the sun’s path like a drunk man. Now, before the sun comes up and burns away the dew, I have to fill this basket of mine with poisonous weeds and medicinal flowers. The Earth is nature’s mother and also nature’s tomb. Plants are born out of the Earth, and they are buried in the Earth when they die. From the Earth’s womb, many different sorts of plants and animals come forth, and the Earth provides her children with many excellent forms of nourishment. Evertything nature creates has some special property, and each one is different. Herbs, plants, and stones possess great power. There is nothing on Earth that is so evil that it does not provide the earth with some special quality. And there is nothing that does not turn bad if it’s put to the wrong use and abused. Virtue turns to vice if it’s misused. Vice sometimes becomes virtue through the right activity.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROMEO$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO enters.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: Within the infant rind of this small flower$NEWLINE$Poison hath residence and medicine power.$NEWLINE$For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;$NEWLINE$Being tasted, stays all senses with the heart.$NEWLINE$Two such opposèd kings encamp them still,$NEWLINE$In man as well as herbs—grace and rude will.
paragraphs.translated: Inside the little rind of this weak flower, there is both poison and powerful medicine. If you smell it, you feel good all over your body. But if you taste it, you die. There are two opposite elements in everything, in men as well as in herbs—good and evil.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And where the worser is predominant,$NEWLINE$Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.
paragraphs.translated: When evil is dominant, death soon kills the body like cancer.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Father.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Good morning, father.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Benedicite.$NEWLINE$What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?$NEWLINE$Young son, it argues a distempered head$NEWLINE$So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed.$NEWLINE$Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye,$NEWLINE$And where care lodges, sleep will never lie.$NEWLINE$But where unbruisèd youth with unstuffed brain$NEWLINE$Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.$NEWLINE$Therefore thy earliness doth me assure$NEWLINE$Thou art uproused by some distemperature.$NEWLINE$Or if not so, then here I hit it right:$NEWLINE$Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$God bless you. Who greets me so early in the morning? Young man, something’s wrong if you’re getting out of bed this early. Every old man has worries, and worried men never get any sleep, but young men shouldn’t have a care in the world. They should get to bed early and get plenty of sleep. Therefore, the fact that you’re awake this early tells me you’ve been upset with some anxiety. If that’s not the case, then this must be the answer: You, Romeo, have not been to bed tonight.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$That last is true. The sweeter rest was mine.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Your last guess is right. I enjoyed a sweeter rest than sleep.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$God pardon sin! Wast thou with Rosaline?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$May God forgive you if you’ve sinned!—Were you with Rosaline?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$With Rosaline, my ghostly Father? No.$NEWLINE$I have forgot that name and that name’s woe.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$With Rosaline, father? No, I have forgotten that girl and all the sadness she brought me.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$That’s my good son. But where hast thou been, then?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$That’s good, my boy. But where have you been?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.$NEWLINE$I have been feasting with mine enemy,$NEWLINE$Where on a sudden one hath wounded me,$NEWLINE$That’s by me wounded. Both our remedies$NEWLINE$Within thy help and holy physic lies.$NEWLINE$I bear no hatred, blessèd man, for, lo,$NEWLINE$My intercession likewise steads my foe.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you before you have to ask me again. I have been feasting with my enemy. Suddenly someone wounded me with love and was wounded with love by me. You have the sacred power to cure both of us. I carry no hatred, holy man, because my request will benefit my enemy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift.$NEWLINE$Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Speak plainly, make your meaning clear, my son. A jumbled confession can only receive a jumbled absolution.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Then plainly know my heart’s dear love is set$NEWLINE$On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.$NEWLINE$As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine,$NEWLINE$And all combined, save what thou must combine$NEWLINE$By holy marriage. When and where and how$NEWLINE$We met, we wooed and made exchange of vow,$NEWLINE$I’ll tell thee as we pass, but this I pray:$NEWLINE$That thou consent to marry us today.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I love rich Capulet’s daughter. I love her, and she loves me. We’re bound to each other in every possible way, except we need you to marry us. I’ll tell you more later about when and where we met, how we fell in love, and how we exchanged promises, but now I’m begging you: please, agree to marry us today.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!$NEWLINE$Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear,$NEWLINE$So soon forsaken? Young men’s love then lies$NEWLINE$Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.$NEWLINE$Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine$NEWLINE$Hath washed thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!$NEWLINE$How much salt water thrown away in waste$NEWLINE$To season love that of it doth not taste!$NEWLINE$The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears,$NEWLINE$Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears.$NEWLINE$Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit$NEWLINE$Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.$NEWLINE$If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine,$NEWLINE$Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.$NEWLINE$And art thou changed? Pronounce this sentence then:$NEWLINE$Women may fall when there’s no strength in men.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Holy Saint Francis, this is a drastic change! Have you given up so quickly on Rosaline, whom you loved so much? Then young men love with their eyes, not with their hearts. Jesus and Mary, how many tears did you cry for Rosaline? How many salty tear-drops did you waste salting a love you never tasted? The sun hasn’t yet melted away the fog you made with all your sighs. The groans you used to make are still ringing in my old ears. There’s still a stain on your cheek from an old tear that hasn’t been washed off yet. If you were ever yourself, and this sadness was yours, you and your sadness were all for Rosaline. And now you’ve changed? Then repeat this after me: you can’t expect women to be faithful when men are so unreliable.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Thou chid’st me oft for loving Rosaline.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$You scolded me often for loving Rosaline.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I scolded you for obsessing about her, not for loving her, my student.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$And badest me bury love.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$And you told me to bury my love.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Not in a grave,$NEWLINE$To lay one in, another out to have.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I didn’t tell you to get rid of one love and replace her with another.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I pray thee, chide not. Her I love now$NEWLINE$Doth grace for grace and love for love allow.$NEWLINE$The other did not so.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Please, I beg you, don’t scold me. The girl I love now returns my love. The other girl did not love me.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, she knew well$NEWLINE$Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.$NEWLINE$But come, young waverer, come, go with me,$NEWLINE$In one respect I’ll thy assistant be,$NEWLINE$For this alliance may so happy prove$NEWLINE$To turn your households' rancor to pure love.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, she knew very well that you were acting like you were in love without really knowing what love means. But come on, inconsistent young man, come with me. I’ll help you with your secret wedding. This marriage may be lucky enough to turn the hatred between your families into pure love.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, let us hence. I stand on sudden haste.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Let’s get out of here. I’m in a rush.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Wisely and slow. They stumble that run fast.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Go wisely and slowly. Those who rush stumble and fall.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BENVOLIO and MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO and MERCUTIO enter.$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Where the devil should this Romeo be?$NEWLINE$Came he not home tonight?
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Where the devil can Romeo be? Didn’t he come home last night?

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Not to his father’s. I spoke with his man.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Not to his father’s house. I asked a servant.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline,$NEWLINE$Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$That fair-skinned, hard-hearted hussy, Rosaline is going to torment him until he goes insane.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Tybalt, the kinsman to old Capulet,$NEWLINE$Hath sent a letter to his father’s house.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Tybalt, old Capulet’s nephew, has sent a letter to Romeo’s father’s house.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$A challenge, on my life.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$I bet it’s a challenge.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Romeo will answer it.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Romeo will answer the challenge.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Any man that can write may answer a letter.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Any man who knows how to write can answer a letter.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Nay, he will answer the letter’s master, how he dares, being dared.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$No, Romeo will respond to the letter’s writer, telling him whether he accepts the challenge.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Alas, poor Romeo! He is already dead, stabbed with a white wench’s black eye, shot through the ear with a love song, the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy’s butt shaft. And is he a man to encounter Tybalt?
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Oh, poor Romeo! He’s already dead. He’s been stabbed by a white girl’s black eye. He’s been cut through the ear with a love song. The center of his heart has been split by blind Cupid’s arrow. Is he man enough at this point to face off with Tybalt?

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Why, what is Tybalt?
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Why, what’s Tybalt’s story?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$More than Prince of Cats. Oh, he’s the courageous captain of compliments. He fights as you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and proportion. He rests his minim rests—one, two, and the third in your bosom. The very butcher of a silk button, a duelist, a duelist, a gentleman of the very first house of the first and second cause. Ah, the immortal passado, the punto reverso, the hai!$NEWLINE$passado$NEWLINE$punto reverso$NEWLINE$hai!
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$He’s tougher than the
Prince of Cats. He does everything by the book. He fights like you sing at a recital, paying attention to time, distance, and proportion. He takes the proper breaks: one, two, and the third in your heart. He’s the butcher who can hit any silk button. A master of duels. He’s a gentleman from the finest school of fencing. He knows how to turn any argument into a swordfight.
He knows passado—the forward thrust—the punto reverso—the backhand thrust—and the hai—the thrust that goes straight through.$NEWLINE$Prince of Cats$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$He knows$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$passado$NEWLINE$punto reverso$NEWLINE$hai

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$The what?
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$He knows what?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$The pox of such antic, lisping, affecting fantasmines, these new tuners of accents! “By Jesu, a very good blade! A very tall man! A very good whore!” Why, is not this a lamentable thing, grandsire, that we should be thus afflicted with these strange flies, these fashion-mongers, these “pardon me’s,” who stand so much on the new form, that they cannot sit at ease on the old bench? Oh, their bones, their bones!
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$I hate these crazy, affected guys who use foreign phrases and newfangled expressions. I hate their strange manners and their weird accents! I hate it when they say, “By Jesus, this is a very good blade, a very brave man, a very good whore.” Isn’t this a sad thing, my good man? Why should we put up with these foreign buzzards, these fashionmongers, these guys who say “pardon me,” these guys who care so much about manners that they can’t kick back on a bench without whining? “Oh, my aching bones!”

paragraphs.original: Enter ROMEO$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO enters.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo!

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Without his roe, like a dried herring. O flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified! Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in. Laura to his lady was but a kitchen-wench— marry, she had a better love to berhyme her—Dido a dowdy, Cleopatra a gypsy, Helen and Hero hildings and harlots, Thisbe a grey eye or so, but not to the purpose.— Signior Romeo, bonjour! There’s a French salutation to your French slop. You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night.$NEWLINE$bonjour!
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$He looks skinny, like a dried herring without its eggs, and he hasn’t got his girl. O flesh, flesh, you’ve turned pale and weak like a fish. Now he’s ready for
Petrarch’s poetry. Compared to Romeo’s girl, Laura was a kitchen slave. Surely she has a better love to make rhymes for her. Dido was shabbily dressed. Cleopatra was a gypsy girl. Helen and Hero were sluts and harlots. Thisbe might have had a blue eye or two, but that doesn’t matter. Signor Romeo, bonjour. There’s a French greeting that matches your drooping French-style pants. You faked us out pretty good last night.$NEWLINE$Petrarch’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$bonjour.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit did I give you?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Good morning to you both. What do you mean I faked you out?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$The slip, sir, the slip. Can you not conceive?
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$You gave us the slip, sir, the slip. Can’t you understand what I’m saying?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great, and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Excuse me, good Mercutio. I had very important business to take care of. It was so important that I had to forget about courtesy and good manners.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$That’s as much as to say, such a case as yours constrains a man to bow in the hams.
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$In other words “important business” made you
flex your buttocks.$NEWLINE$flex your buttocks$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Meaning “to curtsy”?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$You mean do a curtsy?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Thou hast most kindly hit it.
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$You’ve hit the
target, sir.$NEWLINE$target$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$A most courteous exposition.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$That’s a very polite and courteous explanation.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Yes, I am the pink flower—the master, of courtesy and manners.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Pink for flower.
paragraphs.translated:
ROMEO$NEWLINE$The
pink flower.$NEWLINE$pink flower$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Right.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Right.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Why, then is my pump well flowered.
paragraphs.translated:
ROMEO$NEWLINE$Well, then my
pump is well decorated with flowers.$NEWLINE$pump$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Sure wit, follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it is worn, the jest may remain, after the wearing solely singular.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Alright my witty friend, this joke has worn out your pump. Its thin skin is all worn out. The joke is all you have left.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$O single-soled jest, solely singular for the singleness.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$This is a bad joke. It’s all silliness.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Come between us, good Benvolio. My wits faints.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Come break this up, Benvolio. I’m losing this duel of wits.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I’ll cry a match.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Keep going, keep going, or I’ll declare myself the winner.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, I am done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five. Was I with you there for the goose?
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Now, if our jokes go on a wild-goose chase, I’m finished. You have more wild goose in one of your jokes than I have in five of mine. Was I even close to you in the chase for the goose?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there for the goose.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$You were never with me for anything if you weren’t there for the goose.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$I’ll bite you on the ear for that joke.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Nay, good goose, bite not.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$No, good goose, don’t bite me.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting. It is a most sharp sauce.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Your joke is a very bitter apple. Your humor is a spicy sauce.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$And is it not well served into a sweet goose?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Then isn’t it just the right dish for a sweet goose?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Oh, that’s a joke made out of leather that spreads itself thin, from the width of an inch to as fat as a yard.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I stretch it out for that word “broad,” which, added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I stretch my joke for that word “fat.” If you add that word to the word “goose,” it shows that you are a fat goose.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Why, is not this better now than groaning for love? Now art thou sociable. Now art thou Romeo. Now art thou what thou art—by art as well as by nature, for this driveling love is like a great natural that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Why, isn’t all this joking better than groaning about love? Now you’re sociable. Now you’re Romeo. Now you are what you’ve learned to be and what you are naturally. This love of yours was like a blithering idiot who runs up and down looking for a hole to hide his
toy in.$NEWLINE$toy$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Stop there, stop there.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Stop there, stop there.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$You want me to stop my
tale before I’m done.$NEWLINE$tale$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Otherwise your tale would have gotten too long.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Oh, thou art deceived. I would have made it short, for I was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Oh, you’re wrong. I would have made it short. I had come to the deepest part of my tale, and I planned to say nothing more on the topic.

paragraphs.original: Enter NURSE and her man PETER$NEWLINE$NURSE$NEWLINE$PETER
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE enters with her servant, PETER.$NEWLINE$NURSE$NEWLINE$PETER

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Here’s goodly gear.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Here’s something good.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$A sail, a sail!
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$A sail, a sail!$NEWLINE$A sail, a sail!$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Two, two—a shirt and a smock.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$There’s two—a man and a woman.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Peter!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Peter!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$Anon!
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$I’m at your service.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$My fan, Peter.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Give me my fan, Peter.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Good, Peter, to hide her face, for her fan’s the fairer face.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Good Peter, give her her fan to hide her face. Her fan is prettier than her face.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$God ye good morrow, gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Good morning, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$God ye good e'en, fair gentlewoman.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Good afternoon, fair lady.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Is it good e'en?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Is it now afternoon?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$'Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.
paragraphs.translated:
MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$It’s not earlier than that, I tell you. The
lusty hand of the clock is now pricking noon.$NEWLINE$lusty hand$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Out upon you! What a man are you?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Get out of here! What kind of man are you?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$I’m a man, my lady, that God has made for himself to ruin.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$By my troth, it is well said. “For himself to mar,” quoth he? Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$I swear, you speak the truth. “For himself to ruin,” he says. Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I can find young Romeo?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him. I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you find him than he was when you started looking for him. I am the youngest man by that name, because there is no one younger, or worse.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$You say well.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$You speak well.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Yea, is the worst well? Very well took, i' faith, wisely, wisely.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Is the worst well? Very well taken, I believe, very wise.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$If you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with you.
paragraphs.translated:
NURSE$NEWLINE$(to ROMEO) If you’re the Romeo I’m looking for, sir, I would like to have a
confidence with you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$confidence$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$She will indite him to some supper.
paragraphs.translated:
BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$She will
indite him to some dinner party.$NEWLINE$indite$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$A bawd, a bawd, a bawd! So ho!
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$A pimp! A pimp! A pimp! I’ve found it out.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What hast thou found?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What have you found out?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$No hare, sir, unless a hare, sir, in a Lenten pie—that is, something stale and hoar ere it be spent.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$She’s not a prostitute unless she’s using her ugliness to hide her promiscuity.

paragraphs.original: (sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$An old hare hoar,$NEWLINE$An old hare hoar,$NEWLINE$And an old hare hoar,$NEWLINE$And an old hare hoar,$NEWLINE$Is very good meat in Lent.$NEWLINE$Is very good meat in Lent.$NEWLINE$But a hare that is hoar$NEWLINE$But a hare that is hoar$NEWLINE$Is too much for a score$NEWLINE$Is too much for a score$NEWLINE$When it hoars ere it be spent.$NEWLINE$When it hoars ere it be spent.$NEWLINE$(speaks)$NEWLINE$(speaks)
paragraphs.translated: (he walks by them and sings)$NEWLINE$(he walks by them and sings)$NEWLINE$Old rabbit meat is good to eat,$NEWLINE$Old rabbit meat is good to eat,$NEWLINE$If you can’t get anything else.$NEWLINE$If you can’t get anything else.$NEWLINE$But if it’s so old,$NEWLINE$But if it’s so old,$NEWLINE$That it goes bad before you eat it,$NEWLINE$That it goes bad before you eat it,$NEWLINE$Then it was a waste of money.$NEWLINE$Then it was a waste of money.$NEWLINE$(speaking)$NEWLINE$(speaking)

paragraphs.original: Romeo, will you come to your father’s? We’ll to dinner, thither.
paragraphs.translated: Romeo, are you going to your father’s for lunch? Let’s go there.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I will follow you.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I’ll follow after you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Farewell, ancient lady. Farewell, lady, lady, lady.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Goodbye, old lady. Goodbye, lady, lady, lady.$NEWLINE$Goodbye, old lady. Goodbye, lady, lady, lady.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MERCUTIO and BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO and MERCUTIO exit.$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this that was so full of his ropery?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Please tell me, sir, who was that foulmouthed punk who was so full of crude jokes?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$A gentleman, Nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Nurse, he’s a man who likes to hear the sound of his own voice. He says more in one minute than he does in a whole month.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$An he speak any thing against me, I’ll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks. And if I cannot, I’ll find those that shall.
