Scurvy knave! I am none of his flirt-gills. I am none of his skains-mates. (to PETER) And thou must stand by, too, and suffer every knave to use me at his pleasure?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$If he says anything against me, I’ll humble him, even if he were stronger than he is—and twenty punks like him. If I can’t do it myself, I’ll find someone who can. That dirty rat! I’m not one of his sluts. I’m not one of his punk friends who carries a knife. (to PETER) And you just stand there letting every jerk make fun of me for kicks.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$I saw no man use you at his pleasure. If I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you. I dare draw as soon as another man if I see occasion in a good quarrel and the law on my side.
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$I didn’t see anybody use you for kicks. If I had seen something like that, I would have quickly pulled out my weapon. Believe me, I’ll draw my sword as quick as any other man if I see a fight starting and the law is on my side.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part about me quivers. Scurvy knave!$NEWLINE$(to ROMEO) Pray you, sir, a word. And as I told you, my young lady bid me inquire you out. What she bade me say, I will keep to myself. But first let me tell ye, if ye should lead her into a fool’s paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say. For the gentlewoman is young, and therefore, if you should deal double with her, truly it were an ill thing to be offered to any gentlewoman, and very weak dealing.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Now, I swear, I’m so angry that I’m shaking all over. That rotten scoundrel! (to ROMEO) Now, please, may I have a word with you, sir? My young mistress asked me to find you. What she asked me to say I’ll keep to myself. But let me tell you this first. If you lead her into a fool’s paradise, as the saying goes, it would be an outrageous crime because the girl is so young. And if you try to trick her, it would be an evil thing to do to any woman and very poor behavior.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress. I protest unto thee—
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Nurse, give my regards to to your lady. I swear to you—

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Good heart, and i' faith, I will tell her as much. Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$You have a good heart, and believe me, I’ll tell her that. Lord, Lord, she’ll be a happy woman.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What wilt thou tell her, Nurse? Thou dost not mark me.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What are you going to tell her, Nurse? You’re not paying attention to me.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$I will tell her, sir, that you do protest, which, as I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.
paragraphs.translated:
NURSE$NEWLINE$Sir, I’ll tell her that you
protest to her, which I think is the gentlemanly thing to do..$NEWLINE$protest$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Bid her devise$NEWLINE$Some means to come to shrift this afternoon.$NEWLINE$And there she shall at Friar Lawrence' cell$NEWLINE$Be shrived and married. (gives her coins) Here is for thy pains.$NEWLINE$(gives her coins)
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Tell her to devise a plan to get out of her house and come to confession at the abbey this afternoon. At Friar Lawrence’s cell she can make confession and be married. (giving her coins) Here is a reward for your efforts.$NEWLINE$(giving her coins)

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$No, truly, sir. Not a penny.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$No, really, I won’t take a penny.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Go to. I say you shall.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Go on, I insist you take it.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$(takes the money) This afternoon, sir? Well, she shall be there.$NEWLINE$(takes the money)
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$(taking the money) This afternoon, sir? She’ll be there.$NEWLINE$(taking the money)

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$And stay, good Nurse. Behind the abbey wall$NEWLINE$Within this hour my man shall be with thee$NEWLINE$And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair,$NEWLINE$Which to the high top-gallant of my joy$NEWLINE$Must be my convoy in the secret night.$NEWLINE$Farewell. Be trusty, and I’ll quit thy pains.$NEWLINE$Farewell. Commend me to thy mistress.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Wait good Nurse. Within an hour, one of my men will come to you behind the abbey wall and give you a rope ladder. I’ll use the rope ladder to climb over the walls at night. Then I’ll meet Juliet joyfully and in secret. Goodbye. Be honest and helpful, and I’ll repay you for your efforts. Goodbye. Sing my praises to your mistress.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Now God in heaven bless thee! Hark you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$May God in heaven bless you. Now please listen, sir.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What sayst thou, my dear Nurse?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What do you have to say, my dear Nurse?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Is your man secret? Did you ne'er hear say,$NEWLINE$“Two may keep counsel, putting one away”?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Can your man keep a secret? Haven’t you ever heard the saying, “Two can conspire to put one away”?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Warrant thee, my man’s as true as steel.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I assure you, my man is as true as steel.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.—Lord, Lord! when ’twas a little prating thing.—Oh, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard, but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him. I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man. But, I’ll warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world. Doth not rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?$NEWLINE$rosemary$NEWLINE$Romeo
paragraphs.translated:
NURSE$NEWLINE$Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady. Lord, Lord, when she was a little baby—Oh, there is one nobleman in the city, a guy named Paris, who would be happy to claim her as his own. Juliet would rather look at a toad than at him. I make her angry sometimes by saying that Paris is more handsome than you are. But when I say so, I swear she turns white as a sheet. Don’t “
rosemary” and “Romeo” begin with the same letter?$NEWLINE$rosemary$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Ay, Nurse, what of that? Both with an R.$NEWLINE$R
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Yes, Nurse, what about that? They both begin with the letter “R.”

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Ah, mocker, that’s the dog’s name. R is for the—No, I know it begins with some other letter, and she hath the prettiest sententious of it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good to hear it.$NEWLINE$R
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Ah, you jokester—that’s the dog’s name. “R” is for the—no, I know it begins with another letter. She says the most beautiful things about you and rosemary. It would be good for you to hear the things she says.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Commend me to thy lady.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Give my compliments to your lady.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Ay, a thousand times.—Peter!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Yes, a thousand times. Peter!

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$Anon!
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$I’m ready.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Before and apace.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$(giving PETER her fan) Go ahead. Go quickly.$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$her fan)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter JULIET$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET enters.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$The clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse.$NEWLINE$In half an hour she promised to return.$NEWLINE$Perchance she cannot meet him. That’s not so.$NEWLINE$Oh, she is lame! Love’s heralds should be thoughts,$NEWLINE$Which ten times faster glide than the sun’s beams,$NEWLINE$Driving back shadows over louring hills.$NEWLINE$Therefore do nimble-pinioned doves draw love$NEWLINE$And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.$NEWLINE$Now is the sun upon the highmost hill$NEWLINE$Of this day’s journey, and from nine till twelve$NEWLINE$Is three long hours, yet she is not come.$NEWLINE$Had she affections and warm youthful blood,$NEWLINE$She would be as swift in motion as a ball.$NEWLINE$My words would bandy her to my sweet love,$NEWLINE$And his to me.$NEWLINE$But old folks, many feign as they were dead,$NEWLINE$Unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I sent the Nurse at nine o'clock. Maybe she can’t find him. That can’t be. Oh, she’s slow! Love’s messengers should be thoughts, which fly ten times faster than sunbeams. They should be strong enough to push shadows over the dark hills. That’s the way doves carry Venus so fast, and that’s why Cupid has wings that let him fly as fast as the wind. Now it’s noon. That’s three hours since nine o'clock, but she hasn’t come back. If she was young and passionate, she’d move as fast as a ball. My words would bounce her to my sweet love, and his words would bounce her back to me. But a lot of old people act like they’re already dead—sluggish, slow, fat, and colorless, like lead.

paragraphs.original: Enter NURSE and PETER$NEWLINE$NURSE$NEWLINE$PETER
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE and PETER enter.$NEWLINE$NURSE$NEWLINE$PETER

paragraphs.original: O God, she comes.—O honey Nurse, what news?$NEWLINE$Hast thou met with him? Send thy man away.
paragraphs.translated: Oh my God, here she comes! Oh sweet Nurse, what news do you bring? Have you spoken to him? Send your man away.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Peter, stay at the gate.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Peter, wait for me at the gate.

paragraphs.original: Exit PETER$NEWLINE$PETER
paragraphs.translated: PETER exits.$NEWLINE$PETER

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Now, good sweet Nurse— O Lord, why look’st thou sad?$NEWLINE$Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily.$NEWLINE$If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news$NEWLINE$By playing it to me with so sour a face.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Now, good sweet Nurse—Oh Lord, why do you look so sad? Even if the news is sad, tell me with a smile on your face. If the news is good, you’re ruining the sweet news by playing a trick with a sour face like that.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$I am aweary. Give me leave awhile.$NEWLINE$Fie, how my bones ache! What a jaunt have I!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$I am tired. Leave me alone for a minute. Oh my, my bones ache so much. I’ve been running all over the place.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I would thou hadst my bones and I thy news.$NEWLINE$Nay, come, I pray thee, speak. Good, good Nurse, speak.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I wish you had my bones, and I had your news. Come on now, I beg you, speak, good Nurse, speak.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Jesu, what haste! Can you not stay awhile?$NEWLINE$Do you not see that I am out of breath?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Sweet Jesus, you’re in such a hurry! Can’t you wait for a moment? Don’t you see that I’m out of breath?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath$NEWLINE$To say to me that thou art out of breath?$NEWLINE$The excuse that thou dost make in this delay$NEWLINE$Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.$NEWLINE$Is thy news good, or bad? Answer to that.$NEWLINE$Say either, and I’ll stay the circumstance.$NEWLINE$Let me be satisfied. Is ’t good or bad?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$How can you be out of breath when you have enough breath to tell me that you’re out of breath? The excuse you make to delay the news is longer than the news itself. Is the news good or bad? Answer that question. Tell me if it’s good or bad, and I’ll wait for the details. Tell me so I can be satisfied. Is it good or bad?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Well, you have made a simple choice. You know not how to choose a man. Romeo! No, not he, though his face be better than any man’s, yet his leg excels all men’s, and for a hand and a foot and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they are past compare. He is not the flower of courtesy, but, I’ll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb. Go thy ways, wench. Serve God. What, have you dined at home?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Well, you have made a foolish choice. You don’t know how to pick a man. Romeo? No, not him, though his face is more handsome than any man’s, and his legs are prettier, and as for his hands and feet and body, they’re not much to speak of, and yet they’re beyond compare. He’s not the most polite man in the world, but, believe me, he’s gentle as a lamb. Well, do what you want. Be good. Have you had lunch yet?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$No, no. But all this did I know before.$NEWLINE$What says he of our marriage? What of that?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$No, I haven’t had lunch. Everything you told me I already knew. What does he say about our marriage? What about that?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Lord, how my head aches! What a head have I!$NEWLINE$It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.$NEWLINE$My back a' t' other side. Ah, my back, my back!$NEWLINE$Beshrew your heart for sending me about,$NEWLINE$To catch my death with jaunting up and down!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Lord, what a headache I’ve got! My head is pounding. It feels like it’ll break into twenty pieces. My back aches too—(JULIET rubs her back) Ooh, on the other side—ah, my poor aching back! Curse your heart for sending me running all over town. I could get sick and die.$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$rubs her back)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.$NEWLINE$Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what says my love?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Believe me, I’m sorry you’re in pain. Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what did my love Romeo say?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, a virtuous— Where is your mother?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Your love says, like an honorable gentleman, who is courteous, kind, handsome, and, I believe, virtuous— where is your mother?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Where is my mother? Why, she is within.$NEWLINE$Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest!$NEWLINE$“Your love says, like an honest gentleman,$NEWLINE$'Where is your mother?'”
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Where is my mother? Why, she’s inside. Where else would she be? Your answer is so strange! “Your love says, like an honorable gentleman, 'Where is your mother?'”

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$O God’s lady dear,$NEWLINE$Are you so hot? Marry, come up, I trow.$NEWLINE$Is this the poultice for my aching bones?$NEWLINE$Henceforward do your messages yourself.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh holy Mary, mother of God! Are you this impatient? Come on, you’re being ridiculous! Is this the cure for my aching bones? From now on, take care of your messages yourself.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Here’s such a coil. Come, what says Romeo?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$You’re making such a fuss. Come on, what did Romeo say?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Have you got leave to go to shrift today?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Do you have permission to go out and take confession today?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I have.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I do.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence’s cell.$NEWLINE$There stays a husband to make you a wife.$NEWLINE$Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks.$NEWLINE$They’ll be in scarlet straight at any news.$NEWLINE$Hie you to church. I must another way$NEWLINE$To fetch a ladder, by the which your love$NEWLINE$Must climb a bird’s nest soon when it is dark.$NEWLINE$I am the drudge and toil in your delight,$NEWLINE$But you shall bear the burden soon at night.$NEWLINE$Go. I’ll to dinner. Hie you to the cell.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Then hurry up and rush over to Friar Lawrence’s cell. There’s a husband there who’s waiting to make you his wife. Now I see the blood rushing to your cheeks. You blush bright red as soon as you hear any news. Go to the church. I must go by a different path to get a rope ladder. Your love will use it to climb up to your window while it’s dark. I do the drudge work for your pleasure. But soon you’ll be doing a wife’s work all night long. Go. I’ll go to lunch. You go to Friar Lawrence’s cell.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Hie to high fortune! Honest Nurse, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Wish me luck. Thank you, dear Nurse.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FRIAR LAWRENCE and ROMEO$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE and ROMEO enter.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$So smile the heavens upon this holy act$NEWLINE$That after-hours with sorrow chide us not.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$May the heavens be happy with this holy act of marriage, so nothing unfortunate happens later to make us regret it.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Amen, amen. But come what sorrow can,$NEWLINE$It cannot countervail the exchange of joy$NEWLINE$That one short minute gives me in her sight.$NEWLINE$Do thou but close our hands with holy words,$NEWLINE$Then love-devouring death do what he dare;$NEWLINE$It is enough I may but call her mine.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Amen, amen. But whatever misfortunes occur, they can’t ruin the joy I feel with one look at her. All you have to do is join our hands with holy words, then love-destroying death can do whatever it pleases. It’s enough for me if I can call her mine.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$These violent delights have violent ends$NEWLINE$And in their triumph die, like fire and powder,$NEWLINE$Which, as they kiss, consume. The sweetest honey$NEWLINE$Is loathsome in his own deliciousness$NEWLINE$And in the taste confounds the appetite.$NEWLINE$Therefore love moderately. Long love doth so.$NEWLINE$Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$These sudden joys have sudden endings. They burn up in victory like fire and gunpowder. When they meet, as in a kiss, they explode. Too much honey is delicious, but it makes you sick to your stomach. Therefore, love each other in moderation. That is the key to long-lasting love. Too fast is as bad as too slow.

paragraphs.original: Enter JULIET, somewhat fast, and embraceth ROMEO$NEWLINE$JULIET$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: JULIET enters in a rush and embraces ROMEO.$NEWLINE$JULIET$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: Here comes the lady. Oh, so light a foot$NEWLINE$Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint.$NEWLINE$A lover may bestride the gossamers$NEWLINE$That idles in the wanton summer air,$NEWLINE$And yet not fall. So light is vanity.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes the lady. Oh,a footstep as light as hers will never endure the rocky road of life. Lovers are so light they can walk on a spiderweb floating on a summer breeze, and yet not fall. That’s how flimsy and unreal pleasure is.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Good even to my ghostly confessor.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Good evening, my spiritual confessor.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Romeo will thank you, my girl, for both of us.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$As much to him, else is his thanks too much.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I’ll give him equal thanks, so we’re even.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy$NEWLINE$Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more$NEWLINE$To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath$NEWLINE$This neighbor air, and let rich music’s tongue$NEWLINE$Unfold the imagined happiness that both$NEWLINE$Receive in either by this dear encounter.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Ah, Juliet if you’re as happy as I am, and you’re better with words, tell me about the happiness you imagine we’ll have in our marriage.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Conceit, more rich in matter than in words,$NEWLINE$Brags of his substance, not of ornament.$NEWLINE$They are but beggars that can count their worth.$NEWLINE$But my true love is grown to such excess$NEWLINE$I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I can imagine more than I can say—I have more on my mind than words. Anyone who can count how much he has is poor. My true love has made me so rich that I can’t count even half of my wealth.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Come, come with me, and we will make short work.$NEWLINE$For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone$NEWLINE$Till holy church incorporate two in one.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Come, come with me, and we’ll do the job quickly. Because if you don’t mind, I’m not leaving you two alone until you’re united in marriage.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MERCUTIO, BENVOLIO, Mercutio’s PAGE, and others$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO, his page, and BENVOLIO enter with other men.$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$I pray thee, good Mercutio, let’s retire.$NEWLINE$The day is hot; the Capulets, abroad;$NEWLINE$And if we meet we shall not ’scape a brawl,$NEWLINE$For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$I’m begging you, good Mercutio, let’s call it a day. It’s hot outside, and the Capulets are wandering around. If we bump into them, we’ll certainly get into a fight. When it’s hot outside, people become angry and hot-blooded.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Thou art like one of those fellows that, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword upon the table and says “God send me no need of thee!” and, by the operation of the second cup, draws it on the drawer when indeed there is no need.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$You’re like one of those guys who walks into a bar, slams his sword on the table, and then says, “I pray I never have to use you.” By the time he orders his second drink, he pulls his sword on the bartender for no reason at all.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Am I like such a fellow?
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Am I really like one of those guys?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to be moved.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Come on, you can be as angry as any guy in Italy when you’re in the mood. When someone does the smallest thing to make you angry, you get angry. And when you’re in the mood to get angry, you find something to get angry about.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$And what to?
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$And what about that?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other. Thou, why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast. Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes. What eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel? Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling. Thou hast quarreled with a man for coughing in the street because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun. Didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter? With another, for tying his new shoes with old ribbon? And yet thou wilt tutor me from quarreling!
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$If there were two men like you, pretty soon there’d be none because the two of you would kill each other. You would fight with a man if he had one more whisker or one less whisker in his beard than you have in your beard. You’ll fight with a man who’s cracking nuts just because you have hazelnut-colored eyes. Only you would look for a fight like that. Your head is as full of fights as an egg is full of yolk, but your head has been beaten like scrambled eggs from so much fighting. You started a fight with a man who coughed in the street because he woke up a dog that was sleeping in the sun. Didn’t you argue it out with your tailor for wearing one of his new suits before the right season? And with another for tying the new shoes he made with old laces? And yet you’re the one who wants to teach me about restraint!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$If I were in the habit of fighting the way you are, my life insurance rates would be sky high.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$The fee simple? O simple!
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Your life insurance? That’s foolish.

paragraphs.original: Enter TYBALT, PETRUCHIO, and other CAPULETS$NEWLINE$TYBALT$NEWLINE$PETRUCHIO$NEWLINE$CAPULETS
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT, PETRUCHIO, and CAPULETS enter.$NEWLINE$TYBALT$NEWLINE$PETRUCHIO$NEWLINE$CAPULETS

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$By my head, here comes the Capulets.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Oh great, here come the Capulets.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$By my heel, I care not.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Well, well, I don’t care.

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Follow me close, for I will speak to them.$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, good e'en. A word with one of you.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$(to PETRUCCIO and others) Follow me closely, I’ll talk to them. (to the MONTAGUES) Good afternoon, gentlemen. I’d like to have a word with one of you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and others)$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$And but one word with one of us? Couple it with something. Make it a word and a blow.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$You just want one word with one of us? Put it together with something else. Make it a word and a blow.

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$You’ll find me ready enough to do that, sir, if you give me a reason.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Could you not take some occasion without giving?
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Can’t you find a reason without my giving you one?

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Mercutio, thou consort’st with Romeo.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Mercutio, you hang out with Romeo.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Consort? What, dost thou make us minstrels? An thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords. Here’s my fiddlestick. Here’s that shall make you dance. Zounds, “consort”!
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$“Hang out?” Who do you think we are, musicians in a band? If we look like musicians to you, you can expect to hear nothing but noise. (touching the blade of his sword) This is my fiddlestick. I’ll use it to make you dance. Goddammit—“Hang out!”$NEWLINE$(touching the blade of his sword)

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$We talk here in the public haunt of men.$NEWLINE$Either withdraw unto some private place,$NEWLINE$And reason coldly of your grievances,$NEWLINE$Or else depart. Here all eyes gaze on us.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$We’re talking here in a public place. Either go someplace private, or talk it over rationally, or else just go away. Out here everybody can see us.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Men’s eyes were made to look and let them gaze.$NEWLINE$I will not budge for no man’s pleasure, I.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Men’s eyes were made to see things, so let them watch. I won’t move to please anybody.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROMEO$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO enters.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Well, peace be with you, sir. Here comes my man.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Well, may peace be with you. Here comes my man, the man I’m looking for.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$But I’ll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery.$NEWLINE$Marry, go before to field, he’ll be your follower.$NEWLINE$Your worship in that sense may call him “man.”
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$He’s not your man. Alright, walk out into a field, and he’ll chase you. In that sense you can call him your “man.”

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Romeo, the love I bear thee can afford$NEWLINE$No better term than this: thou art a villain.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Romeo, there’s only one thing I can call you. You’re a villain.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee$NEWLINE$Doth much excuse the appertaining rage$NEWLINE$To such a greeting. Villain am I none.$NEWLINE$Therefore, farewell. I see thou know’st me not.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Tybalt, I have a reason to love you that lets me put aside the rage I should feel and excuse that insult. I am no villain. So, goodbye. I can tell that you don’t know who I am.

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries$NEWLINE$That thou hast done me. Therefore turn and draw.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Boy, your words can’t excuse the harm you’ve done to me. So now turn and draw your sword.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I do protest I never injured thee,$NEWLINE$But love thee better than thou canst devise,$NEWLINE$Till thou shalt know the reason of my love.$NEWLINE$And so, good Capulet—which name I tender$NEWLINE$As dearly as my own—be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I disagree. I’ve never done you harm. I love you more than you can understand until you know the reason why I love you. And so, good Capulet—which is a name I love like my own name—you should be satisfied with what I say.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$O calm dishonourable, vile submission!$NEWLINE$Alla stoccata carries it away. (draws his sword)$NEWLINE$Alla stoccata$NEWLINE$(draws his sword)$NEWLINE$Tybalt, you ratcatcher, will you walk?
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$This calm submission is dishonorable and vile. The thrust of a sword will end this surrender. (draws his sword)Tybalt, you rat-catcher, will you go fight me?$NEWLINE$(draws his sword)

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$What wouldst thou have with me?
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$What do you want from me?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Good King of Cats, nothing but one of your nine lives, that I mean to make bold withal, and, as you shall use me hereafter, dry-beat the rest of the eight. Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears? Make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Good King of Cats, I want to take one of your nine lives. I’ll take one, and, depending on how you treat me after that, I might beat the other eight out of you too. Will you pull your sword out of its sheath? Hurry up, or I’ll smack you on the ears with my sword before you have yours drawn.

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$I am for you. (draws his sword)$NEWLINE$(draws his sword)
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$I’ll fight you. (he draws his sword)$NEWLINE$(he draws his sword)

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Noble Mercutio, put your sword away.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Come, sir, your passado.$NEWLINE$passado
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$(to TYBALT) Come on, sir, perform your forward thrust, your passado.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$passado.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO and TYBALT fight$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$TYBALT
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO and TYBALT fight$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$TYBALT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(draws his sword) Draw, Benvolio. Beat down their weapons.$NEWLINE$(draws his sword)$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, for shame! Forbear this outrage.$NEWLINE$Tybalt, Mercutio! The Prince expressly hath$NEWLINE$Forbidden bandying in Verona streets.$NEWLINE$Hold, Tybalt! Good Mercutio!
paragraphs.translated: (drawing his sword) Draw your sword, Benvolio. Let’s beat down their weapons. Gentlemen, stop this disgraceful fight. Tybalt, Mercutio, the Prince has banned fighting in the streets of Verona. Stop, Tybalt. Stop, good Mercutio.$NEWLINE$(drawing his sword)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO tries to break up the fight TYBALT stabs MERCUTIO under ROMEO’s am$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$TYBALT$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO tries to break up the fight. TYBALT reaches under ROMEO’s arm and stabs MERCUTIO.$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$TYBALT$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO

paragraphs.original: PETRUCHIO$NEWLINE$Away, Tybalt.
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO$NEWLINE$Let’s get away, Tybalt.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt TYBALT, PETRUCHIO, and the other CAPULETS$NEWLINE$TYBALT$NEWLINE$PETRUCHIO$NEWLINE$CAPULETS
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT, PETRUCHIO, and the other CAPULETS exit.$NEWLINE$TYBALT$NEWLINE$PETRUCHIO$NEWLINE$CAPULETS

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$I am hurt.$NEWLINE$A plague o' both your houses! I am sped.$NEWLINE$Is he gone and hath nothing?
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$I’ve been hurt. May a plague curse both your families. I’m finished. Did he get away clean?

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$What, art thou hurt?
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$What, are you hurt?

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch. Marry, ’tis enough.$NEWLINE$Where is my page?—Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Yes, yes. It’s a scratch, just a scratch. But it’s enough. Where is my page? Go, boy. Get me a doctor.

paragraphs.original: Exit MERCUTIO'S PAGE$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO'S PAGE
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO'S PAGE exits.$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO'S PAGE

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Courage, man. The hurt cannot be much.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Have courage, man. The wound can’t be that bad.

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$No, ’tis not so deep as a well nor so wide as a church-door, but ’tis enough, ’twill serve. Ask for me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man. I am peppered, I warrant, for this world. A plague o' both your houses! Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death! A braggart, a rogue, a villain that fights by the book of arithmetic! Why the devil came you between us? I was hurt under your arm.$NEWLINE$
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$No, it’s not as deep as a well, or as wide as a church door, but it’s enough. It’ll do the job. Ask for me tomorrow, and you’ll find me in a grave. I’m done for in this world, I believe. May a plague strike both your houses. Goddammit! I can’t believe that dog, that rat, that mouse, that cat could scratch me to death! That braggart, punk villain who fights like he learned swordsmanship from a manual! Why the hell did you come in between us? He struck me from under your arm.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I thought all for the best.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I thought it was the right thing to do.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Help me into some house, Benvolio,$NEWLINE$Or I shall faint. A plague o' both your houses!$NEWLINE$They have made worms' meat of me. I have it,$NEWLINE$And soundly too. Your houses!
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$Take me inside some house, Benvolio, or I’ll pass out. May a plague strike both your families! They’ve turned me into food for worms. I’m done for. Curse your families!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MERCUTIO and BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: MERCUTIO and BENVOLIO exit.$NEWLINE$MERCUTIO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$This gentleman, the Prince’s near ally,$NEWLINE$My very friend, hath got his mortal hurt$NEWLINE$In my behalf. My reputation stained$NEWLINE$With Tybalt’s slander.—Tybalt, that an hour$NEWLINE$Hath been my kinsman! O sweet Juliet,$NEWLINE$Thy beauty hath made me effeminate$NEWLINE$And in my temper softened valor’s steel!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$This gentleman Mercutio, a close relative of the Prince and my dear friend, was killed while defending me from Tybalt’s slander—Tybalt, who had been my cousin for a whole hour! Oh, sweet Juliet, your beauty has made me weak like a woman, and you have softened my bravery, which before was as hard as steel.

paragraphs.original: Enter BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO enters.$NEWLINE$BENVOLIO

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!$NEWLINE$That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds,$NEWLINE$Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Oh Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead! His brave spirit has floated up to heaven, but it was too early for him to leave life on earth.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$This day’s black fate on more days doth depend.$NEWLINE$This but begins the woe others must end.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$The future will be affected by today’s terrible events. Today is the start of a terror that will end in the days ahead.

paragraphs.original: Enter TYBALT$NEWLINE$TYBALT
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT enters.$NEWLINE$TYBALT

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Alive in triumph—and Mercutio slain!$NEWLINE$Away to heaven, respective lenity,$NEWLINE$And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now.$NEWLINE$Now, Tybalt, take the “villain” back again$NEWLINE$That late thou gavest me, for Mercutio’s soul$NEWLINE$Is but a little way above our heads,$NEWLINE$Staying for thine to keep him company.$NEWLINE$Either thou or I, or both, must go with him.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$He’s alive and victorious, and Mercutio’s dead? Enough with mercy and consideration. It’s time for rage to guide my actions. Now, Tybalt, you can call me “villain” the way you did before. Mercutio’s soul is floating right above our heads. He’s waiting for you to keep him company on the way up to heaven. Either you, or I, or both of us have to go with him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here$NEWLINE$Shalt with him hence.
paragraphs.translated: TYBALT$NEWLINE$Wretched boy, you hung out with him here, and you’re going to go to heaven with him.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$This shall determine that.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$This fight will decide who dies.

paragraphs.original: They fight. TYBALT falls$NEWLINE$TYBALT
paragraphs.translated: They fight. TYBALT falls and dies$NEWLINE$TYBALT

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Romeo, away, be gone!$NEWLINE$The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.$NEWLINE$Stand not amazed. The Prince will doom thee death$NEWLINE$If thou art taken. Hence, be gone, away!
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Romeo, get out of here. The citizens are around, and Tybalt is dead. Don’t stand there shocked. The Prince will give you the death penalty if you get caught. So get out of here!

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, I am fortune’s fool!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, I have awful luck.

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Why dost thou stay?
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Why are you waiting?

paragraphs.original: Exit ROMEO$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CITIZENS OF THE WATCH$NEWLINE$CITIZENS OF THE WATCH
paragraphs.translated: The CITIZENS OF THE WATCH enter.$NEWLINE$CITIZENS OF THE WATCH

paragraphs.original: CITIZEN OF THE WATCH$NEWLINE$Which way ran he that killed Mercutio?$NEWLINE$Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?
paragraphs.translated: CITIZEN OF THE WATCH$NEWLINE$The man who killed Mercutio, which way did he go? Tybalt, that murderer, which way did he run?

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$There lies that Tybalt.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Tybalt is lying over there.

paragraphs.original: CITIZEN OF THE WATCH$NEWLINE$(to TYBALT) Up, sir, go with me.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I charge thee in the Prince’s name, obey.
paragraphs.translated: CITIZEN OF THE WATCH$NEWLINE$(to TYBALT) Get up, sir, and come with me. I command you, by the authority of the Prince, to obey me.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE, MONTAGUE, CAPULET, LADY MONTAGUE, LADY CAPULET, and OTHERS$NEWLINE$PRINCE$NEWLINE$MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$OTHERS
paragraphs.translated: The PRINCE enters with MONTAGUE, CAPULET, LADY MONTAGUE, LADY CAPULET, and OTHERS.$NEWLINE$PRINCE$NEWLINE$MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$OTHERS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Where are the vile beginners of this fray?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Where are the evil men who started this fight?

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$O noble prince, I can discover all$NEWLINE$The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl.$NEWLINE$There lies the man, slain by young Romeo,$NEWLINE$That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Oh, noble prince, I can tell you everything about the unfortunate circumstances of this deadly fight. Over there Tybalt is lying dead. He killed your relative, brave Mercutio, and then young Romeo killed him.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Tybalt, my cousin! O my brother’s child!$NEWLINE$O Prince! O cousin! Husband! Oh, the blood is spilled$NEWLINE$Of my dear kinsman! Prince, as thou art true,$NEWLINE$For blood of ours shed blood of Montague.$NEWLINE$O cousin, cousin!
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Tybalt was my nephew! He was my brother’s son! Oh Prince, oh nephew, oh husband! Oh, my nephew is dead! Oh Prince, as you are a man of honor, take revenge for this murder by killing someone from the Montague family. Oh cousin, cousin!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Benvolio, who started this fight?

paragraphs.original: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Tybalt here slain, whom Romeo’s hand did slay.$NEWLINE$Romeo, that spoke him fair, bade him bethink$NEWLINE$How nice the quarrel was and urged withal$NEWLINE$Your high displeasure. All this uttered$NEWLINE$With gentle breath, calm look, knees humbly bowed,$NEWLINE$Could not take truce with the unruly spleen$NEWLINE$Of Tybalt deaf to peace, but that he tilts$NEWLINE$With piercing steel at bold Mercutio’s breast,$NEWLINE$Who, all as hot, turns deadly point to point,$NEWLINE$And, with a martial scorn, with one hand beats$NEWLINE$Cold death aside and with the other sends$NEWLINE$It back to Tybalt, whose dexterity,$NEWLINE$Retorts it. Romeo, he cries aloud,$NEWLINE$“Hold, friends! Friends, part!” and, swifter than his tongue,$NEWLINE$His agile arm beats down their fatal points,$NEWLINE$And ’twixt them rushes—underneath whose arm$NEWLINE$An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life$NEWLINE$Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled.
paragraphs.translated: BENVOLIO$NEWLINE$Tybalt started the fight before he was killed by Romeo. Romeo spoke to Tybalt politely and told him how silly this argument was. He mentioned that you would not approve of the fight. He said all of this gently and calmly, kneeling down out of respect. But he could not make peace with Tybalt, who was in an angry mood and wouldn’t listen to talk about peace. Tybalt and Mercutio began to fight each other fiercely, lunging at one another and dodging each other’s blows. Romeo cried out, “Stop, my friends. Break it up.” Then he jumped in between them and forced them to put their swords down. But Tybalt reached under Romeo’s arm and thrust his sword into brave Mercutio. Then Tybalt fled the scene.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But by and by comes back to Romeo,$NEWLINE$Who had but newly entertained revenge,$NEWLINE$And to ’t they go like lightning, for ere I$NEWLINE$Could draw to part them was stout Tybalt slain.$NEWLINE$And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.$NEWLINE$This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.
paragraphs.translated: But pretty soon he came back to meet Romeo, who was overcome with the desire for revenge. As quick as lightning, they started fighting. Before I could break up the fight, Tybalt was killed. Romeo ran away when Tybalt fell dead. I’m telling you the truth, I swear on my life.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$He is a kinsman to the Montague.$NEWLINE$Affection makes him false. He speaks not true.$NEWLINE$Some twenty of them fought in this black strife,$NEWLINE$And all those twenty could but kill one life.$NEWLINE$I beg for justice, which thou, Prince, must give.$NEWLINE$Romeo slew Tybalt. Romeo must not live.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Benvolio is part of the Montague family. His loyalties to the Montagues make him tell lies. He’s not telling the truth. There were twenty Montagues fighting in this awful riot, and together those twenty could only kill one man. I demand justice. You, Prince, are the man who can give me justice. Romeo killed Tybalt. Romeo must die.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Romeo slew him; he slew Mercutio.$NEWLINE$Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Romeo killed Tybalt. Tybalt killed Mercutio. Who should now pay the price for Mercutio’s life?

paragraphs.original: MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$Not Romeo, Prince, he was Mercutio’s friend.$NEWLINE$His fault concludes but what the law should end,$NEWLINE$The life of Tybalt.
paragraphs.translated: MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$Not Romeo, Prince. He was Mercutio’s friend. His crime did justice’s job by taking Tybalt’s life.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$And for that offence$NEWLINE$Immediately we do exile him hence.$NEWLINE$I have an interest in your hearts' proceeding.$NEWLINE$My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding.$NEWLINE$But I’ll amerce you with so strong a fine$NEWLINE$That you shall all repent the loss of mine.$NEWLINE$I will be deaf to pleading and excuses.$NEWLINE$Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses,$NEWLINE$Therefore use none. Let Romeo hence in haste,$NEWLINE$Else, when he’s found, that hour is his last.$NEWLINE$Bear hence this body and attend our will.$NEWLINE$Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$And for that crime, Romeo is hereby exiled from Verona. I’m involved in your rivalry. Mercutio was my relative, and he lies dead because of your bloody feud. I’ll punish you so harshly that you’ll regret causing me this loss. I won’t listen to your pleas or excuses. You can’t get out of trouble by praying or crying, so don’t bother. Tell Romeo to leave the city immediately, or else, if he is found, he will be killed. Take away this body, and do what I say. Showing mercy by pardoning killers only causes more murders.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter JULIET alone$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET enters alone.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Gallop apace, you fiery-footed steeds,$NEWLINE$Toward Phoebus' lodging. Such a wagoner$NEWLINE$As Phaeton would whip you to the west$NEWLINE$And bring in cloudy night immediately.$NEWLINE$Spread thy close curtain, love-performing night,$NEWLINE$That runaways' eyes may wink, and Romeo$NEWLINE$Leap to these arms, untalked of and unseen.$NEWLINE$Lovers can see to do their amorous rites$NEWLINE$By their own beauties, or, if love be blind,$NEWLINE$It best agrees with night. Come, civil night,$NEWLINE$Thou sober-suited matron, all in black,$NEWLINE$And learn me how to lose a winning match$NEWLINE$Played for a pair of stainless maidenhoods.$NEWLINE$Hood my unmanned blood bating in my cheeks,$NEWLINE$With thy black mantle, till strange love, grow bold,$NEWLINE$Think true love acted simple modesty.$NEWLINE$Come, night. Come, Romeo. Come, thou day in night,$NEWLINE$For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night$NEWLINE$Whiter than new snow upon a raven’s back.$NEWLINE$Come, gentle night, come, loving, black-browed night,$NEWLINE$Give me my Romeo. And when I shall die,$NEWLINE$Take him and cut him out in little stars,$NEWLINE$And he will make the face of heaven so fine$NEWLINE$That all the world will be in love with night$NEWLINE$And pay no worship to the garish sun.$NEWLINE$Oh, I have bought the mansion of a love,$NEWLINE$But not possessed it, and though I am sold,$NEWLINE$Not yet enjoyed. So tedious is this day$NEWLINE$As is the night before some festival$NEWLINE$To an impatient child that hath new robes$NEWLINE$And may not wear them.
paragraphs.translated: I wish the sun would hurry up and set and night would come immediately. When the night comes and everyone goes to sleep, Romeo will leap into my arms, and no one will know. Beauty makes it possible for lovers to see how to make love in the dark. Or else love is blind, and its best time is the night. I wish night would come, like a widow dressed in black, so I can learn how to submit to my husband and lose my virginity. Let the blood rushing to my cheeks be calmed. In the darkness, let me, a shy virgin, learn the strange act of sex so that it seems innocent, modest, and true. Come, night. Come, Romeo. You’re like a day that comes during the night. You’re whiter than snow on the black wings of a raven. Come, gentle night. Come, loving, dark night. Give me my Romeo. And when I die, turn him into stars and form a constellation in his image. His face will make the heavens so beautiful that the world will fall in love with the night and forget about the garish sun. Oh, I have bought love’s mansion, but I haven’t moved in yet.I belong to Romeo now, but he hasn’t taken possession of me yet. This day is so boring that I feel like a child on the night before a holiday, waiting to put on my fancy new clothes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter NURSE with cords$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE enters with the rope ladder in her pouch.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: Oh, here comes my Nurse,$NEWLINE$And she brings news, and every tongue that speaks$NEWLINE$But Romeo’s name speaks heavenly eloquence.—$NEWLINE$Now, Nurse, what news? What hast thou there? The cords$NEWLINE$That Romeo bid thee fetch?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, here comes my Nurse, and she brings news. Every voice that mentions Romeo’s name sounds beautiful. Now, Nurse, what’s the news? Is that the rope ladder Romeo told you to pick up?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Ay, ay, the cords.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Yes, yes, this is the rope ladder.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Ay me, what news? Why dost thou wring thy hands?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh my, what’s the news? Why do you look so upset?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Ah, welladay! He’s dead, he’s dead, he’s dead!$NEWLINE$We are undone, lady, we are undone!$NEWLINE$Alack the day! He’s gone, he’s killed, he’s dead!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, it’s a sad day! He’s dead. He’s dead. He’s dead! We’re ruined, lady, we’re ruined! What an awful day! He’s gone. He’s been killed. He’s dead!

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Can heaven be so envious?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Can God be so jealous and hateful?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Romeo can,$NEWLINE$Though heaven cannot. O Romeo, Romeo!$NEWLINE$Who ever would have thought it? Romeo!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Romeo is hateful, even though God isn’t. Oh, Romeo, Romeo, who ever would have thought it would be Romeo?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What devil art thou that dost torment me thus?$NEWLINE$This torture should be roared in dismal hell.$NEWLINE$Hath Romeo slain himself? Say thou but “ay,”$NEWLINE$And that bare vowel I shall poison more$NEWLINE$I$NEWLINE$Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice.$NEWLINE$I am not I if there be such an I,$NEWLINE$I,$NEWLINE$Or those eyes shut that makes thee answer “ay.”$NEWLINE$If he be slain, say “ay,” or if not, “no.”$NEWLINE$Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$What kind of devil are you to torture me like this? This is as bad as the tortures of hell. Has Romeo killed himself? Just say “Yes” and I will turn more poisonous than the snake with the evil eye. I will no longer be myself if you tell me Romeo killed himself. If he’s been killed, say “Yes.” If not, say “No.” These short words will determine my joy or my pain.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes—$NEWLINE$God save the mark!—here on his manly breast.$NEWLINE$A piteous corse, a bloody piteous corse.$NEWLINE$Pale, pale as ashes, all bedaubed in blood,$NEWLINE$All in gore blood. I swoonèd at the sight.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$I saw the wound. I saw it with my own eyes. God bless that wound, here on his manly chest. A pitiful corpse, a bloody, pitiful corpse.$NEWLINE$Pale as ashes and drenched in blood. All the dried blood was so gory. I fainted when I saw it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O, break, my hear, poor bankrupt, break at once!$NEWLINE$To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty.$NEWLINE$Vile earth, to earth resign. End motion here,$NEWLINE$And thou and Romeo press one heavy bier.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh, my heart is breaking. Oh, my bankrupt heart is breaking. I’ll send my eyes to prison, and they’ll never be free to look at anything again. I’ll give my vile body back to the earth. I’ll never move again. My body and Romeo’s will lie together in one sad coffin.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!$NEWLINE$O courteous Tybalt! Honest gentleman!$NEWLINE$That ever I should live to see thee dead.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, Tybalt, Tybalt, he was the best friend I had. Oh, polite Tybalt, he was an honorable gentleman. I wish I had not lived long enough to see him die.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What storm is this that blows so contrary?$NEWLINE$Is Romeo slaughtered, and is Tybalt dead?$NEWLINE$My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?$NEWLINE$Then, dreadful trumpet, sound the general doom!$NEWLINE$For who is living if those two are gone?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$What disaster is this? Has Romeo been killed, and is Tybalt dead too? Tybalt was my dearest cousin. Romeo was even dearer to me as my husband. Let the trumpets play the song of doom, because who can be alive if those two are gone?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banishèd.$NEWLINE$Romeo that killed him—he is banishèd.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banished. Romeo killed Tybalt, and his punishment was banishment.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$It did, it did. Alas the day, it did.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$It did, it did. Curse the day this happened, but it did.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O serpent heart hid with a flowering face!$NEWLINE$Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?$NEWLINE$Beautiful tyrant! Fiend angelical!$NEWLINE$Dove-feathered raven, wolvish-ravening lamb!$NEWLINE$Despisèd substance of divinest show,$NEWLINE$Just opposite to what thou justly seem’st.$NEWLINE$A damnèd saint, an honorable villain!$NEWLINE$O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell$NEWLINE$When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend$NEWLINE$In moral paradise of such sweet flesh?$NEWLINE$Was ever book containing such vile matter$NEWLINE$So fairly bound? Oh, that deceit should dwell$NEWLINE$In such a gorgeous palace!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh, he’s like a snake disguised as a flower. Did a dragon ever hide in such a beautiful cave? He’s a beautiful tyrant and a fiendish angel! He’s a raven with the feathers of the dove. He’s a lamb who hunts like a wolf! I hate him, yet he seemed the most wonderful man. He’s turned out to be the exact opposite of what he seemed. He’s a saint who should be damned. He’s a villain who seemed honorable. Oh nature, what were you doing in hell? Why did you put the soul of a criminal in the perfect body of a man? Was there ever such an evil book with such a beautiful cover? Oh, I can’t believe the deepest evil lurked inside something so beautiful!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$There’s no trust,$NEWLINE$No faith, no honesty in men. All perjured,$NEWLINE$All forsworn, all naught, all dissemblers.$NEWLINE$Ah, where’s my man?—Give me some aqua vitae.—$NEWLINE$These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old.$NEWLINE$Shame come to Romeo!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$There is no trust, no faith, no honesty in men. All of them lie. All of them cheat. They’re all wicked. Ah, where’s my servant?—Give me some brandy.—These griefs, these pains, these sorrows make me old. Shame on Romeo!

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Blistered be thy tongue$NEWLINE$For such a wish! He was not born to shame.$NEWLINE$Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit,$NEWLINE$For ’tis a throne where honor may be crowned.$NEWLINE$Sole monarch of the universal earth,$NEWLINE$Oh, what a beast was I to chide at him!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I hope sores cover your tongue for a wish like that! He was not born to be shameful. Shame does not belong with Romeo. He deserves only honor, complete honor. Oh, I was such a beast to be angry at him.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Are you going to say good things about the man who killed your cousin?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband?$NEWLINE$Ah, poor my lord, what tongue shall smooth thy name,$NEWLINE$When I, thy three hours' wife, have mangled it?$NEWLINE$But wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?$NEWLINE$That villain cousin would have killed my husband.$NEWLINE$Back, foolish tears, back to your native spring.$NEWLINE$Your tributary drops belong to woe,$NEWLINE$Which you, mistaking, offer up to joy.$NEWLINE$My husband lives, that Tybalt would have slain,$NEWLINE$And Tybalt’s dead, that would have slain my husband.$NEWLINE$All this is comfort. Wherefore weep I then?$NEWLINE$Some word there was, worser than Tybalt’s death,$NEWLINE$That murdered me. I would forget it fain,$NEWLINE$But oh, it presses to my memory,$NEWLINE$Like damnèd guilty deeds to sinners' minds.$NEWLINE$“Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banishèd.”
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Am I supposed to say bad things about my own husband? Ah, my poor husband, who will sing your praises when I, your wife of three hours, have been saying awful things about you? But why, you villain, did you kill my cousin? Probably because my cousin the villain would have killed my husband. I’m not going to cry any tears. I would cry with joy that Romeo is alive, but I should cry tears of grief because Tybalt is dead. My husband, whom Tybalt wanted to kill, is alive. Tybalt, who wanted to kill my husband, is dead. All this is comforting news. Why, then, should I cry? There is news worse than the news that Tybalt is dead, news that makes me want to die. I would be glad to forget about it, but it weighs on my memory like sins linger in guilty minds. “Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banished.”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That “banishèd,” that one word “banishèd”$NEWLINE$Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt’s death$NEWLINE$Was woe enough, if it had ended there.$NEWLINE$Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship$NEWLINE$And needly will be ranked with other griefs,$NEWLINE$Why followed not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,”$NEWLINE$“Thy father” or “thy mother,” nay, or both,$NEWLINE$Which modern lamentations might have moved?$NEWLINE$But with a rearward following Tybalt’s death,$NEWLINE$“Romeo is banishèd.” To speak that word,$NEWLINE$Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet,$NEWLINE$All slain, all dead. “Romeo is banishèd.”$NEWLINE$There is no end, no limit, measure, bound,$NEWLINE$In that word’s death. No words can that woe sound.$NEWLINE$Where is my father and my mother, Nurse?
paragraphs.translated: That banishment is worse than the murder of ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt’s death would be bad enough if that was all. Maybe pain likes to have company and can’t come without bringing more pain. It would have been better if, after she said, “Tybalt’s dead,” she told me my mother or my father, or both, were gone. That would have made me make the normal cries of sadness. But to say that Tybalt’s dead and then say, “Romeo has been banished.” To say that is like saying that my father, my mother, Tybalt, Romeo, and Juliet have all been killed, they’re all dead. “Romeo has been banished.” That news brings infinite death. No words can express the pain. Where are my father and my mother, Nurse?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Weeping and wailing over Tybalt’s corse.$NEWLINE$Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$They are crying and moaning over Tybalt’s corpse. Are you going to join them? I’ll bring you there.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Wash they his wounds with tears? Mine shall be spent$NEWLINE$When theirs are dry, for Romeo’s banishment.$NEWLINE$Take up those cords.—Poor ropes, you are beguiled,$NEWLINE$Both you and I, for Romeo is exiled.$NEWLINE$He made you for a highway to my bed,$NEWLINE$But I, a maid, die maiden-widowèd.$NEWLINE$Come, cords.—Come, Nurse. I’ll to my wedding bed.$NEWLINE$And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Are they washing out his wounds with their tears? I’ll cry my tears for Romeo’s banishment when their tears are dry. Pick up this rope ladder. This poor rope ladder, it’s useless now, just like me, because Romeo has been exiled. He made this rope ladder to be a highway to my bed, but I am a virgin, and I will die a virgin and a widow. Let’s go, rope ladder. Nurse, I’m going to lie in my wedding bed. And death, not Romeo, can take my virginity!

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Hie to your chamber. I’ll find Romeo$NEWLINE$To comfort you. I wot well where he is.$NEWLINE$Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night.$NEWLINE$I’ll to him. He is hid at Lawrence' cell.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Go to your bedroom. I’ll find Romeo to comfort you. I know where he is. Listen, your Romeo will be here tonight. I’ll go to him. He’s hiding out in Friar Lawrence’s cell.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$(gives the NURSE a ring)O, find him! Give this ring to my true knight,$NEWLINE$(gives the$NEWLINE$a ring)$NEWLINE$And bid him come to take his last farewell.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$(giving her a ring) Oh, find him! Give this ring to my true knight! And tell him to come here to say his last goodbye.$NEWLINE$(giving her a ring)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE enters.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Romeo, come forth. Come forth, thou fearful man.$NEWLINE$Affliction is enamoured of thy parts,$NEWLINE$And thou art wedded to calamity.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Romeo, come out. Come out, you frightened man. Trouble likes you, and you’re married to disaster.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROMEO$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO enters.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Father, what news? What is the Prince’s doom?$NEWLINE$What sorrow craves acquaintance at my hand$NEWLINE$That I yet know not?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Father, what’s the news? What punishment did the Prince announce? What suffering lies in store for me that I don’t know about yet?

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Too familiar$NEWLINE$Is my dear son with such sour company.$NEWLINE$I bring thee tidings of the Prince’s doom.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$You know too much about suffering. I have news for you about the Prince’s punishment.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$What less than doomsday is the Prince’s doom?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Is the Prince’s punishment any less awful than doomsday?

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$A gentler judgment vanished from his lips:$NEWLINE$Not body’s death, but body’s banishment.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$He made a gentler decision. You won’t die, but you’ll be banished from the city.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Ha, banishment! Be merciful, say “death,”$NEWLINE$For exile hath more terror in his look,$NEWLINE$Much more than death. Do not say “banishment.”
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Ha, banishment? Be merciful and say “death.” Exile is much worse than death. Don’t say “banishment.”

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Hence from Verona art thou banishèd.$NEWLINE$Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$From now on, you are banished from Verona. You should be able to endure this because the world is broad and wide.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$There is no world without Verona walls$NEWLINE$But purgatory, torture, hell itself.$NEWLINE$Hence “banishèd” is banished from the world,$NEWLINE$And world’s exile is death. Then “banishèd,”
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$There is no world for me outside the walls of Verona, except purgatory, torture, and hell itself. So to be banished from Verona is like being banished from the world, and being banished from the world is death.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Is death mistermed. Calling death “banishment,”$NEWLINE$Thou cutt’st my head off with a golden ax$NEWLINE$And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.
paragraphs.translated: Banishment is death by the wrong name. Calling death banishment is like cutting off my head with a golden ax and smiling while I’m being murdered.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$O deadly sin! O rude unthankfulness!$NEWLINE$Thy fault our law calls death, but the kind Prince,$NEWLINE$Taking thy part, hath rushed aside the law,$NEWLINE$And turned that black word “death” to “banishment.”$NEWLINE$This is dear mercy, and thou seest it not.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, deadly sin! Oh, rude and unthankful boy! You committed a crime that is punishable by death, but our kind Prince took sympathy on you and ignored the law when he substituted banishment for death. This is kind mercy, and you don’t realize it.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$'Tis torture and not mercy. Heaven is here,$NEWLINE$Where Juliet lives, and every cat and dog$NEWLINE$And little mouse, every unworthy thing,$NEWLINE$Live here in heaven and may look on her,$NEWLINE$But Romeo may not. More validity,$NEWLINE$More honorable state, more courtship lives$NEWLINE$In carrion flies than Romeo. They may seize$NEWLINE$On the white wonder of dear Juliet’s hand$NEWLINE$And steal immortal blessing from her lips,$NEWLINE$Who even in pure and vestal modesty,$NEWLINE$Still blush, as thinking their own kisses sin.$NEWLINE$But Romeo may not. He is banishèd.$NEWLINE$Flies may do this, but I from this must fly.$NEWLINE$They are free men, but I am banishèd.$NEWLINE$And sayst thou yet that exile is not death?$NEWLINE$Hadst thou no poison mixed, no sharp-ground knife,$NEWLINE$No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean,$NEWLINE$But “banishèd” to kill me?—“Banishèd”!$NEWLINE$O Friar, the damnèd use that word in hell.$NEWLINE$Howling attends it. How hast thou the heart,$NEWLINE$Being a divine, a ghostly confessor,$NEWLINE$A sin-absolver, and my friend professed,$NEWLINE$To mangle me with that word “banishèd”?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$It’s torture, not mercy. Heaven is here because Juliet lives here. Every cat and dog and little mouse, every unworthy animal that lives here can see her, but Romeo can’t. Flies are healthier and more honorable and better suited for romance than Romeo. They can take hold of Juliet’s wonderful white hand and they can kiss her sweet lips. Even while she remains a pure virgin, she blushes when her lips touch each other because she thinks it’s a sin. But Romeo can’t kiss her or hold her hand because he’s been banished. Flies can kiss her, but I must flee the city. Flies are like free men, but I have been banished. And yet you say that exile is not death? Did you have no poison, no sharp knife, no weapon you could use to kill me quickly, nothing so disgraceful, except banishment? Oh Friar, damned souls use the word banishment to describe hell. They howl about banishment. If you’re a member of a divine spiritual order of men who forgive sins, and you say you’re my friend, how do you have the heart to mangle me with the word banishment?

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Thou fond mad man, hear me a little speak.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$You foolish madman, listen to me for a moment.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, thou wilt speak again of banishment.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Oh, you’re just going to talk about banishment again.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I’ll give thee armor to keep off that word—$NEWLINE$Adversity’s sweet milk, philosophy—$NEWLINE$To comfort thee though thou art banishèd.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I’ll give you protection from that word. I’ll give you the antidote for trouble: philosophy. Philosophy will comfort you even though you’ve been banished.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Yet “banishèd”? Hang up philosophy!$NEWLINE$Unless philosophy can make a Juliet,$NEWLINE$Displant a town, reverse a prince’s doom,$NEWLINE$It helps not, it prevails not. Talk no more.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$You’re still talking about “banished?” Forget about philosophy! Unless philosophy can create a Juliet, or pick up a town and put it somewhere else, or reverse a prince’s punishment, it doesn’t do me any good. Don’t say anything else.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, so madmen like you are also deaf.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$How should madmen hear, if wise men can’t even see?

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Let me talk to you about your situation.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel.$NEWLINE$Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love,$NEWLINE$An hour but married, Tybalt murderèd,$NEWLINE$Doting like me, and like me banishèd,$NEWLINE$Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair$NEWLINE$And fall upon the ground, as I do now,$NEWLINE$Taking the measure of an unmade grave.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$You can’t talk about something that you don’t feel. If you were as young as I am, if you were in love with Juliet, if you had just married her an hour ago, if then you murdered Tybalt, if you were lovesick like me, and if you were banished, then you might talk about it. You might also tear your hair out of your head and collapse to the ground the way I do right now. (ROMEO falls on the ground) You might kneel down and measure the grave that hasn’t yet been dug.$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$falls on the ground)

paragraphs.original: Knocking from within
paragraphs.translated: Knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Arise. One knocks. Good Romeo, hide thyself.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Get up. Somebody’s knocking. Hide yourself, good Romeo.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Not I, unless the breath of heartsick groans,$NEWLINE$Mistlike, infold me from the search of eyes.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I won’t hide unless all the mist from my heartsick groans envelopes me like fog and conceals me from people’s searching eyes.

paragraphs.original: Knocking
paragraphs.translated: Knocking.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Hark, how they knock!—Who’s there?—Romeo, arise.$NEWLINE$Thou wilt be taken.—Stay awhile.—Stand up.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Listen, they’re still knocking!—(to the person at the door) Who’s there?—(to ROMEO) Romeo, get up. They’ll arrest you.—(to the person at the door) Hold on a moment.—(to ROMEO) Get up.$NEWLINE$(to the person at the door)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to the person at the door)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Knocking
paragraphs.translated: Knocking

paragraphs.original: Run to my study.—By and by!—God’s will,$NEWLINE$What simpleness is this!—I come, I come.
paragraphs.translated: Run and hide in my study.—Just a minute—For the love of God, why are you being so stupid? I’m coming. I’m coming.

paragraphs.original: Knocking
paragraphs.translated: Knocking.

paragraphs.original: Who knocks so hard? Whence come you? What’s your will?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you knocking so hard? Where do you come from? What do you want?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$(from within) Let me come in, and you shall know my errand.$NEWLINE$(from within)$NEWLINE$I come from Lady Juliet.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Let me come in, and I’ll tell you why I came. I come from Lady Juliet.$NEWLINE$from offstage

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$(opens the door) Welcome then.$NEWLINE$(opens the door)
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$(opening the door) Welcome, then.$NEWLINE$(opening the door)

paragraphs.original: Enter NURSE$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE enters.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$O holy Friar, O, tell me, holy Friar,$NEWLINE$Where is my lady’s lord? Where’s Romeo?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, holy Friar, Oh, tell me, holy Friar, where is my lady’s husband? Where’s Romeo?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$There on the ground, with his own tears made drunk.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$He’s there on the ground. He’s been getting drunk on his own tears.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, he is even in my mistress' case,$NEWLINE$Just in her case. O woeful sympathy,$NEWLINE$Piteous predicament! Even so lies she,$NEWLINE$Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.$NEWLINE$Stand up, stand up. Stand, an you be a man.$NEWLINE$For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.$NEWLINE$Why should you fall into so deep an O?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, he’s acting just like Juliet, just like her. Oh painful sympathy! What a pitiful problem! She’s lying on the ground just like him, blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering. Stand up. Stand up. Stand up if you’re really a man. For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand up. Why should you fall into so deep a moan?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Nurse!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Nurse!

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Ah sir, ah sir. Death’s the end of all.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Ah sir, ah sir. Well, death is the end for everybody.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Spakest thou of Juliet? How is it with her?$NEWLINE$Doth she not think me an old murderer,$NEWLINE$Now I have stained the childhood of our joy$NEWLINE$With blood removed but little from her own?$NEWLINE$Where is she? And how doth she? And what says$NEWLINE$My concealed lady to our canceled love?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Were you talking about Juliet? How is she? Does she think that I’m a practiced murderer because I tainted our newfound joy by killing one of her close relatives? Where is she? How is she doing? What does my hidden wife say about our ruined love?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, she says nothing, sir, but weeps and weeps,$NEWLINE$And now falls on her bed, and then starts up,$NEWLINE$And “Tybalt” calls, and then on Romeo cries,$NEWLINE$And then down falls again.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, she doesn’t say anything, sir. She just weeps and weeps. She falls on her bed and then starts to get up. Then she calls out Tybalt’s name and cries “Romeo,” and then she falls down again.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$As if that name,$NEWLINE$Shot from the deadly level of a gun,$NEWLINE$Did murder her, as that name’s cursed hand$NEWLINE$Murdered her kinsman.
