O, tell me, Friar, tell me,$NEWLINE$In what vile part of this anatomy$NEWLINE$Doth my name lodge? Tell me, that I may sack$NEWLINE$The hateful mansion. (draws his dagger)$NEWLINE$(draws his dagger)
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$She’s calling out my name as if I were a bullet murdering her, just like I murdered her relative. Tell me, Friar, in what part of my body is my name embedded? Tell me, so I can cut it out of myself. (he draws his dagger)$NEWLINE$(he draws his dagger)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Hold thy desperate hand.$NEWLINE$Art thou a man? Thy form cries out thou art.$NEWLINE$Thy tears are womanish. Thy wild acts denote$NEWLINE$The unreasonable fury of a beast.$NEWLINE$Unseemly woman in a seeming man,$NEWLINE$And ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!$NEWLINE$Thou hast amazed me. By my holy order,$NEWLINE$I thought thy disposition better tempered.$NEWLINE$Hast thou slain Tybalt? Wilt thou slay thyself,$NEWLINE$And slay thy lady that in thy life lives$NEWLINE$By doing damnèd hate upon thyself?$NEWLINE$Why rail’st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?$NEWLINE$Since birth and heaven and earth, all three do meet$NEWLINE$In thee at once, which thou at once wouldst lose?$NEWLINE$Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit,$NEWLINE$Which, like a usurer, abound’st in all$NEWLINE$And usest none in that true use indeed$NEWLINE$Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit.$NEWLINE$Thy noble shape is but a form of wax,$NEWLINE$Digressing from the valor of a man;$NEWLINE$Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury,$NEWLINE$Killing that love which thou hast vowed to cherish;$NEWLINE$Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love,$NEWLINE$Misshapen in the conduct of them both,$NEWLINE$Like powder in a skill-less soldier’s flask,$NEWLINE$Is set afire by thine own ignorance;$NEWLINE$And thou dismembered with thine own defence.$NEWLINE$What, rouse thee, man! Thy Juliet is alive,$NEWLINE$For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead—$NEWLINE$There art thou happy. Tybalt would kill thee,$NEWLINE$But thou slew’st Tybalt—there art thou happy.$NEWLINE$The law that threatened death becomes thy friend$NEWLINE$And turns it to exile—there art thou happy.$NEWLINE$A pack of blessings light upon thy back,$NEWLINE$Happiness courts thee in her best array,
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Hold on, and don’t act out of desperation. Are you a man? You look like a man, but your tears make you look like a woman. Your wild actions resemble the irrational fury of a beast. You’re a shameful woman who looks like a man or else an ugly creature who’s half-man, half-beast. You have amazed me. I swear by my holy order, I thought you were smarter and more rational than this. Have you killed Tybalt? Will you kill yourself? And would you also kill your wife, who shares your life, by committing the sin of killing yourself? Why do you complain about your birth, the heavens, and the earth? Life is the union of soul in body through the miracle of birth, but you would throw all that away. You bring shame to your body, your love, and your mind. You have so much natural talent, but like someone who hoards money, you use none of your talent for the right purpose—not your body, not your love, not your mind. Your body is just a wax figure, without the honor of a man. The love that you promised was a hollow lie. You’re killing the love that you vowed to cherish. Your mind, which aids both your body and your love, has mishandled both of them. You’re like a stupid soldier whose gunpowder explodes because he’s careless. The things you were supposed to use to defend yourself end up killing you. Get up, man! Your Juliet is alive. It was for her that you were almost killed earlier. Be happy that she’s alive. Tybalt wanted to kill you, but you killed Tybalt. Be happy that you’re alive. The law that threatened your life was softened into exile. Be happy about that. Your life is full of blessings. You have the best sorts of happiness to enjoy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench,$NEWLINE$Thou pout’st upon thy fortune and thy love.$NEWLINE$Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.$NEWLINE$Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed.$NEWLINE$Ascend her chamber, hence, and comfort her.$NEWLINE$But look thou stay not till the watch be set,$NEWLINE$For then thou canst not pass to Mantua,$NEWLINE$Where thou shalt live, till we can find a time$NEWLINE$To blaze your marriage, reconcile your friends,$NEWLINE$Beg pardon of the Prince, and call thee back$NEWLINE$With twenty hundred thousand times more joy$NEWLINE$Than thou went’st forth in lamentation.—$NEWLINE$Go before, Nurse. Commend me to thy lady,$NEWLINE$And bid her hasten all the house to bed,$NEWLINE$Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.$NEWLINE$Romeo is coming.
paragraphs.translated: But like a misbehaved, sullen girl, you’re whining about your bad luck and your love. Listen, listen, people who act like that die miserable. Go be with your love, as it was decided at your wedding. Climb up to her bedroom and comfort her. But get out of there before the night watchmen take their positions. Then you will escape to the city of Mantua, where you’ll live until we can make your marriage public and make peace between your families. We’ll ask the Prince to pardon you. Then we’ll welcome you back with twenty thousand times more joy than you’ll have when you leave this town crying. Go ahead, Nurse. Give my regards to your lady, and tell her to hurry everybody in the house to bed. I’m sure they’re all so sad that they’ll be ready to sleep. Romeo is coming.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$O Lord, I could have stayed here all the night$NEWLINE$To hear good counsel. Oh, what learning is!$NEWLINE$My lord, I’ll tell my lady you will come.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$O Lord, I could stay here all night listening to such good advice. Educated men are so impressive! (speaking to ROMEO) My lord, I’ll tell my lady you will come.$NEWLINE$(speaking to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Do so, and tell my sweet to be ready to scold me.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir.$NEWLINE$(gives ROMEO JULIET’s ring)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$’s ring)$NEWLINE$Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Here, sir, this is a ring she asked me to give you. Hurry up, it’s getting late. (she gives ROMEO JULIET’s ring)$NEWLINE$(she gives$NEWLINE$’s ring)

paragraphs.original: Exit NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE exits.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$How well my comfort is revived by this!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$This makes me feel so much better!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Go hence. Good night. And here stands all your state:$NEWLINE$Either be gone before the watch be set,$NEWLINE$Or by the break of day disguised from hence.$NEWLINE$Sojourn in Mantua. I’ll find out your man,$NEWLINE$And he shall signify from time to time$NEWLINE$Every good hap to you that chances here.$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand. 'Tis late. Farewell, good night.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Now get out of here. Good night. Everything depends on this: either be out of here before the night watchmen take their positions, or leave in disguise after daybreak. Take a little vacation in Mantua. I’ll find your servant, and he’ll update you now and then on your case as it stands here. Give me your hand. It’s late. Farewell. Good night.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$But that a joy past joy calls out on me,$NEWLINE$It were a grief so brief to part with thee.$NEWLINE$Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I’m off to experience the greatest joy of all, but still it’s sad to leave you in such a rush. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, and PARIS$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$PARIS
paragraphs.translated: Enter CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, and PARIS$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$PARIS

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily,$NEWLINE$That we have had no time to move our daughter.$NEWLINE$Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly,$NEWLINE$And so did I. Well, we were born to die.$NEWLINE$'Tis very late. She’ll not come down tonight.$NEWLINE$I promise you, but for your company,$NEWLINE$I would have been abed an hour ago.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Things have turned out so unluckily, sir, that we haven’t had time to convince our daughter to marry you. Listen, she loved her cousin Tybalt dearly, and so did I. Well, we were all born to die. It’s very late, she won’t be coming downstairs tonight. Believe me, if you weren’t here visiting me, I myself would have gone to bed an hour ago.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$These times of woe afford no time to woo.$NEWLINE$Madam, good night. Commend me to your daughter.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$These times of pain are bad times for romance. Madam, good night. Give my regards to your daughter.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$I will, and know her mind early tomorrow.$NEWLINE$Tonight she is mewed up to her heaviness.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$I will. And I’ll find out what she thinks about marriage early tomorrow. Tonight she is shut up in her room, alone with her sadness.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender$NEWLINE$Of my child’s love. I think she will be ruled$NEWLINE$In all respects by me. Nay, more, I doubt it not.—$NEWLINE$Wife, go you to her ere you go to bed.$NEWLINE$Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love,$NEWLINE$And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next—$NEWLINE$But, soft! What day is this?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Sir Paris, I’ll make a desperate argument for my child’s love. I think she’ll do whatever I say. No, I think she’ll do all that and more. I have no doubt about it. Wife, visit her in her room before you go to bed. Tell her about my son Paris’s love for her. And tell her, listen to me, on Wednesday—Wait—What day is today?

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Monday, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$Monday, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Monday! Ha, ha. Well, Wednesday is too soon,$NEWLINE$O' Thursday let it be.—O' Thursday, tell her,$NEWLINE$She shall be married to this noble earl.—$NEWLINE$Will you be ready? Do you like this haste?$NEWLINE$We’ll keep no great ado, a friend or two.$NEWLINE$For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late,$NEWLINE$It may be thought we held him carelessly,$NEWLINE$Being our kinsman, if we revel much.$NEWLINE$Therefore we’ll have some half a dozen friends,$NEWLINE$And there an end. But what say you to Thursday?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Monday! Ha, ha! Well, Wednesday is too soon. Let it be on Thursday. On Thursday, tell her, she’ll be married to this noble earl. Will you be ready? Do you think it’s a good idea to rush? We shouldn’t have too big a celebration—we can invite a friend or two. Listen, because Tybalt was just killed, people might think that we don’t care about his memory as our relative if we have too grand a party. Therefore we’ll have about half a dozen friends to the wedding, and that’s it. What do you think about Thursday?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$My lord, I would that Thursday were tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$My lord, I wish Thursday were tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well get you gone. O' Thursday be it, then.—$NEWLINE$Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed.$NEWLINE$Prepare her, wife, against this wedding day.—$NEWLINE$Farewell, my lord.—Light to my chamber, ho!$NEWLINE$Afore me! It is so very late,$NEWLINE$That we may call it early by and by.—$NEWLINE$Good night.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well go on home. Thursday it is, then. (to LADY CAPULET) Visit Juliet before you go to bed. Get her ready, my wife, for this wedding day. (to PARIS) Farewell, my lord. Now I’m off to bed. Oh my! It’s so late that we might as well call it early. Good night.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ROMEO and JULIET aloft$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO and JULIET enter above the stage.$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day.$NEWLINE$It was the nightingale, and not the lark,$NEWLINE$That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear.$NEWLINE$Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate tree.$NEWLINE$Believe me, love, it was the nightingale.
paragraphs.translated:
JULIET$NEWLINE$Are you going? It’s still a long time until daybreak. Don’t be afraid. That sound you heard was the
nightingale, not the lark. Every night the nightingale chirps on that pomegranate-tree. Believe me, my love, it was the nightingale.$NEWLINE$nightingale$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$It was the lark, the herald of the morn,$NEWLINE$No nightingale. Look, love, what envious streaks$NEWLINE$Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east.$NEWLINE$Night’s candles are burnt out, and jocund day$NEWLINE$Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.$NEWLINE$I must be gone and live, or stay and die.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$It was the lark, the bird that sings at dawn, not the nightingale. Look, my love, what are those streaks of light in the clouds parting in the east? Night is over, and day is coming. If I want to live, I must go. If I stay, I’ll die.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I.$NEWLINE$It is some meteor that the sun exhales$NEWLINE$To be to thee this night a torchbearer,$NEWLINE$And light thee on thy way to Mantua.$NEWLINE$Therefore stay yet. Thou need’st not to be gone.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$That light is not daylight, I know it. It’s some meteor coming out of the sun to light your way to Mantua. So stay for a while. You don’t have to go yet.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Let me be ta'en. Let me be put to death.$NEWLINE$I am content, so thou wilt have it so.$NEWLINE$I’ll say yon grey is not the morning’s eye.$NEWLINE$'Tis but the pale reflex of Cynthia’s brow.$NEWLINE$Nor that is not the lark, whose notes do beat$NEWLINE$The vaulty heaven so high above our heads.$NEWLINE$I have more care to stay than will to go.$NEWLINE$Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wills it so.—$NEWLINE$How is ’t, my soul? Let’s talk. It is not day.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Let me be captured. Let me be put to death. I am content, if that’s the way you want it. I’ll say the light over there isn’t morning. I’ll say it’s the reflection of the moon. I’ll say that sound isn’t the lark ringing in the sky. I want to stay more than I want to go. Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wants it this way. How are you, my love? Let’s talk. It’s not daylight.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$It is, it is. Hie hence! Be gone, away!$NEWLINE$It is the lark that sings so out of tune,$NEWLINE$Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.$NEWLINE$Some say the lark makes sweet division.$NEWLINE$This doth not so, for she divideth us.$NEWLINE$Some say the lark and loathèd toad change eyes.$NEWLINE$Oh, now I would they had changed voices too,$NEWLINE$Since arm from arm that voice doth us affray,$NEWLINE$Hunting thee hence with hunt’s-up to the day.$NEWLINE$O, now be gone. More light and light it grows.
paragraphs.translated:
JULIET$NEWLINE$It is, it is. Get out of here, be gone, go away! It’s the lark that sings so out of tune, making such harsh noise. Some say the lark makes a sweet division between day and night. It’s not true because she separates us.
Some say the lark traded its eyes with the toad. Oh, now I wish they had traded voices too! Because the lark’s voice tears us out of each other’s arms, and now there will be men hunting for you. Oh, go away now. I see more and more light.$NEWLINE$Some say the lark traded its eyes with the toad$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$More light and light, more dark and dark our woes!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$More and more light. More and more pain for us.

paragraphs.original: Enter NURSE$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE enters.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Madam.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Madam.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Nurse?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Nurse?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Your lady mother is coming to your chamber.$NEWLINE$The day is broke. Be wary, look about.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Your mother is coming to your bedroom. Day has broken. Be careful. Watch out.

paragraphs.original: Exit NURSE$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE exits.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Then, window, let day in and let life out.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Then the window lets day in, and life goes out the window.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Farewell, farewell. One kiss, and I’ll descend.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Farewell, farewell! Give me one kiss, and I’ll go down.

paragraphs.original: Kiss. ROMEO goes down$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: They kiss. ROMEO drops the ladder and goes down.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Art thou gone so, love, lord? Ay, husband, friend,$NEWLINE$I must hear from thee every day in the hour,$NEWLINE$For in a minute there are many days.$NEWLINE$Oh, by this count I shall be much in years$NEWLINE$Ere I again behold my Romeo.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Are you gone like that, my love, my lord? Yes, my husband, my friend! I must hear from you every day in the hour. In a minute there are many days. Oh, by this count I’ll be many years older before I see my Romeo again.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Farewell!$NEWLINE$I will omit no opportunity$NEWLINE$That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Farewell! I won’t miss any chance to send my love to you.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh, think’st thou we shall ever meet again?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh, do you think we’ll ever meet again?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I doubt it not, and all these woes shall serve$NEWLINE$For sweet discourses in our time to come.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I have no doubts. All these troubles will give us stories to tell each other later in life.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O God, I have an ill-divining soul.$NEWLINE$Methinks I see thee now, thou art so low$NEWLINE$As one dead in the bottom of a tomb.$NEWLINE$Either my eyesight fails, or thou look’st pale.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh God, I have a soul that predicts evil things! Now that you are down there, you look like someone dead in the bottom of a tomb. Either my eyesight is failing me, or you look pale.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$And trust me, love, in my eye so do you.$NEWLINE$Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu, adieu!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$And trust me, love, you look pale to me too. Sadness takes away our color. Goodbye, Goodbye!

paragraphs.original: Exit ROMEO$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO exits.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O fortune, fortune! All men call thee fickle.$NEWLINE$If thou art fickle, what dost thou with him$NEWLINE$That is renowned for faith? Be fickle, fortune,$NEWLINE$For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long,$NEWLINE$But send him back.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh luck, luck. Everyone says you can’t make up your mind. If you change your mind so much, what are you going to do to Romeo, who’s so faithful? Change your mind, luck. I hope maybe then you’ll send him back home soon.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$(from within) Ho, daughter, are you up?$NEWLINE$(from within)
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$(offstage) Hey, daughter! Are you awake?$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Who is ’t that calls? Is it my lady mother?$NEWLINE$Is she not down so late or up so early?$NEWLINE$What unaccustomed cause procures her hither?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Who’s that calling? Is it my mother? Isn’t she up very late? Or is she up very early? What strange reason could she have for coming here?

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET enters.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Why, how now, Juliet?
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$What’s going on, Juliet?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Madam, I am not well.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Madam, I am not well.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Evermore weeping for your cousin’s death?$NEWLINE$What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?$NEWLINE$An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live.$NEWLINE$Therefore, have done. Some grief shows much of love,$NEWLINE$But much of grief shows still some want of wit.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Will you cry about your cousin’s death forever? Are you trying to wash him out of his grave with tears? If you could, you couldn’t bring him back to life. So stop crying. A little bit of grief shows a lot of love. But too much grief makes you look stupid.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Let me keep weeping for such a great loss.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend$NEWLINE$Which you weep for.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$You will feel the loss, but the man you weep for will feel nothing.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Feeling so the loss,$NEWLINE$Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Feeling the loss like this, I can’t help but weep for him forever.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well, girl, thou weep’st not so much for his death,$NEWLINE$As that the villain lives which slaughtered him.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well, girl, you’re weeping not for his death as much as for the fact that the villain who killed him is still alive.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What villain, madam?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$What villain, madam?

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$That same villain, Romeo.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$That villain, Romeo.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$(aside) Villain and he be many miles asunder.$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$(to LADY CAPULET) God pardon him! I do, with all my heart,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And yet no man like he doth grieve my heart.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$(speaking so that LADY CAPULET can’t hear) He’s far from being a villain. (to LADY CAPULET) May God pardon him! I do, with all my heart. And yet no man could make my heart grieve like he does.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that$NEWLINE$can’t hear)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$That is because the traitor murderer lives.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$That’s because the murderer is alive.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands.$NEWLINE$Would none but I might venge my cousin’s death!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Yes, madam, he lies beyond my reach. I wish that no one could avenge my cousin’s death except me!

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$We will have vengeance for it, fear thou not.$NEWLINE$Then weep no more. I’ll send to one in Mantua,$NEWLINE$Where that same banished runagate doth live,$NEWLINE$Shall give him such an unaccustomed dram$NEWLINE$That he shall soon keep Tybalt company.$NEWLINE$And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$We’ll have revenge for it. Don’t worry about that. Stop crying. I’ll send a man to Mantua, where that exiled rogue is living. Our man will poison Romeo’s drink, and Romeo will join Tybalt in death. And then, I hope, you’ll be satisfied.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Indeed, I never shall be satisfied$NEWLINE$With Romeo, till I behold him—dead—$NEWLINE$Is my poor heart for a kinsman vexed.$NEWLINE$Madam, if you could find out but a man$NEWLINE$To bear a poison, I would temper it,$NEWLINE$That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof,$NEWLINE$Soon sleep in quiet. Oh, how my heart abhors$NEWLINE$To hear him named, and cannot come to him.$NEWLINE$To wreak the love I bore my cousin$NEWLINE$Upon his body that slaughtered him!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I’ll never be satisfied with Romeo until I see him . . . dead—dead is how my poor heart feels when I think about my poor cousin. Madam, if you can find a man to deliver the poison, I’ll mix it myself so that Romeo will sleep quietly soon after he drinks it. Oh, how I hate to hear people say his name and not be able to go after him. I want to take the love I had for my cousin and take it out on the body of the man who killed him.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Find thou the means, and I’ll find such a man.$NEWLINE$But now I’ll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Find out the way, and I’ll find the right man. But now I have joyful news for you, girl.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$And joy comes well in such a needy time.$NEWLINE$What are they, beseech your ladyship?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$And it’s good to have joy in such a joyless time. What’s the news? Please tell me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child.$NEWLINE$One who, to put thee from thy heaviness,$NEWLINE$Hath sorted out a sudden day of joy$NEWLINE$That thou expect’st not, nor I looked not for.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well, well, you have a careful father, child. He has arranged a sudden day of joy to end your sadness. A day that you did not expect and that I did not seek out.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Madam, in happy time, what day is that?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Madam, tell me quickly, what day is that?

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn,$NEWLINE$The gallant, young, and noble gentleman,$NEWLINE$The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church,$NEWLINE$Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Indeed, my child, at Saint Peter’s Church early Thursday morning, the gallant, young, and noble gentleman Count Paris will happily make you a joyful bride.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too,$NEWLINE$He shall not make me there a joyful bride.$NEWLINE$I wonder at this haste, that I must wed$NEWLINE$Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.$NEWLINE$I pray you, tell my lord and father, madam,$NEWLINE$I will not marry yet. And when I do, I swear$NEWLINE$It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate,$NEWLINE$Rather than Paris. These are news indeed!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Now, I swear by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, he will not make me a joyful bride there. This is a strange rush. How can I marry him, this husband, before he comes to court me? Please, tell my father, madam, I won’t marry yet. And, when I do marry, I swear, it will be Romeo, whom you know I hate, rather than Paris. That’s really news!

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Here comes your father. Tell him so yourself,$NEWLINE$And see how he will take it at your hands.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Here comes your father. Tell him so yourself, and see how he takes the news.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAPULET and NURSE$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET and the NURSE enter.$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$When the sun sets the air doth drizzle dew,$NEWLINE$But for the sunset of my brother’s son$NEWLINE$It rains downright.$NEWLINE$How now? A conduit, girl? What, still in tears,$NEWLINE$Evermore showering? In one little body$NEWLINE$Thou counterfeit’st a bark, a sea, a wind,$NEWLINE$For still thy eyes, which I may call the sea,$NEWLINE$Do ebb and flow with tears. The bark thy body is,$NEWLINE$Sailing in this salt flood. The winds thy sighs,$NEWLINE$Who, raging with thy tears, and they with them,$NEWLINE$Without a sudden calm will overset$NEWLINE$Thy tempest-tossèd body.—How now, wife?$NEWLINE$Have you delivered to her our decree?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$When the sun sets, the air drizzles dew. But at the death of my brother’s son, it rains a downpour. What are you, girl? Some kind of fountain? Why are you still crying? Will you cry forever? In one little body you seem like a ship, the sea, and the winds. Your eyes, which I call the sea, flow with tears. The ship is your body which is sailing on the salt flood of your tears. The winds are your sighs. Your sighs and your tears are raging. Unless you calm down, tears and sighs will overwhelm your body and sink your ship. So where do things stand, wife? Have you told her our decision?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, but she will none, she gives you thanks.$NEWLINE$I would the fool were married to her grave!
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, I told her. But she won’t agree. She says thank you but refuses. I wish the fool were dead and married to her grave!

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Soft, take me with you, take me with you, wife.$NEWLINE$How, will she none? Doth she not give us thanks?$NEWLINE$Is she not proud? Doth she not count her blessed,$NEWLINE$Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought$NEWLINE$So worthy a gentleman to be her bride?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Wait! Hold on, wife. I don’t understand. How can this be? She refuses? Isn’t she grateful? Isn’t she proud of such a match? Doesn’t she realize what a blessing this is? Doesn’t she realize how unworthy she is of the gentleman we have found to be her bridegroom?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Not proud you have, but thankful that you have.$NEWLINE$Proud can I never be of what I hate,$NEWLINE$But thankful even for hate that is meant love.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I am not proud of what you have found for me. But I am thankful that you have found it. I can never be proud of what I hate. But I can be thankful for something I hate, if it was meant with love.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$How, how, how, how? Chopped logic! What is this?$NEWLINE$“Proud,” and “I thank you,” and “I thank you not,”$NEWLINE$And yet “not proud”? Mistress minion you,$NEWLINE$Thank me no thankings, nor proud me no prouds,$NEWLINE$But fettle your fine joints 'gainst Thursday next$NEWLINE$To go with Paris to Saint Peter’s Church,$NEWLINE$Or I will drag thee on a hurdle thither.$NEWLINE$Out, you green sickness, carrion! Out, you baggage!$NEWLINE$You tallow face!
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$What is this? What is this fuzzy logic? What is this? I hear you say “proud” and “I thank you,” and then “no thank you” and “not proud,” you spoiled little girl. You’re not really giving me any thanks or showing me any pride. But get yourself ready for Thursday. You’re going to Saint Peter’s Church to marry Paris. And if you don’t go on your own, I’ll drag you there. You disgust me, you little bug! You worthless girl! You pale face!

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Fie, fie! What, are you mad?
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Shame on you! What, are you crazy?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Good Father, I beseech you on my knees,$NEWLINE$Hear me with patience but to speak a word.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Good father, I’m begging you on my knees, be patient and listen to me say just one thing.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Hang thee, young baggage! Disobedient wretch!$NEWLINE$I tell thee what: get thee to church o' Thursday,$NEWLINE$Or never after look me in the face.$NEWLINE$Speak not. Reply not. Do not answer me.$NEWLINE$My fingers itch.—Wife, we scarce thought us blest$NEWLINE$That God had lent us but this only child,$NEWLINE$But now I see this one is one too much$NEWLINE$And that we have a curse in having her.$NEWLINE$Out on her, hilding!
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Forget about you, you worthless girl! You disobedient wretch! I’ll tell you what. Go to church on Thursday or never look me in the face again. Don’t say anything. Don’t reply. Don’t talk back to me.$NEWLINE$(JULIET rises)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$rises)$NEWLINE$I feel like slapping you. Wife, we never thought ourselves blessed that God only gave us this one child. But now I see that this one is one too many. We were cursed when we had her. She disgusts me, the little hussy!

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$God in heaven bless her!$NEWLINE$You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$God in heaven bless her! My lord, you’re wrong to berate her like that.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$And why, my Lady Wisdom? Hold your tongue,$NEWLINE$Good prudence. Smatter with your gossips, go.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$And why, wise lady? You shut up, old woman. Go blabber with your gossiping friends.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$I speak no treason.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$I’ve said nothing wrong.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Oh, God 'i' good e'en.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Oh, for God’s sake.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$May not one speak?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Can’t I say something?

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Peace, you mumbling fool!$NEWLINE$Utter your gravity o'er a gossip’s bowl,$NEWLINE$For here we need it not.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Be quiet, you mumbling fool! Say your serious things at lunch with your gossiping friends. We don’t need to hear it.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$You are too hot.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$You’re getting too angry.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$God’s bread! It makes me mad.$NEWLINE$Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play,$NEWLINE$Alone, in company, still my care hath been$NEWLINE$To have her matched. And having now provided$NEWLINE$A gentleman of noble parentage,$NEWLINE$Of fair demesnes, youthful, and nobly trained,$NEWLINE$Stuffed, as they say, with honorable parts,$NEWLINE$Proportioned as one’s thought would wish a man—$NEWLINE$And then to have a wretched puling fool,$NEWLINE$A whining mammet, in her fortune’s tender,$NEWLINE$To answer “I’ll not wed,” “I cannot love,”$NEWLINE$“I am too young,” “I pray you, pardon me.”—$NEWLINE$But, an you will not wed, I’ll pardon you.$NEWLINE$Graze where you will, you shall not house with me.$NEWLINE$Look to ’t, think on ’t, I do not use to jest.$NEWLINE$Thursday is near. Lay hand on heart, advise.$NEWLINE$An you be mine, I’ll give you to my friend.$NEWLINE$An you be not, hang, beg, starve, die in the streets,$NEWLINE$For, by my soul, I’ll ne'er acknowledge thee,$NEWLINE$Nor what is mine shall never do thee good.$NEWLINE$Trust to ’t, bethink you. I’ll not be forsworn.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Goddammit! It makes me mad. Day and night, hour after hour, all the time, at work, at play, alone, in company, my top priority has always been to find her a husband. Now I’ve provided a husband from a noble family, who is good-looking, young, well-educated. He’s full of good qualities.$NEWLINE$He’s the man of any girl’s dreams. But this wretched, whimpering fool, like a whining puppet, she looks at this good fortune and answers, “I won’t get married. I can’t fall in love. I’m too young. Please, excuse me.” Well, if you won’t get married, I’ll excuse you. Eat wherever you want, but you can no longer live under my roof. Consider that. Think about it. I’m not in the habit of joking. Thursday is coming. Put your hand on your heart and listen to my advice. If you act like my daughter, I’ll marry you to my friend. If you don’t act like my daughter, you can beg, starve, and die in the streets. I swear on my soul, I will never take you back or do anything for you. Believe me. Think about it. I won’t break this promise.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit CAPULET$NEWLINE$CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET exits.$NEWLINE$CAPULET

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Is there no pity sitting in the clouds$NEWLINE$That sees into the bottom of my grief?—$NEWLINE$O sweet my mother, cast me not away!$NEWLINE$Delay this marriage for a month, a week.$NEWLINE$Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed$NEWLINE$In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Is there no pity in the sky that can see my sadness? Oh, my sweet mother, don’t throw me out! Delay this marriage for a month, or a week. Or, if you don’t delay, make my wedding bed in the tomb where Tybalt lies.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Talk not to me, for I’ll not speak a word.$NEWLINE$Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Don’t talk to me, because I won’t say a word. Do as you please, because I’m done worrying about you.

paragraphs.original: Exit LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET exits.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O God!—O Nurse, how shall this be prevented?$NEWLINE$My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven.$NEWLINE$How shall that faith return again to earth,$NEWLINE$Unless that husband send it me from heaven$NEWLINE$By leaving earth? Comfort me. Counsel me.—$NEWLINE$Alack, alack, that heaven should practice stratagems$NEWLINE$Upon so soft a subject as myself.—$NEWLINE$What sayst thou? Hast thou not a word of joy?$NEWLINE$Some comfort, Nurse.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh God!—Oh Nurse, how can this be stopped? My husband is alive on earth, my vows of marriage are in heaven. How can I bring those promises back down to earth, unless my husband sends them back down to me by dying and going to heaven? Give me comfort. Give me advice. Oh no! Oh no! Why does heaven play tricks on someone as weak as me? What do you say? Don’t you have one word of joy? Give me some comfort, Nurse.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Faith, here it is.$NEWLINE$Romeo is banishèd, and all the world to nothing$NEWLINE$That he dares ne'er come back to challenge you.$NEWLINE$Or, if he do, it needs must be by stealth.$NEWLINE$Then, since the case so stands as now it doth,$NEWLINE$I think it best you married with the county.$NEWLINE$Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.$NEWLINE$Romeo’s a dishclout to him. An eagle, madam,$NEWLINE$Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye$NEWLINE$As Paris hath. Beshrew my very heart,$NEWLINE$I think you are happy in this second match,$NEWLINE$For it excels your first. Or if it did not,$NEWLINE$Your first is dead, or ’twere as good he were,$NEWLINE$As living here and you no use of him.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$This is what I have to say: Romeo has been banished. And it’s a sure thing that he will never come back to challenge you. If he does come back, he’ll have to sneak back undercover. Then, since things are the way they are, I think the best thing to do is to marry the count. Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman! Romeo’s a dishcloth compared to him. Madam, an eagle does not have eyes as green, as quick, and as fair as the eyes of Paris. Curse my very heart, but I think you should be happy in this second marriage, because it’s better than your first. Even if it’s not better, your first marriage is over. Or if Romeo is as good as Paris, Romeo doesn’t live here, so you don’t get to enjoy him.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Speakest thou from thy heart?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Are you speaking from your heart?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$And from my soul too, else beshrew them both.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$I speak from my heart and from my soul too. If not, curse them both.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Amen!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Amen!

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$What?
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$What?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Well, thou hast comforted me marvelous much.$NEWLINE$Go in, and tell my lady I am gone,$NEWLINE$Having displeased my father, to Lawrence’s cell$NEWLINE$To make confession and to be absolved.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Well, you have given me great comfort. Go inside and tell my mother that I’m gone. I made my father angry, so I went to Friar Lawrence’s cell to confess and be forgiven.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Marry, I will, and this is wisely done.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Alright, I will. This is a good idea.

paragraphs.original: Exit NURSE$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE exits.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Ancient damnation! O most wicked fiend!$NEWLINE$Is it more sin to wish me thus forsworn,$NEWLINE$Or to dispraise my lord with that same tongue$NEWLINE$Which she hath praised him with above compare$NEWLINE$So many thousand times? Go, counselor.$NEWLINE$Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain.$NEWLINE$I’ll to the friar to know his remedy.$NEWLINE$If all else fail, myself have power to die.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$That damned old lady! Oh, that most wicked fiend! Is it a worse sin for her to want me to break my vows or for her to say bad things about my husband after she praised him so many times before? Away with you and your advice, Nurse. From now on, I will never tell you what I feel in my heart. I’m going to the Friar to find out his solution. If everything else fails, at least I have the power to take my own life.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: JULIET exits.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FRIAR LAWRENCE and PARIS$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$PARIS
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE and PARISenter.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$PARIS

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$On Thursday, sir? The time is very short.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$On Thursday, sir? That’s very soon.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$My father Capulet will have it so,$NEWLINE$And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$That’s how my future father-in-law Capulet wants it, and I’m not dragging my feet.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$You say you do not know the lady’s mind.$NEWLINE$Uneven is the course. I like it not.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$You say you don’t know what the girl thinks. That’s a rocky road to be riding. I don’t like it.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Immoderately she weeps for Tybalt’s death,$NEWLINE$And therefore have I little talked of love,$NEWLINE$For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.$NEWLINE$Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous$NEWLINE$That she do give her sorrow so much sway,$NEWLINE$And in his wisdom hastes our marriage$NEWLINE$To stop the inundation of her tears—$NEWLINE$Which, too much minded by herself alone,$NEWLINE$May be put from her by society.$NEWLINE$Now do you know the reason of this haste.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$She’s grieving too much over the death of Tybalt. So I haven’t had the chance to talk to her about love. Romantic love doesn’t happen when people are in mourning. Now, sir, her father thinks it’s dangerous that she allows herself to become so sad. He’s being smart by rushing our marriage to stop her from crying. She cries too much by herself. If she had someone to be with her, she would stop crying. Now you know the reason for the rush.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$(aside) I would I knew not why it should be slowed.—$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Look, sir, here comes the lady toward my cell.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$(to himself) I wish I didn’t know the reason why the marriage should be slowed down.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$Look, sir, here comes the lady walking toward my cell.

paragraphs.original: Enter JULIET$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET enters.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Happily met, my lady and my wife.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$I’m happy to meet you, my lady and my wife.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$That might be the case sir, after I’m married.$NEWLINE$after

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$That “may be” must be, love, on Thursday next.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$That “may be” must be, love, on Thursday.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$What must be shall be.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$What must be will be.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$That’s a certain text.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$That is a certain truth.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Come you to make confession to this Father?
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$Have you come to make confession to this father?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$To answer that, I should confess to you.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$If I answered that question, I’d be making confession to you.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Do not deny to him that you love me.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$Don’t deny to him that you love me.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I will confess to you that I love him.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I’ll confess to you that I love him.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$You will also confess, I’m sure, that you love me.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$If I do so, it will be of more price$NEWLINE$Being spoke behind your back than to your face.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$If I do so, it will mean more if I say it behind your back than if I say it to your face.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$You poor soul, your face has suffered many tears.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$The tears have got small victory by that,$NEWLINE$For it was bad enough before their spite.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$The tears haven’t done much because my face looked bad enough before I started to cry.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Thou wrong’st it more than tears with that report.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$You’re treating your face even worse by saying that.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$That is no slander, sir, which is a truth,$NEWLINE$And what I spake, I spake it to my face.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$What I say isn’t slander, sir. It’s the truth. And what I said, I said to my face.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Thy face is mine, and thou hast slandered it.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$Your face is mine, and you have slandered it.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$It may be so, for it is not mine own.—$NEWLINE$Are you at leisure, holy Father, now,$NEWLINE$Or shall I come to you at evening mass?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$That may be the case, because my face doesn’t belong to me.—Do you have time for me now, Father, or should I come to you at evening mass?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.—$NEWLINE$My lord, we must entreat the time alone.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I have time for you now, my sad daughter. (to PARIS) My lord, we must ask you to leave us alone.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$God shield I should disturb devotion!—$NEWLINE$Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye.$NEWLINE$(kisses her) Till then, adieu, and keep this holy kiss.$NEWLINE$(kisses her)
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$God forbid that I should prevent sacred devotion! Juliet, I will wake you early on Thursday. (kissing her) Until then, good-bye, and keep this holy kiss.$NEWLINE$. (kissing her)

paragraphs.original: Exit PARIS$NEWLINE$PARIS
paragraphs.translated: PARIS exits.$NEWLINE$PARIS

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O, shut the door! And when thou hast done so,$NEWLINE$Come weep with me, past hope, past cure, past help.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh, shut the door, and after you shut it, come over here and weep with me. This mess is beyond hope, beyond cure, beyond help!

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$O Juliet, I already know thy grief.$NEWLINE$It strains me past the compass of my wits.$NEWLINE$I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it,$NEWLINE$On Thursday next be married to this county.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, Juliet, I already know about your sad situation. It’s a problem too hard for me to solve. I hear that you must marry this count on Thursday, and that nothing can delay it.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Tell me not, Friar, that thou hear’st of this,$NEWLINE$Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it.$NEWLINE$If in thy wisdom thou canst give no help,$NEWLINE$Do thou but call my resolution wise,$NEWLINE$And with this knife I’ll help it presently.$NEWLINE$(shows him a knife)$NEWLINE$(shows him a knife)$NEWLINE$God joined my heart and Romeo’s, thou our hands.$NEWLINE$And ere this hand, by thee to Romeo sealed,$NEWLINE$Shall be the label to another deed,$NEWLINE$Or my true heart with treacherous revolt$NEWLINE$Turn to another, this shall slay them both.$NEWLINE$Therefore out of thy long-experienced time,$NEWLINE$Give me some present counsel, or, behold,$NEWLINE$'Twixt my extremes and me this bloody knife$NEWLINE$Shall play the umpire, arbitrating that$NEWLINE$Which the commission of thy years and art$NEWLINE$Could to no issue of true honor bring.$NEWLINE$Be not so long to speak. I long to die$NEWLINE$If what thou speak’st speak not of remedy.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Don’t tell me that you’ve heard about this marriage, Friar, unless you can tell me how to prevent it. If you who are so wise can’t help, please be kind enough to call my solution wise. (she shows him a knife) And I’ll solve the problem now with this knife. God joined my heart to Romeo’s. You joined our hands. And before I—who was married to Romeo by you—am married to another man, I’ll kill myself. You are wise and you have so much experience. Give me some advice about the current situation. Or watch. Caught between these two difficulties, I’ll act like a judge with my bloody knife. I will truly and honorably resolve the situation that you can’t fix, despite your experience and education. Don’t wait long to speak. I want to die if what you say isn’t another solution.$NEWLINE$(she shows him a knife)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Hold, daughter. I do spy a kind of hope,$NEWLINE$Which craves as desperate an execution$NEWLINE$As that is desperate which we would prevent.$NEWLINE$If, rather than to marry County Paris,$NEWLINE$Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself,$NEWLINE$Then is it likely thou wilt undertake$NEWLINE$A thing like death to chide away this shame,$NEWLINE$That copest with death himself to ’scape from it.$NEWLINE$An if thou darest, I’ll give thee remedy.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Hold on, daughter, I see some hope. But we must act boldly because the situation is so desperate. If you’ve made up your mind to kill yourself instead of marrying Count Paris, then you’ll probably be willing to try something like death to solve this shameful problem. You can wrestle with death to escape from shame. And if you dare to do it, I’ll give you the solution.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris,$NEWLINE$From off the battlements of yonder tower;$NEWLINE$Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk$NEWLINE$Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;$NEWLINE$Or shut me nightly in a charnel house,$NEWLINE$O'ercovered quite with dead men’s rattling bones,$NEWLINE$With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls;$NEWLINE$Or bid me go into a new-made grave$NEWLINE$And hide me with a dead man in his shroud—$NEWLINE$Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble—$NEWLINE$And I will do it without fear or doubt,$NEWLINE$To live an unstained wife to my sweet love.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh, you can tell me to jump off the battle posts of any tower, or to walk down the crime-ridden streets of a slum. Or tell me to sit in a field full of poisonous snakes. Chain me up with wild bears. Hide me every night in a morgue full of dead bodies with wet, smelly flesh and skulls without jawbones. Or tell me to climb down into a freshly dug grave, and hide me with a dead man in his tomb. All those ideas make me tremble when I hear them named. But I will do them without fear or dread in order to be a pure wife to my sweet love.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Hold, then. Go home, be merry. Give consent$NEWLINE$To marry Paris. Wednesday is tomorrow.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow night look that thou lie alone.$NEWLINE$Let not the Nurse lie with thee in thy chamber.$NEWLINE$(shows her a vial)$NEWLINE$(shows her a vial)$NEWLINE$Take thou this vial, being then in bed,$NEWLINE$And this distillèd liquor drink thou off,$NEWLINE$When presently through all thy veins shall run$NEWLINE$A cold and drowsy humor, for no pulse$NEWLINE$Shall keep his native progress, but surcease.$NEWLINE$No warmth, no breath shall testify thou livest.$NEWLINE$The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade$NEWLINE$To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall$NEWLINE$Like death when he shuts up the day of life.$NEWLINE$Each part, deprived of supple government,$NEWLINE$Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death.$NEWLINE$And in this borrowed likeness of shrunk death$NEWLINE$Thou shalt continue two and forty hours,$NEWLINE$And then awake as from a pleasant sleep.$NEWLINE$Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes$NEWLINE$To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead.$NEWLINE$Then, as the manner of our country is,$NEWLINE$In thy best robes uncovered on the bier$NEWLINE$Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault$NEWLINE$Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.$NEWLINE$In the meantime, against thou shalt awake,$NEWLINE$Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift,$NEWLINE$And hither shall he come, and he and I$NEWLINE$Will watch thy waking, and that very night$NEWLINE$Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.$NEWLINE$And this shall free thee from this present shame,$NEWLINE$If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear,$NEWLINE$Abate thy valor in the acting it.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Hold on, then. Go home, be cheerful, and tell them you agree to marry Paris. Tomorrow is Wednesday. Tomorrow night make sure that you are alone. Don’t let the Nurse stay with you in your bedroom. (showing her a vial) When you’re in bed, take this vial, mix its contents with liquor, and drink. Then a cold, sleep-inducing drug will run through your veins, and your pulse will stop. Your flesh will be cold, and you’ll stop breathing. The red in your lips and your cheeks will turn pale, and your eyes will shut. It will seem like you’re dead. You won’t be able to move, and your body will be stiff like a corpse. You’ll remain in this deathlike state for forty-two hours, and then you’ll wake up as if from a pleasant sleep. Now, when the bridegroom comes to get you out of bed on Thursday morning, you’ll seem dead. Then, as tradition demands, you’ll be dressed up in your best clothes, put in an open coffin, and carried to the Capulet family tomb. Meanwhile, I’ll send Romeo word of our plan. He’ll come here, and we’ll keep a watch for when you wake up. That night, Romeo will take you away to Mantua. This plan will free you from the shameful situation that troubles you now as long as you don’t change your mind, or become scared like a silly woman and ruin your brave effort.$NEWLINE$(showing her a vial)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Give me, give me! O, tell not me of fear!
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Give me the vial. Give it to me! Don’t talk to me about fear.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$(gives her a vial)$NEWLINE$(gives her a vial)$NEWLINE$Hold. Get you gone. Be strong and prosperous$NEWLINE$In this resolve. I’ll send a friar with speed$NEWLINE$To Mantua with my letters to thy lord.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$(giving her the vial) Now go along on your way. Be strong and successful in this decision. I’ll send a friar quickly to Mantua with my letter for Romeo.$NEWLINE$(giving her the vial)

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Love give me strength, and strength shall help afford.$NEWLINE$Farewell, dear Father.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Love will give me strength, and strength will help me accomplish this plan. Goodbye, dear Father.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, separately
paragraphs.translated: They exit separately.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, NURSE, and two or three SERVINGMEN$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE$NEWLINE$SERVINGMEN
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET enters with LADY CAPULET, the NURSE, and two or three SERVINGMEN.$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE$NEWLINE$SERVINGMEN

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$(gives paper to FIRST SERVINGMAN) So many guests invite as here are writ.$NEWLINE$(gives paper to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$(giving the FIRST SERVINGMAN a piece of paper) Invite all the guests on this list.$NEWLINE$(giving the$NEWLINE$a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$FIRST SERVINGMAN
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST SERVINGMAN exits.$NEWLINE$FIRST SERVINGMAN

paragraphs.original: (to SECOND SERVINGMAN) Sirrah, go hire me twenty cunning cooks.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: (to SECOND SERVINGMAN) Boy, go hire twenty skilled cooks.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SECOND SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$You shall have none ill, sir, for I’ll try if they can lick their fingers.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$You won’t get any bad cooks from me. I’ll test them by making them lick their fingers.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$How canst thou try them so?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$How can you test them like that?

paragraphs.original: SECOND SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, ’tis an ill cook that cannot lick his own fingers. Therefore he that cannot lick his fingers goes not with me.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$Easy, sir. It’s a bad cook who can’t lick his own fingers. So the cooks who can’t lick their fingers aren’t hired.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Go, be gone.$NEWLINE$We shall be much unfurnished for this time.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Go, get out of here.

paragraphs.original: Exit SECOND SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$SECOND SERVINGMAN
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND SERVINGMAN exits.$NEWLINE$SECOND SERVINGMAN

paragraphs.original: What, is my daughter gone to Friar Lawrence?
paragraphs.translated: We’re unprepared for this wedding celebration. (to the NURSE) What, has my daughter gone to see Friar Lawrence?$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Ay, forsooth.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s true.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well, he may chance to do some good on her.$NEWLINE$A peevish self-willed harlotry it is.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well, there’s a chance he may do her some good. She’s a stubborn little brat.

paragraphs.original: Enter JULIET$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET enters.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Look, she’s come home from confession with a happy look on her face.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$How now, my headstrong? Where have you been gadding?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$So, my headstrong daughter, where have you been?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Where I have learned me to repent the sin$NEWLINE$Of disobedient opposition$NEWLINE$To you and your behests, and am enjoined$NEWLINE$By holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here$NEWLINE$To beg your pardon. (falls to her knees)$NEWLINE$(falls to her knees)$NEWLINE$Pardon, I beseech you!$NEWLINE$Henceforward I am ever ruled by you.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I went somewhere where I learned that being disobedient to my father is a sin. Holy Father Lawrence instructed me to fall on my knees and beg your forgiveness. (she kneels down) Forgive me, I beg you. From now on I’ll do whatever you say.$NEWLINE$(she kneels down)

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Send for the county. Go tell him of this.$NEWLINE$I’ll have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Send for the Count. Go tell him about this. I’ll make this wedding happen tomorrow morning.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$I met the youthful lord at Lawrence' cell,$NEWLINE$And gave him what becomèd love I might,$NEWLINE$Not stepping o'er the bounds of modesty.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$I met the young man at Lawrence’s cell. I treated him with the proper love, as well as I could, while still being modest.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Why, I am glad on ’t. This is well. Stand up.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Well, I’m glad about this. This is good. Stand up.

paragraphs.original: JULIET stands up$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET stands up.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: This is as ’t should be.—Let me see the county.$NEWLINE$Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither.—$NEWLINE$Now, afore God, this reverend holy friar!$NEWLINE$Our whole city is much bound to him.
paragraphs.translated: This is the way is should be. I want to see the count. Yes, alright, go, I say, and bring him here. Now, before God, our whole city owes this friar a great debt.

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Nurse, will you go with me into my closet$NEWLINE$To help me sort such needful ornaments$NEWLINE$As you think fit to furnish me tomorrow?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Nurse, will you come with me to my closet and help me pick out the clothes and the jewelry I’ll need to wear tomorrow?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$No, not till Thursday. There is time enough.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$No, not until Thursday. There’s plenty of time.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Go, Nurse. Go with her. We’ll to church tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Go, Nurse, go with her. We’ll have the wedding at the church tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt JULIET and NURSE$NEWLINE$JULIET$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: JULIET and the NURSE exit.$NEWLINE$JULIET$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$We shall be short in our provision.$NEWLINE$'Tis now near night.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Our supplies will be short for the party. It’s already almost night.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Tush, I will stir about,$NEWLINE$And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife.$NEWLINE$Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her.$NEWLINE$I’ll not to bed tonight. Let me alone.$NEWLINE$I’ll play the housewife for this once.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Don’t worry, I will set things in motion. And everything will be alright, I promise you, wife. You should go to Juliet and dress her up. I’m not going to bed tonight. Leave me alone. I’ll pretend to be the housewife for once.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET exits.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET exits.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET

paragraphs.original: —What, ho?$NEWLINE$They are all forth?—Well, I will walk myself$NEWLINE$To County Paris, to prepare him up$NEWLINE$Against tomorrow. My heart is wondrous light$NEWLINE$Since this same wayward girl is so reclaimed.
paragraphs.translated: Hey! What? They’re all gone? Well, I will walk by myself to Count Paris to get him ready for tomorrow. My heart is wonderfully happy because this troubled girl has been taken back and now will be married.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET exits.$NEWLINE$CAPULET

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter JULIET and NURSE$NEWLINE$JULIET$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: JULIET and the NURSE enter.$NEWLINE$JULIET$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Ay, those attires are best. But, gentle Nurse,$NEWLINE$I pray thee, leave me to myself tonight,$NEWLINE$For I have need of many orisons$NEWLINE$To move the heavens to smile upon my state,$NEWLINE$Which, well thou know’st, is cross and full of sin.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Yes, those are the best clothes. But, gentle Nurse, please leave me alone tonight. I have to say a lot of prayers to make the heavens bless me. You know that my life is troubled and full of sin.

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET enters.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$What, are you busy, ho? Need you my help?
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$What, are you busy? Do you need my help?

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$No, madam. We have culled such necessaries$NEWLINE$As are behooveful for our state tomorrow.$NEWLINE$So please you, let me now be left alone,$NEWLINE$And let the Nurse this night sit up with you.$NEWLINE$For, I am sure, you have your hands full all$NEWLINE$In this so sudden business.
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$No, madam, we’ve figured out the best things for me to wear tomorrow at the ceremony. So if it’s okay with you, I’d like to be left alone now. Let the Nurse sit up with you tonight. I’m sure you have your hands full preparing for the sudden festivities.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Good night.$NEWLINE$Get thee to bed and rest, for thou hast need.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Good night. Go to bed and get some rest. I’m sure you need it.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LADY CAPULET and NURSE$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET and the NURSE exit.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Farewell!—God knows when we shall meet again.$NEWLINE$I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins$NEWLINE$That almost freezes up the heat of life.$NEWLINE$I’ll call them back again to comfort me.—$NEWLINE$Nurse!—What should she do here?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Good-bye. Only God knows when we’ll meet again. There is a slight cold fear cutting through my veins. It almost freezes the heat of life. I’ll call them back here to comfort me. Nurse!—Oh, what good would she do here?$NEWLINE$In my desperate situation, I have to act alone.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: My dismal scene I needs must act alone.$NEWLINE$Come, vial. (holds out the vial)$NEWLINE$(holds out the vial)$NEWLINE$What if this mixture do not work at all?$NEWLINE$Shall I be married then tomorrow morning?$NEWLINE$No, no. This shall forbid it. Lie thou there.$NEWLINE$(lays her knife down)$NEWLINE$(lays her knife down)$NEWLINE$What if it be a poison, which the friar$NEWLINE$Subtly hath ministered to have me dead,$NEWLINE$Lest in this marriage he should be dishonored$NEWLINE$Because he married me before to Romeo?$NEWLINE$I fear it is. And yet, methinks, it should not,$NEWLINE$For he hath still been tried a holy man.$NEWLINE$How if, when I am laid into the tomb,$NEWLINE$I wake before the time that Romeo$NEWLINE$Come to redeem me? There’s a fearful point.$NEWLINE$Shall I not, then, be stifled in the vault$NEWLINE$To whose foul mouth no healthsome air breathes in,$NEWLINE$And there die strangled ere my Romeo comes?$NEWLINE$Or, if I live, is it not very like$NEWLINE$The horrible conceit of death and night,$NEWLINE$Together with the terror of the place—$NEWLINE$As in a vault, an ancient receptacle,$NEWLINE$Where for these many hundred years the bones$NEWLINE$Of all my buried ancestors are packed;$NEWLINE$Where bloody Tybalt, yet but green in earth,$NEWLINE$Lies festering in his shroud; where, as they say,$NEWLINE$At some hours in the night spirits resort—?$NEWLINE$Alack, alack, is it not like that I,$NEWLINE$So early waking, what with loathsome smells,$NEWLINE$And shrieks like mandrakes torn out of the earth,$NEWLINE$That living mortals, hearing them, run mad—?
paragraphs.translated: Alright, here’s the vial. What if this mixture doesn’t work at all? Will I be married tomorrow morning? No, no, this knife will stop it. Lie down right there.$NEWLINE$(she lays down the knife) What if the Friar mixed the potion to kill me? Is he worried that he will be disgraced if I marry Paris after he married me to Romeo? I’m afraid that it’s poison. And yet, it shouldn’t be poison because he is a trustworthy holy man. What if, when I am put in the tomb, I wake up before Romeo comes to save me? That’s a frightening idea. Won’t I suffocate in the tomb? There’s no healthy air to breathe in there. Will I die of suffocation before Romeo comes? Or if I live, I’ll be surrounded by death and darkness. It will be terrible. There will be bones hundreds of years old in that tomb, my ancestors' bones. Tybalt’s body will be in there, freshly entombed, and his corpse will be rotting. They say that during the night the spirits are in tombs. Oh no, oh no. I’ll wake up and smell awful odors. I’ll hear screams that would drive people crazy.$NEWLINE$(she lays down the knife)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Oh, if I wake, shall I not be distraught,$NEWLINE$Environèd with all these hideous fears,$NEWLINE$And madly play with my forefather’s joints,$NEWLINE$And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud,$NEWLINE$And, in this rage, with some great kinsman’s bone,$NEWLINE$As with a club, dash out my desperate brains?$NEWLINE$Oh, look! Methinks I see my cousin’s ghost$NEWLINE$Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body$NEWLINE$Upon a rapier’s point. Stay, Tybalt, stay!$NEWLINE$Romeo, Romeo, Romeo! Here’s drink. I drink to thee.
paragraphs.translated: If I wake up too early, won’t I go insane with all these horrible, frightening things around me, start playing with my ancestors' bones, and pull Tybalt’s corpse out of his death shroud? Will I grab one of my dead ancestor’s bones and bash in my own skull? Oh, look! I think I see my cousin Tybalt’s ghost. He’s looking for Romeo because Romeo killed him with his sword. Wait, Tybalt, wait! Romeo, Romeo, Romeo! Here’s a drink. I drink to you.

paragraphs.original: She drinks and falls down on the bed, hidden by the bed curtains
paragraphs.translated: She drinks from the vial and falls on her bed, hidden by her bed curtains.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY CAPULET and NURSE$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET and the NURSE enter.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, Nurse.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Wait. Take these keys and get more spices, Nurse.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$They’re calling for dates and quinces in the pastry kitchen.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAPULET$NEWLINE$CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET enters.$NEWLINE$CAPULET

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Come, stir, stir, stir! The second cock hath crowed.$NEWLINE$The curfew bell hath rung. 'Tis three o'clock.—$NEWLINE$Look to the baked meats, good Angelica.$NEWLINE$Spare not for the cost.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Come on, wake up, wake up, wake up! The second cock crowed. The curfew-bell rang. It’s three o'clock. Go get the baked meats, good Angelica. Don’t worry about the cost.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Go, you cot-quean, go.$NEWLINE$Get you to bed, faith. You’ll be sick tomorrow$NEWLINE$For this night’s watching.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Go, you old housewife, go. Go to bed, dear. You’ll be sick tomorrow because you’ve stayed up all night.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$No, not a whit, what. I have watched ere now$NEWLINE$All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$No, not at all. What? I’ve stayed up all night many times before for less important matters, and I’ve never gotten sick.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time,$NEWLINE$But I will watch you from such watching now.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Yes, you’ve been a ladies' man in your time. But I’ll make sure you don’t stay up any later now.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LADY CAPULET and NURSE$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET and the NURSE exit.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$A jealous hood, a jealous hood!
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$A jealous woman, a jealous woman!

paragraphs.original: Enter three or four SERVINGMEN with spits and logs and baskets$NEWLINE$SERVINGMEN
paragraphs.translated: Three or four SERVINGMEN enter with spits, logs, and baskets.$NEWLINE$SERVINGMEN

paragraphs.original: Now, fellow,$NEWLINE$What is there?
paragraphs.translated: Now, fellow, what have you got there?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$Things for the cook, sir, but I know not what.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$Things for the cook, sir. But I don’t know what they are.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Make haste, make haste, sirrah.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Hurry up, hurry up.

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$FIRST SERVINGMAN
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST SERVINGMAN exits.$NEWLINE$FIRST SERVINGMAN

paragraphs.original: (to SECOND SERVINGMAN) Fetch drier logs.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Call Peter. He will show thee where they are.
paragraphs.translated: (to SECOND SERVINGMAN) You, fetch logs that are drier than these. Call Peter, he’ll show you where they are.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SECOND SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$I have a head, sir, that will find out logs,$NEWLINE$And never trouble Peter for the matter.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$I’m smart enough to find the logs myself without bothering Peter.

paragraphs.original: Exit SECOND SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$SECOND SERVINGMAN
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND SERVINGMAN exits.$NEWLINE$SECOND SERVINGMAN

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Mass, and well said. A merry whoreson, ha!$NEWLINE$Thou shalt be loggerhead.—Good faith, ’tis day.$NEWLINE$The county will be here with music straight,$NEWLINE$For so he said he would. I hear him near.—
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Right, and well said. That guy’s funny. He’s got a head full of logs. Goodness, it’s daylight. The count will be here soon with music. At least he said he would. I hear him coming near.

paragraphs.original: Music plays within
paragraphs.translated: Music plays offstage.

paragraphs.original: Nurse! Wife! What, ho? What, Nurse, I say!
paragraphs.translated: Nurse! Wife! What? Hey, Nurse!

paragraphs.original: Enter NURSE$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE returns.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: Go waken Juliet. Go and trim her up.$NEWLINE$I’ll go and chat with Paris. Hie, make haste,$NEWLINE$Make haste. The bridegroom he is come already.$NEWLINE$Make haste, I say.
paragraphs.translated: Go wake Juliet. Go and get her dressed. I’ll go and chat with Paris. Hey, hurry up, hurry up! The bridegroom is already here. Hurry up, I say.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter NURSE$NEWLINE$NURSE
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE enters.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Mistress! What, mistress! Juliet!—Fast, I warrant her, she.—$NEWLINE$Why, lamb! Why, lady! Fie, you slug-a-bed.$NEWLINE$Why, love, I say. Madam! Sweet-heart! Why, bride!$NEWLINE$What, not a word? You take your pennyworths now.$NEWLINE$Sleep for a week, for the next night, I warrant,$NEWLINE$The County Paris hath set up his rest$NEWLINE$That you shall rest but little.—God forgive me,$NEWLINE$Marry, and amen. How sound is she asleep!$NEWLINE$I must needs wake her.—Madam, madam, madam!$NEWLINE$Ay, let the county take you in your bed.$NEWLINE$He’ll fright you up, i' faith. Will it not be?$NEWLINE$(opens the bed curtains)$NEWLINE$(opens the bed curtains)$NEWLINE$What, dressed and in your clothes, and down again?$NEWLINE$I must needs wake you. Lady, lady, lady!—$NEWLINE$Alas, alas! Help, help! My lady’s dead!—$NEWLINE$Oh, welladay, that ever I was born!—$NEWLINE$Some aqua vitae, ho!—My lord! My lady!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Mistress! Hey, mistress! Juliet! I bet she’s fast asleep. Hey, lamb! Hey, lady! Hey, you lazy bones! Hey, love, I say! Madam! Sweetheart! Hey, bride! What, you don’t say a word? You take your beauty sleep now. Get yourself a week’s worth of sleep. Tomorrow night, I bet, Count Paris won’t let you get much rest. God forgive me. Alright, and amen. How sound asleep she is! I must wake her up. Madam, madam, madam! Yes, let the count take you in your bed. He’ll wake you up, I bet. Won’t he?$NEWLINE$(she opens the bed curtains) What?
