You’re still dressed in all your clothes. But you’re still asleep. I must wake you up. Lady! Lady! Lady! Oh no, oh no! Help, help! My lady’s dead! Oh curse the day that I was born! Ho! Get me some brandy! My lord! My lady!$NEWLINE$(she opens the bed curtains)

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET enters.$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$What noise is here?
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$What’s all the noise in here?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$O lamentable day!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, sad day!

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$What is the matter?
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$What is the matter?

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Look, look. O heavy day!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Look, look! Oh, what a sad day!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$O me, O me! My child, my only life,$NEWLINE$Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!—$NEWLINE$Help, help! Call help.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Oh my, Oh my! My child, my reason for living, wake up, look up, or I’ll die with you! Help, help! Call for help.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAPULET$NEWLINE$CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET enters.$NEWLINE$CAPULET

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$For shame, bring Juliet forth. Her lord is come.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$For shame, bring Juliet out here. Her bridegroom is here.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$She’s dead, deceased, she’s dead. Alack the day!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$She’s dead, deceased, she’s dead. Curse the day!

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Alack the day. She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Curse the day! She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Ha? Let me see her. Out, alas! She’s cold.$NEWLINE$Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.$NEWLINE$Life and these lips have long been separated.$NEWLINE$Death lies on her like an untimely frost$NEWLINE$Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$No! Let me see her. Oh no! She’s cold. Her blood has stopped, and her joints are stiff. She’s been dead for some time. She’s dead, like a beautiful flower, killed by an unseasonable frost.

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$O lamentable day!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh, sad day!

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$O woeful time.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Oh, this is a painful time!

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail,$NEWLINE$Ties up my tongue and will not let me speak.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Death, which has taken her away to make me cry, now ties up my tongue and won’t let me speak.

paragraphs.original: Enter FRIAR LAWRENCE, County PARIS, and MUSICIANS$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$MUSICIANS
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE and PARIS enter with MUSICIANS.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$MUSICIANS

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Come, is the bride ready to go to church?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Come, is the bride ready to go to church?

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Ready to go, but never to return.$NEWLINE$O son! The night before thy wedding day$NEWLINE$Hath death lain with thy wife. There she lies,$NEWLINE$Flower as she was, deflowered by him.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$She’s ready to go, but she’ll never return. (to PARIS) Oh son! On the night before your wedding day, death has taken your wife. There she lies. She was a flower, but death deflowered her.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Death is my son-in-law. Death is my heir.$NEWLINE$My daughter he hath wedded. I will die,$NEWLINE$And leave him all. Life, living, all is Death’s.
paragraphs.translated: Death is my son-in-law. Death is my heir. My daughter married death. I will die and leave Death everything. Life, wealth, everything belongs to Death.

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Have I thought long to see this morning’s face,$NEWLINE$And doth it give me such a sight as this?
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$Have I waited so long to see this morning, only to see this?

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!$NEWLINE$Most miserable hour that e'er time saw$NEWLINE$In lasting labor of his pilgrimage.$NEWLINE$But one, poor one, one poor and loving child,$NEWLINE$But one thing to rejoice and solace in,$NEWLINE$And cruel death hath catched it from my sight!
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day! This is the most miserable hour of all time! I had only one child, one poor child, one poor and loving child, the one thing I had to rejoice and comfort myself, and cruel Death has stolen it from me!

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$O woe! O woeful, woeful, woeful day!$NEWLINE$Most lamentable day, most woeful day$NEWLINE$That ever, ever, I did yet behold!$NEWLINE$O day, O day, O day, O hateful day!$NEWLINE$Never was seen so black a day as this.$NEWLINE$O woeful day, O woeful day!
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Oh pain! Oh painful, painful, painful day! The saddest day, most painful day that I ever, ever did behold! Oh day! Oh day! Oh day! Oh hateful day! There has never been so black a day as today. Oh painful day, Oh painful day!

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Beguiled, divorcèd, wrongèd, spited, slain!$NEWLINE$Most detestable Death, by thee beguiled,$NEWLINE$By cruel, cruel thee quite overthrown!$NEWLINE$O love! O life! Not life, but love in death.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$She was tricked, divorced, wronged, spited, killed! Death, the most despicable thing, tricked her. Cruel, cruel Death killed her. Oh love! Oh life! There is no life, but my love is dead!

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Despised, distressèd, hated, martyred, killed!$NEWLINE$Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now$NEWLINE$To murder, murder our solemnity?$NEWLINE$O child, O child! My soul, and not my child!$NEWLINE$Dead art thou! Alack, my child is dead,$NEWLINE$And with my child my joys are buried.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Despised, distressed, hated, martyred, killed! Why did this have to happen now? Why did Death have to ruin our wedding? Oh child! Oh child! My soul and not my child! You are dead! Oh no! My child is dead. My child will be buried, and so will my joys.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Peace, ho, for shame! Confusion’s cure lives not$NEWLINE$In these confusions. Heaven and yourself$NEWLINE$Had part in this fair maid. Now heaven hath all,
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Be quiet, for shame! The cure for confusion is not yelling and screaming. You had this child with the help of heaven. Now heaven has her.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And all the better is it for the maid.$NEWLINE$Your part in her you could not keep from death,$NEWLINE$But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.$NEWLINE$The most you sought was her promotion,$NEWLINE$For ’twas your heaven she should be advanced.$NEWLINE$And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced$NEWLINE$Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?$NEWLINE$Oh, in this love, you love your child so ill$NEWLINE$That you run mad, seeing that she is well.$NEWLINE$She’s not well married that lives married long,$NEWLINE$But she’s best married that dies married young.$NEWLINE$Dry up your tears and stick your rosemary$NEWLINE$On this fair corse, and, as the custom is,$NEWLINE$And in her best array, bear her to church.$NEWLINE$For though some nature bids us all lament,$NEWLINE$Yet nature’s tears are reason’s merriment.
paragraphs.translated: She is in a better place. You could not prevent her from dying someday, but heaven will give her eternal life. The most you hope for was for her to marry wealthy and rise up the social ladder—that was your idea of heaven. And now you cry, even though she has risen up above the clouds, as high as heaven itself? Oh, in this love, you love your child so badly, that you go mad, even though she is in heaven. It is best to marry well and die young, better than to be married for a long time. Dry up your tears, and put your rosemary on this beautiful corpse. And, in accordance with custom, carry her to the church in her best clothes. It’s natural for us to shed tears for her, but the truth is, we should be happy for her.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$All things that we ordained festival$NEWLINE$Turn from their office to black funeral.$NEWLINE$Our instruments to melancholy bells,$NEWLINE$Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast.$NEWLINE$Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change,$NEWLINE$Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse,$NEWLINE$And all things change them to the contrary.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$All the things that we prepared for the wedding party will now be used for the funeral. Our happy music will now be sad. Our wedding banquet will become a sad burial feast. Our celebratory hymns will change to sad funeral marches. Our bridal flowers will cover a buried corpse. And everything will be used for the opposite purpose from what we intended.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Sir, go you in, and, madam, go with him;$NEWLINE$And go, Sir Paris. Every one prepare$NEWLINE$To follow this fair corse unto her grave.$NEWLINE$The heavens do lour upon you for some ill.$NEWLINE$Move them no more by crossing their high will.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Sir, you go in. And, madam, go with him. And you go too, Sir Paris. Everyone prepare to take this beautiful corpse to her grave. The heavens hang threateningly over you for some past sin. Don’t disturb the heavens any more by trying to go against heaven’s will.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, PARIS, and FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, PARIS, and FRIAR LAWRENCE exit.$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Faith, we may put up our pipes and be gone.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Well, we can put away our pipes and go home.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NURSE$NEWLINE$Honest good fellows, ah, put up, put up,$NEWLINE$For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.
paragraphs.translated: NURSE$NEWLINE$Honest good boys, ah, put 'em away, put 'em away. As you know, this is a sad case.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The NURSE exits.$NEWLINE$NURSE

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, well, things could get better.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETER$NEWLINE$PETER
paragraphs.translated: PETER enters.$NEWLINE$PETER

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$Musicians, O musicians, “Heart’s Ease,” “Heart’s Ease.” O, an you will have me live, play “Heart’s Ease.”
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$Musicians, oh, musicians, play “Heart’s Ease,” “Heart’s Ease.” Oh, I’ll die if you don’t play “Heart’s Ease.”

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Why “Heart’s ease?”
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Why “Heart’s Ease”?

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$O musicians, because my heart itself plays “My Heart is Full.” O, play me some merry dump to comfort me.
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$Oh, musicians, because my heart is singing “My$NEWLINE$Heart is Full of Woe.” Oh, play me some happy sad song to comfort me.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Not a dump, we. 'Tis no time to play now.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$No, not a sad song. It’s not the right time to play.

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$You will not then?
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$You won’t, then?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$I will then give it you soundly.
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$Then I’ll really give it to you.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$What will you give us?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$What will you give us?

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$No money, on my faith, but the gleek. I will give you the minstrel.
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$No money, I swear. But I’ll play a trick on you. I’ll call you a minstrel.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Then I will give you the serving creature.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Then I’ll call you a serving-creature.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$Then will I lay the serving creature’s dagger on your pate. I will carry no crotchets. I’ll re you, I’ll fa you. Do you note me?$NEWLINE$re$NEWLINE$fa
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$Then I’ll smack you on the head with the serving-creature’s knife. I won’t mess around. I’ll make you sing. Do you hear me?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$An you re us and fa us, you note us.$NEWLINE$re$NEWLINE$fa
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$If you make us sing, you’ll hear us.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Pray you, put up your dagger and put out your wit.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Please, put down your knife and stop kidding around.

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$Then have at you with my wit. I will dry-beat you with an iron wit and put up my iron dagger. Answer me like men.
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$So you don’t like my kidding around! I’ll kid you to death, and then I’ll put down my knife. Answer me like men.

paragraphs.original: (sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$When griping grief the heart doth wound$NEWLINE$When griping grief the heart doth wound$NEWLINE$And doleful dumps the mind oppress,$NEWLINE$And doleful dumps the mind oppress,$NEWLINE$Then music with her silver sound—$NEWLINE$Then music with her silver sound—
paragraphs.translated: (sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$When sadness wounds your heart,$NEWLINE$When sadness wounds your heart,$NEWLINE$And pain takes over your mind,$NEWLINE$And pain takes over your mind,$NEWLINE$Then music with her silver sound—$NEWLINE$Then music with her silver sound—

paragraphs.original: (speaks) Why “silver sound”? Why “music with her silver sound”? What say you, Simon Catling?$NEWLINE$(speaks)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaks) Why the line “silver sound”? What do they mean, “music with her silver sound”? What do you say, Simon
Catling?$NEWLINE$(speaks)$NEWLINE$Catling$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICAN$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Well, sir, because silver has a sweet sound.

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$Prates.—What say you, Hugh Rebeck?
paragraphs.translated:
PETER$NEWLINE$That’s a stupid answer! What do you say, Hugh
Rebeck?$NEWLINE$Rebeck$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SECOND MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$I say, “silver sound” because musicians sound for silver.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$I say “silver sound,” because musicians play to earn silver.

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$Prates too.—What say you, James Soundpost?
paragraphs.translated:
PETER$NEWLINE$Another studpid answer! What do you say, James
Soundpost?$NEWLINE$Soundpost$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: THIRD MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Faith, I know not what to say.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Well, I don’t know what to say.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PETER$NEWLINE$Oh, I cry you mercy, you are the singer. I will say for you. It is “music with her silver sound” because musicians have no gold for sounding.
paragraphs.translated: PETER$NEWLINE$Oh, I beg your pardon. You’re the singer. I’ll answer for you. It is “music with her silver sound,” because musicians have no gold to use to make sounds.

paragraphs.original: (sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Then music with her silver sound$NEWLINE$Then music with her silver sound$NEWLINE$With speedy help doth lend redress.$NEWLINE$With speedy help doth lend redress.
paragraphs.translated: (sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Then music with her silver sound$NEWLINE$Then music with her silver sound$NEWLINE$makes you feel just fine.$NEWLINE$makes you feel just fine.

paragraphs.original: Exit PETER$NEWLINE$PETER
paragraphs.translated: PETER exits.$NEWLINE$PETER

paragraphs.original: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$What a pestilent knave is this same!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$What an annoying man, this guy is!

paragraphs.original: SECOND MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Hang him, Jack! Come, we’ll in here, tarry for the mourners and stay dinner.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MUSICIAN$NEWLINE$Forget about him, Jack! Come, we’ll go in there. We’ll wait for the mourners and stay for dinner.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: The MUSICIANS exit.$NEWLINE$MUSICIANS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ROMEO$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO enters.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep,$NEWLINE$My dreams presage some joyful news at hand.$NEWLINE$My bosom’s lord sits lightly in his throne,$NEWLINE$And all this day an unaccustomed spirit$NEWLINE$Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts.$NEWLINE$I dreamt my lady came and found me dead—$NEWLINE$Strange dream, that gives a dead man leave to think—$NEWLINE$And breathed such life with kisses in my lips$NEWLINE$That I revived and was an emperor.$NEWLINE$Ah me! How sweet is love itself possessed$NEWLINE$When but love’s shadows are so rich in joy!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$If I can trust my dreams, then some joyful news is coming soon. Love rules my heart, and all day long a strange feeling has been making me cheerful. I had a dream that my lady came and found me dead. It’s a strange dream that lets a dead man think! She came and brought me back to life by kissing my lips. I rose from the dead and was an emperor. Oh my! How sweet it would be to actually have the woman I love, when merely thinking about love makes me so happy.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROMEO’s man BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO’s servant BALTHASAR enters.$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original: News from Verona!—How now, Balthasar?$NEWLINE$Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?$NEWLINE$How doth my lady? Is my father well?$NEWLINE$How fares my Juliet? That I ask again,$NEWLINE$For nothing can be ill if she be well.
paragraphs.translated: Do you have news from Verona!—What is it, Balthasar? Do you bring me a letter from the friar? How is my wife? Is my father well? How is my Juliet? I ask that again because nothing can be wrong if she is well.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.$NEWLINE$Her body sleeps in Capels' monument,$NEWLINE$And her immortal part with angels lives.$NEWLINE$I saw her laid low in her kindred’s vault$NEWLINE$And presently took post to tell it you.$NEWLINE$O, pardon me for bringing these ill news,$NEWLINE$Since you did leave it for my office, sir.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Then she is well, and nothing is wrong. Her body sleeps in the Capulet tomb, and her immortal soul lives with the angels in heaven. I saw her buried in her family’s tomb, and then I came here to tell you the news. Oh, pardon me for bringing this bad news, but you told me it was my job, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Is it e'en so? Then I defy you, stars!$NEWLINE$Thou know’st my lodging. Get me ink and paper,$NEWLINE$And hire post horses. I will hence tonight.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Is it really true? Then I rebel against you, stars! You know where I live. Get me some ink and paper, and hire some horses to ride. I will leave here for Verona tonight.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I do beseech you, sir, have patience.$NEWLINE$Your looks are pale and wild, and do import$NEWLINE$Some misadventure.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Please, sir, have patience. You look pale and wild as if you’re going to hurt yourself.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Tush, thou art deceived.$NEWLINE$Leave me and do the thing I bid thee do.$NEWLINE$Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Tsk, you’re wrong. Leave me and do what I told you to do. Don’t you have a letter for me from the friar?

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$No, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$No, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$No matter. Get thee gone,$NEWLINE$And hire those horses. I’ll be with thee straight.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$No matter. Get on your way and hire those horses. I’ll be with you right away.

paragraphs.original: Exit BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR exits.$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original: Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee tonight.$NEWLINE$Let’s see for means. O mischief, thou art swift$NEWLINE$To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!$NEWLINE$I do remember an apothecary—$NEWLINE$And hereabouts he dwells—which late I noted$NEWLINE$In tattered weeds, with overwhelming brows,$NEWLINE$Culling of simples. Meager were his looks,$NEWLINE$Sharp misery had worn him to the bones,$NEWLINE$And in his needy shop a tortoise hung,$NEWLINE$An alligator stuffed, and other skins$NEWLINE$Of ill-shaped fishes; and about his shelves$NEWLINE$A beggarly account of empty boxes,$NEWLINE$Green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds,$NEWLINE$Remnants of packthread and old cakes of roses,$NEWLINE$Were thinly scattered to make up a show.
paragraphs.translated: Well, Juliet, I’ll lie with you tonight. Let’s see how. Destructive thoughts come quickly to the minds of desperate men! I remember a pharmacist who lives nearby. I remember he wears shabby clothes and has bushy eyebrows. He makes drugs from herbs. He looks poor and miserable and worn out to the bone. He had a tortoise shell hanging up in his shop as well as a stuffed alligator and other skins of strange fish. There were a few empty boxes on his shelves, as well as green clay pots, and some musty seeds. There were a few strands of string and mashed rose petals on display.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Noting this penury, to myself I said,$NEWLINE$“An if a man did need a poison now”—$NEWLINE$Whose sale is present death in Mantua—$NEWLINE$“Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.”$NEWLINE$Oh, this same thought did but forerun my need,$NEWLINE$And this same needy man must sell it me.$NEWLINE$As I remember, this should be the house.$NEWLINE$Being holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.$NEWLINE$What, ho! Apothecary!
paragraphs.translated: Noticing all this poverty, I said to myself, “If a man needed some poison”—which they would immediately kill you for selling in Mantua—“here is a miserable wretch who’d sell it to him.” Oh, this idea came before I needed the poison. But this same poor man must sell it to me. As I remember, this should be the house. Today’s a holiday, so the beggar’s shop is shut. Hey! Pharmacist!

paragraphs.original: Enter APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$APOTHECARY
paragraphs.translated: The APOTHECARY enters.$NEWLINE$APOTHECARY

paragraphs.original: APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$Who calls so loud?
paragraphs.translated: APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$Who’s that calling so loud?

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Come hither, man. I see that thou art poor.$NEWLINE$Hold, there is forty ducats. Let me have$NEWLINE$A dram of poison, such soon-speeding gear$NEWLINE$As will disperse itself through all the veins$NEWLINE$That the life-weary taker may fall dead,$NEWLINE$And that the trunk may be discharged of breath$NEWLINE$As violently as hasty powder fired$NEWLINE$Doth hurry from the fatal cannon’s womb.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Come here, man. I see that you are poor. Here are forty ducats. Let me have a shot of poison, something that works so fast that the person who takes it will die as fast as gunpowder exploding in a canon.

paragraphs.original: APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$Such mortal drugs I have, but Mantua’s law$NEWLINE$Is death to any he that utters them.
paragraphs.translated: APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$I have lethal poisons like that. But it’s against the law to sell them in Mantua, and the penalty is death.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness,$NEWLINE$And fear’st to die? Famine is in thy cheeks.$NEWLINE$Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes.$NEWLINE$Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back.$NEWLINE$The world is not thy friend nor the world’s law.$NEWLINE$The world affords no law to make thee rich.$NEWLINE$Then be not poor, but break it, and take this.$NEWLINE$(holds out money)$NEWLINE$(holds out money)
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$You’re this poor and wretched and still afraid to die? Your cheeks are thin because of hunger. I can see in your eyes that you’re starving. Anyone can see that you’re a beggar. The world is not your friend, and neither is the law. The world doesn’t make laws to make you rich. So don’t be poor. Break the law, and take this money. (he holds out money)$NEWLINE$(he holds out money)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$My poverty, but not my will, consents.
paragraphs.translated: APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$I agree because I’m poor, not because I want to.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I pay thy poverty and not thy will.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I pay you because you’re poor, not because you want me to buy this.

paragraphs.original: APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$(gives ROMEO poison) Put this in any liquid thing you will$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$poison)$NEWLINE$And drink it off; and, if you had the strength$NEWLINE$Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.
paragraphs.translated: APOTHECARY$NEWLINE$(gives ROMEO poison) Put this in any kind of liquid you want and drink it down. Even if you were as strong as twenty men, it would kill you immediately.$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$poison)

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(gives APOTHECARY money)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$money)$NEWLINE$There is thy gold, worse poison to men’s souls,$NEWLINE$Doing more murder in this loathsome world,$NEWLINE$Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell.$NEWLINE$I sell thee poison. Thou hast sold me none.$NEWLINE$Farewell. Buy food, and get thyself in flesh.—$NEWLINE$Come, cordial and not poison, go with me$NEWLINE$To Juliet’s grave, for there must I use thee.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(gives APOTHECARY money) There is your gold. Money is a worse poison to men’s souls, and commits more murders in this awful world, than these poor poisons that you’re not allowed to sell. I’ve sold you poison. You haven’t sold me any. Goodbye. Buy yourself food, and put some flesh on your bones. I’ll take this mixture, which is a medicine, not a poison, to Juliet’s grave. That’s where I must use it.$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$money)$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$FRIAR JOHN
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR JOHN enters.$NEWLINE$FRIAR JOHN

paragraphs.original: FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$Holy Franciscan Friar! Brother, ho!
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$Holy Franciscan Friar! Brother, hey!

paragraphs.original: Enter FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE enters.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$This same should be the voice of Friar John.$NEWLINE$Welcome from Mantua. What says Romeo?$NEWLINE$Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$That sounds like the voice of Friar John. Welcome back from Mantua. What does Romeo say? Or, if he wrote down his thoughts, give me his letter.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$Going to find a barefoot brother out,$NEWLINE$One of our order, to associate me,$NEWLINE$Here in this city visiting the sick,$NEWLINE$And finding him, the searchers of the town,$NEWLINE$Suspecting that we both were in a house$NEWLINE$Where the infectious pestilence did reign,$NEWLINE$Sealed up the doors and would not let us forth.$NEWLINE$So that my speed to Mantua there was stayed.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$I went to find another poor friar from our order to accompany me. He was here in this city visiting the sick. When I found him, the town health officials suspected that we were both in a house that had been hit with the plague. They quarantined the house, sealed up the doors, and refused to let us out. I couldn’t go to Mantua because I was stuck there.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Then who took my letter to Romeo?

paragraphs.original: FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$I could not send it—here it is again—$NEWLINE$(gives FRIAR LAWRENCE a letter)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a letter)$NEWLINE$Nor get a messenger to bring it thee,$NEWLINE$So fearful were they of infection.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$I couldn’t send it. Here it is. (he gives FRIAR LAWRENCE a letter) I couldn’t get a messenger to bring it to you either because they were scared of spreading the infection.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$a letter)

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Unhappy fortune! By my brotherhood,$NEWLINE$The letter was not nice but full of charge,$NEWLINE$Of dear import, and the neglecting it$NEWLINE$May do much danger. Friar John, go hence.$NEWLINE$Get me an iron crow and bring it straight$NEWLINE$Unto my cell.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Unhappy fortune! By my brotherhood, the letter was not just a nice greeting. It was full of very important information. It’s very dangerous that it hasn’t been sent. Friar John, go and get me an iron crowbar. Bring it straight back to my cell.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$Brother, I’ll go and bring it thee.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$Brother, I’ll go and bring it to you.

paragraphs.original: Exit FRIAR JOHN$NEWLINE$FRIAR JOHN
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR JOHN exits.$NEWLINE$FRIAR JOHN

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Now must I to the monument alone.$NEWLINE$Within this three hours will fair Juliet wake.$NEWLINE$She will beshrew me much that Romeo$NEWLINE$Hath had no notice of these accidents.$NEWLINE$But I will write again to Mantua,$NEWLINE$And keep her at my cell till Romeo come.$NEWLINE$Poor living corse, closed in a dead man’s tomb!
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Now I must go to the tomb alone. Within three hours Juliet will wake up. She’ll be very angry with me that Romeo doesn’t know what happened. But I’ll write again to Mantua, and I’ll keep her in my cell until Romeo comes. That poor living corpse. She’s shut inside a dead man’s tomb!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE exits.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PARIS and his PAGE$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: PARIS enters with his PAGE.$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$Give me thy torch, boy. Hence, and stand aloof.$NEWLINE$Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.$NEWLINE$Under yon yew trees lay thee all along,$NEWLINE$Holding thine ear close to the hollow ground—$NEWLINE$So shall no foot upon the churchyard tread,$NEWLINE$Being loose, unfirm, with digging up of graves,$NEWLINE$But thou shalt hear it. Whistle then to me,$NEWLINE$As signal that thou hear’st something approach.$NEWLINE$Give me those flowers. Do as I bid thee, go.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$Give me your torch, boy. Go away and stay apart from me. Put the torch out, so I can’t be seen. Hide under the yew-trees over there. Listen to make sure no one is coming through the graveyard. If you hear any one, whistle to me to signal that someone is approaching. Give me those flowers. Do as I tell you. Go.

paragraphs.original: PAGE extinguishes torch, gives PARIS flowers$NEWLINE$PAGE$NEWLINE$PARIS
paragraphs.translated: The PAGE puts out the torch and gives PARIS the flowers.$NEWLINE$PAGE$NEWLINE$PARIS

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$(aside) I am almost afraid to stand alone$NEWLINE$aside$NEWLINE$Here in the churchyard. Yet I will adventure.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$(to himself) I am almost afraid to stand alone here in the graveyard, but I’ll take the risk.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: PAGE moves aside$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: The PAGE moves aside$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$(scatters flowers at JULIET'S closed tomb)$NEWLINE$(scatters flowers at$NEWLINE$closed tomb)$NEWLINE$Sweet flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew—$NEWLINE$O woe! Thy canopy is dust and stones—$NEWLINE$Which with sweet water nightly I will dew.$NEWLINE$Or, wanting that, with tears distilled by moans,$NEWLINE$The obsequies that I for thee will keep$NEWLINE$Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$(he scatters flowers at JULIET’s closed tomb) Sweet flower, I’m spreading flowers over your bridal bed. Oh, pain! Your canopy is dust and stones. I’ll water these flowers every night with sweet water. Or, if I don’t do that, my nightly rituals to remember you will be to put flowers on your grave and weep.$NEWLINE$(he scatters flowers at$NEWLINE$’s closed tomb)

paragraphs.original: PAGE whistles$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: The PAGE whistles$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: The boy gives warning something doth approach.$NEWLINE$What cursèd foot wanders this way tonight$NEWLINE$To cross my obsequies and true love’s rite?$NEWLINE$What with a torch! Muffle me, night, awhile.
paragraphs.translated: The boy is warning me that someone approaches. Who could be walking around here tonight? Who’s ruining my rituals of true love?$NEWLINE$It’s someone with a torch! I must hide in the darkness for awhile.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PARIS moves away from the tomb Enter ROMEO and BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: PARIS hides in the darkness. ROMEO and BALTHASAR enter with a torch, a pickax, and an iron crowbar.$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.$NEWLINE$(takes them from BALTHASAR)$NEWLINE$(takes them from$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Hold, take this letter. Early in the morning$NEWLINE$See thou deliver it to my lord and father.$NEWLINE$(gives letter to BALTHASAR)$NEWLINE$(gives letter to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Give me the light.$NEWLINE$(takes torch from BALTHASAR)$NEWLINE$(takes torch from$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Upon thy life I charge thee,$NEWLINE$Whate'er thou hear’st or seest, stand all aloof,$NEWLINE$And do not interrupt me in my course.$NEWLINE$Why I descend into this bed of death$NEWLINE$Is partly to behold my lady’s face,$NEWLINE$But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger$NEWLINE$A precious ring, a ring that I must use$NEWLINE$In dear employment. Therefore hence, be gone.$NEWLINE$But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry$NEWLINE$In what I farther shall intend to do,$NEWLINE$By heaven, I will tear thee joint by joint$NEWLINE$And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs.$NEWLINE$The time and my intents are savage, wild,$NEWLINE$More fierce and more inexorable far$NEWLINE$Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.$NEWLINE$
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Give me that pickax and the crowbar. (he takes them from BALTHASAR) Here, take this letter. Early in the morning deliver it to my father. (he gives the letter to BALTHASAR) Give me the light. (he takes the torch from BALTHASAR) Swear on your life, I command you, whatever you hear or see, stay away from me and do not interrupt me in my plan. I’m going down into this tomb of the dead, partly to behold my wife’s face. But my main reason is to take a precious ring from her dead finger. I must use that ring for an important purpose. So go on your way. But if you get curious and return to spy on me, I swear I’ll tear you apart limb by limb and spread your body parts around to feed the hungry animals in the graveyard. My plan is wild and savage. I am more fierce in this endeavor than a hungry tiger or the raging sea.$NEWLINE$(he takes them from$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(he gives the letter to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(he takes the torch from$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I’ll go, sir, and I won’t bother you.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$So shalt thou show me friendship. Take thou that.$NEWLINE$(gives BALTHASAR money)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$money)$NEWLINE$Live and be prosperous, and farewell, good fellow.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$That’s the way to show me friendship. Take this. (he gives BALTHASAR money) Live and be prosperous. Farewell, good fellow.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$(aside) For all this same, I’ll hide me hereabout.$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$His looks I fear, and his intents I doubt.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only PARIS can hear) Despite what I said, I’ll hide nearby. I’m frightened by the look on his face, and I have doubts about his intentions.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR moves aside, falls asleep$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR moves aside and falls asleep.$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death,$NEWLINE$Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth,$NEWLINE$Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open,$NEWLINE$And in despite I’ll cram thee with more food!$NEWLINE$(begins to opens the tomb with his tools)$NEWLINE$(begins to opens the tomb with his tools)
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$(speaking to the tomb) You horrible mouth of death! You’ve eaten up the dearest creature on Earth. Now I’m going to force open your rotten jaws and make you eat another body. (ROMEO begins to open the tomb with his tools)$NEWLINE$(speaking to the tomb)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$begins to open the tomb with his tools)

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$(aside) This is that banished haughty Montague,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$That murdered my love’s cousin, with which grief,$NEWLINE$It is supposed the fair creature died.$NEWLINE$And here is come to do some villainous shame$NEWLINE$To the dead bodies. I will apprehend him.$NEWLINE$(to ROMEO) Stop thy unhallowed toil, vile Montague!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Can vengeance be pursued further than death?$NEWLINE$Condemnèd villain, I do apprehend thee.$NEWLINE$Obey and go with me, for thou must die.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$(speaking so that ROMEO can’t hear) It’s that arrogant Montague, the one who’s been banished. He’s the one who murdered my love’s cousin Tybalt. They think she died with grief for that cousin. This guy has come here to commit awful crimes against the dead bodies. I’ll catch him.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that$NEWLINE$can’t hear)
(to ROMEO) Stop your evil work, vile Montague! Can you take revenge on dead bodies? Condemned villain, I’ve caught you. Obey and come with me. You must die.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I must indeed, and therefore came I hither.$NEWLINE$Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man.$NEWLINE$Fly hence and leave me. Think upon these gone.$NEWLINE$Let them affright thee. I beseech thee, youth,$NEWLINE$Put not another sin upon my head$NEWLINE$By urging me to fury. O, be gone!$NEWLINE$By heaven, I love thee better than myself,$NEWLINE$For I come hither armed against myself.$NEWLINE$Stay not, be gone. Live, and hereafter say$NEWLINE$A madman’s mercy bid thee run away.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$I must indeed. That’s why I came here. Good and noble young man, don’t mess with someone who’s desperate. Get away from here and leave me. Think about the ones who have died. Let them put fear in your heart. Please, young man, don’t make me angry. I don’t want to commit another crime. Oh, go away! I swear, I love you more than I love myself. For I’ve come here with weapons to use against myself. Don’t stay here, go away. Live, and from now on, say a madman mercifully told you to run away.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$I do defy thy commination$NEWLINE$And apprehend thee for a felon here.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$I refuse your request. I’m arresting you as a criminal.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Wilt thou provoke me? Then have at thee, boy!
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Are you going to provoke me? Alright, let’s fight, boy!

paragraphs.original: ROMEO and PARIS fight$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$PARIS
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO and PARIS fight.$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$PARIS

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$O Lord, they fight! I will go call the watch.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$Oh Lord, they’re fighting! I’ll go call the watch.

paragraphs.original: Exit PAGE$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: The PAGE exits.$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: PARIS$NEWLINE$(falls) Oh, I am slain! If thou be merciful,$NEWLINE$(falls)$NEWLINE$Open the tomb. Lay me with Juliet.
paragraphs.translated: PARIS$NEWLINE$(he falls) Oh, I’ve been killed!$NEWLINE$(he falls)$NEWLINE$If you are merciful, open the tomb and lay me next to Juliet.

paragraphs.original: PARIS dies$NEWLINE$PARIS
paragraphs.translated: PARIS dies.$NEWLINE$PARIS

paragraphs.original: ROMEO$NEWLINE$In faith, I will.—Let me peruse this face.$NEWLINE$Mercutio’s kinsman, noble County Paris.$NEWLINE$What said my man, when my betossèd soul$NEWLINE$Did not attend him as we rode? I think$NEWLINE$He told me Paris should have married Juliet.$NEWLINE$Said he not so? Or did I dream it so?$NEWLINE$Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Juliet,$NEWLINE$To think it was so?—O, give me thy hand,$NEWLINE$One writ with me in sour misfortune’s book.$NEWLINE$I’ll bury thee in a triumphant grave.
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO$NEWLINE$Alright, I will. Let me look at this face. It’s Mercutio’s relative, noble Count Paris! What did my man say? I was worried, so I wasn’t listening to him while we were riding. I think he told me Paris was about to marry Juliet. Isn’t that what he said? Or was I dreaming? Or am I crazy? Did I hear him say something about Juliet and jump to conclusions? Oh, give me your hand. Both of us had such bad luck! I’ll bury you in a magnificent grave.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO opens the tomb to reveal JULIET inside$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO opens the tomb to reveal JULIET inside.$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: A grave? Oh, no. A lantern, slaughtered youth,$NEWLINE$For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes$NEWLINE$This vault a feasting presence full of light.$NEWLINE$Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interred.$NEWLINE$(lays PARIS in the tomb)$NEWLINE$(lays$NEWLINE$in the tomb)
paragraphs.translated: A grave? Oh no! This is a lantern, dead Paris. Juliet lies here, and her beauty fills this tomb with light. Dead men, lie there. You are being buried by another dead man. (he lays PARIS in the tomb)$NEWLINE$(he lays$NEWLINE$in the tomb)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How oft when men are at the point of death$NEWLINE$Have they been merry, which their keepers call$NEWLINE$A lightning before death! Oh, how may I$NEWLINE$Call this a lightning?—O my love, my wife!$NEWLINE$Death, that hath sucked the honey of thy breath,$NEWLINE$Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty.$NEWLINE$Thou art not conquered. Beauty’s ensign yet$NEWLINE$Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks,$NEWLINE$And death’s pale flag is not advancèd there.—$NEWLINE$Tybalt, liest thou there in thy bloody sheet?$NEWLINE$O, what more favor can I do to thee,$NEWLINE$Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain$NEWLINE$To sunder his that was thine enemy?$NEWLINE$Forgive me, cousin.—Ah, dear Juliet,$NEWLINE$Why art thou yet so fair? Shall I believe$NEWLINE$That unsubstantial death is amorous,$NEWLINE$And that the lean abhorrèd monster keeps$NEWLINE$Thee here in dark to be his paramour?$NEWLINE$For fear of that, I still will stay with thee,$NEWLINE$And never from this palace of dim night$NEWLINE$Depart again. Here, here will I remain$NEWLINE$With worms that are thy chamber maids. Oh, here$NEWLINE$Will I set up my everlasting rest,$NEWLINE$And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars$NEWLINE$From this world-wearied flesh. Eyes, look your last.$NEWLINE$Arms, take your last embrace. And, lips, O you$NEWLINE$The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss$NEWLINE$A dateless bargain to engrossing death.$NEWLINE$(kisses JULIET, takes out the poison)$NEWLINE$(kisses$NEWLINE$takes out the poison)$NEWLINE$Come, bitter conduct, come, unsavoury guide.$NEWLINE$Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on$NEWLINE$The dashing rocks thy seasick, weary bark.$NEWLINE$Here’s to my love! (drinks the poison) O true apothecary,$NEWLINE$(drinks the poison)$NEWLINE$Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.
paragraphs.translated: How often are men happy right before they die! They call it the lightness before death. Oh, how can I call this lightness? Oh, my love! My wife! Death has sucked the honey from your breath, but it has not yet ruined your beauty. You haven’t been conquered. There is still red in your lips and in your cheeks. Death has not yet turned them pale. Tybalt, are you lying there in your bloody death shroud? Oh, what better favor can I do for you than to kill the man who killed you with the same hand that made you die young. Forgive me, cousin! Ah, dear Juliet, why are you still so beautiful? Should I believe that death is in love with you, and that the awful monster keeps you here to be his mistress? I don’t like that idea, so I’ll stay with you. And I will never leave this tomb. Here, here I’ll remain with worms that are your chamber-maids. Oh, I’ll rest here forever. I’ll forget about all the bad luck that has troubled me. Eyes, look out for the last time! Arms, make your last embrace! And lips, you are the doors of breath. Seal with a righteous kiss the deal I have made with death forever. (ROMEO kisses JULIET and takes out the poison) Come, bitter poison, come, unsavory guide! You desperate pilot, let’s crash this sea-weary ship into the rocks! Here’s to my love!$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$kisses$NEWLINE$and takes out the poison)$NEWLINE$ROMEO drinks the poison.$NEWLINE$drinks the poison$NEWLINE$Oh, that pharmacist was honest! His drugs work quickly. So I die with a kiss.

paragraphs.original: ROMEO dies$NEWLINE$ROMEO
paragraphs.translated: ROMEO dies.$NEWLINE$ROMEO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FRIAR LAWRENCE with lantern, crow, and spade$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE enters with a lantern, crowbar, and shovel.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Saint Francis be my speed! How oft tonight$NEWLINE$Have my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Saint Francis, help me! How often tonight have my old feet stumbled on gravestones! Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Here’s one, a friend, and one that knows you well.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I’m a friend, a friend who knows you well.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Bliss be upon you! Tell me, good my friend,$NEWLINE$What torch is yond that vainly lends his light$NEWLINE$To grubs and eyeless skulls? As I discern,$NEWLINE$It burneth in the Capels' monument.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$God bless you! Tell me, my good friend, what is that light over there? The one that vainly lights up the darkness for worms and skulls without eyes? It looks to me like it’s burning in the Capulet tomb.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$It doth so, holy sir, and there’s my master,$NEWLINE$One that you love.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$That is where it’s burning, father. My master is there. The one you love.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Who is it?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Who is it?

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Romeo.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Romeo.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$How long hath he been there?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$How long has he been there?

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Full half an hour.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$For a full half hour.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Go with me to the vault.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Go with me to the tomb.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I dare not, sir.$NEWLINE$My master knows not but I am gone hence,$NEWLINE$And fearfully did menace me with death$NEWLINE$If I did stay to look on his intents.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I don’t dare, sir. My master doesn’t know I’m still here. He threatened me with death if I stayed to look at what he was doing.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Stay, then. I’ll go alone. Fear comes upon me.$NEWLINE$Oh, much I fear some ill unthrifty thing.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$Stay, then. I’ll go alone. I’m suddenly afraid. Oh, I’m very scared something awful has happened.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$As I did sleep under this yew tree here,$NEWLINE$I dreamt my master and another fought,$NEWLINE$And that my master slew him.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$As I slept under this yew-tree here, I had a dream that my master and someone else were fighting and that my master killed him.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$(approaches the tomb)$NEWLINE$(approaches the tomb)$NEWLINE$Romeo!—$NEWLINE$Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains$NEWLINE$The stony entrance of the sepulcher?$NEWLINE$What mean these masterless and gory swords$NEWLINE$To lie discolored by this place of peace?$NEWLINE$(looks inside the tomb)$NEWLINE$(looks inside the tomb)$NEWLINE$Romeo! O, pale!—Who else? What, Paris too?$NEWLINE$And steeped in blood?—Ah, what an unkind hour$NEWLINE$Is guilty of this lamentable chance!$NEWLINE$The lady stirs.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$(approaching the tomb) Romeo!$NEWLINE$(approaching the tomb)$NEWLINE$Oh no! What is this blood that stains the stony entrance of this tomb? Why are these bloody swords lying here, abandoned by their masters? Next to this place of peace?$NEWLINE$(he looks inside the tomb) Romeo! Oh, he’s pale! Who else? What, Paris too? And he’s covered in blood? Ah, when did these horrible things happen? The lady’s moving.$NEWLINE$(he looks inside the tomb)

paragraphs.original: JULIET wakes$NEWLINE$JULIET
paragraphs.translated: JULIET wakes up.$NEWLINE$JULIET

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$O comfortable Friar! Where is my lord?$NEWLINE$I do remember well where I should be,$NEWLINE$And there I am. Where is my Romeo?
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh friendly friar! Where is my husband? I remember very well where I should be, and here I am. Where is my Romeo?

paragraphs.original: A noise sounds from outside the tomb
paragraphs.translated: A noise sounds from outside the tomb.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I hear some noise. Lady, come from that nest$NEWLINE$Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep.$NEWLINE$A greater power than we can contradict$NEWLINE$Hath thwarted our intents. Come, come away.$NEWLINE$Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead,$NEWLINE$And Paris too. Come, I’ll dispose of thee$NEWLINE$Among a sisterhood of holy nuns.$NEWLINE$Stay not to question, for the watch is coming.$NEWLINE$Come, go, good Juliet. I dare no longer stay.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I hear some noise. Lady, come out of the tomb. A greater power than we can fight has ruined our plan. Come, come away. Your husband lies dead there, and Paris too. Come, I’ll place you among the sisterhood of holy nuns. Don’t wait to ask questions. The watch is coming. Come, let’s go, good Juliet, I don’t dare stay any longer.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Go, get thee hence, for I will not away.—
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Go, get out of here. I’m not going anywhere.

paragraphs.original: Exit FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE exits.$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE

paragraphs.original: What’s here? A cup, closed in my true love’s hand?$NEWLINE$Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end.—$NEWLINE$O churl, drunk all, and left no friendly drop$NEWLINE$To help me after? I will kiss thy lips.$NEWLINE$Haply some poison yet doth hang on them,$NEWLINE$To make me die with a restorative.$NEWLINE$(kisses ROMEO)$NEWLINE$(kisses$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thy lips are warm.
paragraphs.translated: What’s this here? It’s a cup, closed in my true love’s hand? Poison, I see, has been the cause of his death. How rude! He drank it all, and didn’t leave any to help me afterward. I will kiss your lips. Perhaps there’s still some poison on them, to make me die with a medicinal kiss. (she kisses ROMEO) Your lips are warm.$NEWLINE$(she kisses$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Enter WATCHMEN and PARIS’s PAGE$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMEN and PARIS’s PAGE enter.$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN$NEWLINE$PARIS$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(to PAGE) Lead, boy. Which way?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(coming to the PAGE) Lead, boy. Which way?$NEWLINE$(coming to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: JULIET$NEWLINE$Yea, noise? Then I’ll be brief. O happy dagger,$NEWLINE$This is thy sheath. There rust and let me die.$NEWLINE$(stabs herself with ROMEO’s dagger and dies)$NEWLINE$(stabs herself with$NEWLINE$’s dagger and dies)
paragraphs.translated: JULIET$NEWLINE$Oh, noise? Then I’ll be quick. Oh, good, a knife!$NEWLINE$My body will be your sheath.$NEWLINE$Rust inside my body and let me die.$NEWLINE$(she stabs herself with ROMEO’s dagger and dies)$NEWLINE$(she stabs herself with$NEWLINE$’s dagger and dies)

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$This is the place. There, where the torch doth burn.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$This is the place. There, where the torch is burning.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$The ground is bloody.—Search about the churchyard.$NEWLINE$Go, some of you. Whoe'er you find, attach.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$The ground is bloody. Search the graveyard. Go, some of you, arrest whoever you find.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt some WATCHMEN$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN
paragraphs.translated: Some WATCHMEN exit.$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN

paragraphs.original: Pitiful sight! Here lies the county slain,$NEWLINE$And Juliet bleeding, warm and newly dead,$NEWLINE$Who here hath lain these two days buried.—$NEWLINE$Go, tell the Prince. Run to the Capulets.$NEWLINE$Raise up the Montagues.$NEWLINE$Some others search.
paragraphs.translated: This is a pitiful sight! The count is dead. Juliet is bleeding. Her body is warm, and she seems to have been dead only a short time, even though she has been buried for two days. Go, tell the Prince. Run to the Capulets. Wake up the Montagues. Have some others search.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt more WATCHMEN$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN
paragraphs.translated: Some other WATCHMEN exit in several directions.$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: We see the ground whereon these woes do lie,$NEWLINE$But the true ground of all these piteous woes$NEWLINE$We cannot without circumstance descry.
paragraphs.translated: We see the cause of all this pain. But we’ll have to investigate to discover the whole story.

paragraphs.original: Reenter SECOND WATCHMAN with ROMEO’s man BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$ROMEO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND WATCHMAN reenters with BALTHASAR.$NEWLINE$SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Here’s Romeo’s man. We found him in the churchyard.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Here’s Romeo’s man. We found him in the churchyard.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Hold him in safety till the Prince come hither.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Hold him in custody until the Prince gets here.

paragraphs.original: Reenter THIRD WATCHMAN with FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$THIRD WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE
paragraphs.translated: The THIRD WATCHMAN reenters with FRIAR LAWRENCE.$NEWLINE$THIRD WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$FRIAR LAWRENCE

paragraphs.original: THIRD WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Here is a friar that trembles, sighs and weeps.$NEWLINE$We took this mattock and this spade from him$NEWLINE$As he was coming from this churchyard’s side.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Here is a friar who’s trembling, sighing and weeping. We took this pickax and this shovel from him, as he was walking from this side of the graveyard.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$A great suspicion. Stay the friar too.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Very suspicious. Hold the friar too.

paragraphs.original: Enter the PRINCE with ATTENDANTS$NEWLINE$PRINCE$NEWLINE$ATTENDANTS
paragraphs.translated: The PRINCE enters with ATTENDANTS.$NEWLINE$PRINCE$NEWLINE$ATTENDANTS

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$What misadventure is so early up$NEWLINE$That calls our person from our morning rest?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$What crimes happen so early in the morning that I have to wake up before the usual time?

paragraphs.original: Enter CAPULET and LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET and LADY CAPULET enter.$NEWLINE$CAPULET$NEWLINE$LADY CAPULET

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$What should it be that is so shrieked abroad?
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$What’s the problem, that they cry out so loud?

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Oh, the people in the street cry “Romeo,”$NEWLINE$Some “Juliet,” and some “Paris,” and all run$NEWLINE$With open outcry toward our monument.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Some people in the street are crying “Romeo.” Some are crying “Juliet,” and some are crying “Paris.” They’re all running in an open riot toward our tomb.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$What fear is this which startles in our ears?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$What’s this awful thing that everyone’s crying about?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain,$NEWLINE$And Romeo dead, and Juliet, dead before,$NEWLINE$Warm and new killed.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Prince, here lies Count Paris killed. And Romeo dead. And Juliet. She was dead before, but now she’s warm and hasn’t been dead for long.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Investigate how this foul murder came about.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Here is a friar, and slaughtered Romeo’s man,$NEWLINE$With instruments upon them fit to open$NEWLINE$These dead men’s tombs.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Here is a friar, and dead Romeo’s man. They’ve got tools on them—tools they could use to open these tombs.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$O heavens! O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!$NEWLINE$This dagger hath mista'en—for, lo, his house$NEWLINE$Is empty on the back of Montague,$NEWLINE$And it mis-sheathèd in my daughter’s bosom.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Oh heavens! Oh wife, look at how our daughter bleeds! That knife should be in its sheath on that Montague’s back, but instead it’s mis-sheathed in my daughter’s breast.

paragraphs.original: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$O me! This sight of death is as a bell,$NEWLINE$That warns my old age to a sepulcher.
paragraphs.translated: LADY CAPULET$NEWLINE$Oh my! This sight of death is like a bell that warns me I’m old and I’ll die soon.

paragraphs.original: Enter MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$MONTAGUE
paragraphs.translated: MONTAGUE enters.$NEWLINE$MONTAGUE

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Come, Montague, for thou art early up$NEWLINE$To see thy son and heir now early down.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Come, Montague. You’re up early to see your son down early.

paragraphs.original: MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$Alas, my liege, my wife is dead tonight.$NEWLINE$Grief of my son’s exile hath stopped her breath.$NEWLINE$What further woe conspires against mine age?
paragraphs.translated: MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$Oh, my liege, my wife died tonight. Sadness over my son’s exile stopped her breath. What further pain must I endure in my old age?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Look, and thou shalt see.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Look, and you’ll see.

paragraphs.original: MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$(to ROMEO) O thou untaught! What manners is in this,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$To press before thy father to a grave?
paragraphs.translated: MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$(seeing ROMEO's body) Oh, you undisciplined boy! Where are your manners? It’s not right for a son to push past his father on his way to the grave.$NEWLINE$(seeing$NEWLINE$s body)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while,$NEWLINE$Till we can clear these ambiguities$NEWLINE$And know their spring, their head, their true descent,$NEWLINE$And then will I be general of your woes,$NEWLINE$And lead you even to death. Meantime forbear,$NEWLINE$And let mischance be slave to patience.—$NEWLINE$Bring forth the parties of suspicion.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Be quiet and hold back your remarks of outrage, until we can clear up these questions. We want to know how it started and what really happened. And then I’ll be the leader of pain, and maybe I’ll lead you as far as death. In the meantime, hold on, and be patient. Bring forth the men under suspicion.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I am the greatest, able to do least,$NEWLINE$Yet most suspected, as the time and place$NEWLINE$Doth make against me, of this direful murder.$NEWLINE$And here I stand, both to impeach and purge,$NEWLINE$Myself condemnèd and myself excused.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I am the greatest, but I was able to do the least. I am under the most suspicion, because I was here at the time of this awful murder. And here I stand, you can question me and punish me. I have already condemned and excused myself.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Tell us what you know about this affair.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I will be brief, for my short date of breath$NEWLINE$Is not so long as is a tedious tale.$NEWLINE$Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet,$NEWLINE$And she, there dead, that Romeo’s faithful wife.$NEWLINE$I married them, and their stol'n marriage day$NEWLINE$Was Tybalt’s doomsday, whose untimely death$NEWLINE$Banished the new-made bridegroom from the city—$NEWLINE$For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.$NEWLINE$You, to remove that siege of grief from her,$NEWLINE$Betrothed and would have married her perforce$NEWLINE$To County Paris. Then comes she to me,$NEWLINE$And with wild looks bid me devise some mean$NEWLINE$To rid her from this second marriage,$NEWLINE$Or in my cell there would she kill herself.$NEWLINE$Then gave I her, so tutored by my art,$NEWLINE$A sleeping potion, which so took effect$NEWLINE$As I intended, for it wrought on her$NEWLINE$The form of death.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR LAWRENCE$NEWLINE$I will be brief because I’m not going to live long enough to tell a boring story. Romeo, who lies there dead, was the husband of that Juliet. And she, who lies there dead, was that Romeo’s faithful wife. I married them; their secret wedding day was the day Tybalt died. His untimely death caused the bridegroom to be banished from the city. Juliet was sad because Romeo was gone, not because of Tybalt’s death. To cure her sadness, you arranged a marriage for her with Count Paris. Then she came to me, and, looking wild, she asked me to devise a plan to get her out of this second marriage. She threatened to kill herself in my cell if I didn’t help her. So I gave her a sleeping potion that I had mixed with my special skills. It worked as planned. She seemed to everyone to be dead.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Meantime I writ to Romeo,$NEWLINE$That he should hither come as this dire night,$NEWLINE$To help to take her from her borrowed grave,$NEWLINE$Being the time the potion’s force should cease.$NEWLINE$But he which bore my letter, Friar John,$NEWLINE$Was stayed by accident, and yesternight$NEWLINE$Returned my letter back. Then all alone$NEWLINE$At the prefixèd hour of her waking$NEWLINE$Came I to take her from her kindred’s vault,$NEWLINE$Meaning to keep her closely at my cell$NEWLINE$Till I conveniently could send to Romeo,$NEWLINE$But when I came, some minute ere the time$NEWLINE$Of her awakening, here untimely lay$NEWLINE$The noble Paris and true Romeo dead.$NEWLINE$She wakes, and I entreated her come forth,$NEWLINE$And bear this work of heaven with patience.$NEWLINE$But then a noise did scare me from the tomb,$NEWLINE$And she, too desperate, would not go with me,$NEWLINE$But, as it seems, did violence on herself.$NEWLINE$All this I know, and to the marriage$NEWLINE$Her Nurse is privy. And if aught in this$NEWLINE$Miscarried by my fault, let my old life$NEWLINE$Be sacrificed some hour before his time$NEWLINE$Unto the rigor of severest law.
paragraphs.translated: In the meantime I wrote to Romeo and told him to come here on this awful night to help remove her from her temporary grave when the sleeping potion wore off. But the man who carried my letter, Friar John, was held up by an accident. Last night he gave me the letter back. So I came here alone at the hour when she was supposed to wake up. I came to take her out of her family’s tomb, hoping to hide her in my cell until I could make contact with Romeo. But by the time I got here, just a few minutes before Juliet woke up, Paris and Romeo were already dead. She woke up, and I asked her to come out of the tomb with me and endure this tragedy with patience. But then a noise sent me running scared from the tomb. She was too desperate to come with me, and it seems that she killed herself. I know all of this. And her Nurse knows about the marriage too. If any part of this tragedy is my fault, let my old life be sacrificed and let me suffer the most severe punishment.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$We still have known thee for a holy man.—$NEWLINE$Where’s Romeo’s man? What can he say in this?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$We have always known you to be a holy man. Where’s Romeo’s man? What does he have to say about this?

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I brought my master news of Juliet’s death,$NEWLINE$And then in post he came from Mantua$NEWLINE$To this same place, to this same monument.$NEWLINE$(shows a letter) This letter he early bid me give his father,$NEWLINE$(shows a letter)$NEWLINE$And threatened me with death, going in the vault,$NEWLINE$If I departed not and left him there.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I brought my master news of Juliet’s death. And then he rode from Mantua here to this tomb. (he shows a letter) Earlier this morning he asked me to give this letter to his father. When he went into the vault, he threatened me with death if I didn’t leave him alone there.$NEWLINE$(he shows a letter)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Give me the letter. I will look on it.$NEWLINE$(takes letter from BALTHASAR)$NEWLINE$(takes letter from$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Where is the county’s page, that raised the watch?—$NEWLINE$Sirrah, what made your master in this place?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Give me the letter. I’ll look at it. (he takes the letter from BALTHASAR) Where is the count’s page, the one who called the watch? Boy, what was your master doing here?$NEWLINE$(he takes the letter from$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$He came with flowers to strew his lady’s grave,$NEWLINE$And bid me stand aloof, and so I did.$NEWLINE$Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb,$NEWLINE$And by and by my master drew on him,$NEWLINE$And then I ran away to call the watch.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$He came with flowers to spread on his lady’s grave. And he asked me to stand far away and leave him alone, and so I did. Then someone with a torch came to open the tomb. So my master drew on him. And then I ran away to call the watch.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$(skims the letter) This letter doth make good the friar’s words,$NEWLINE$(skims the letter)$NEWLINE$Their course of love, the tidings of her death.$NEWLINE$And here he writes that he did buy a poison$NEWLINE$Of a poor 'pothecary, and therewithal$NEWLINE$Came to this vault to die and lie with Juliet.$NEWLINE$Where be these enemies?—Capulet! Montague!$NEWLINE$See what a scourge is laid upon your hate,$NEWLINE$That heaven finds means to kill your joys with love!$NEWLINE$And I, for winking at your discords, too$NEWLINE$Have lost a brace of kinsmen. All are punished.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$(skimming the letter) This letter confirms the friar’s account. It describes the course of their love and mentions the news of her death. Here he writes that he bought poison from a poor pharmacist. He brought that poison with him to this vault to die and lie with Juliet. Where are these enemies? Capulet! Montague! Do you see what a great evil results from your hate? Heaven has figured out how to kill your joys with love. Because I looked the other way when your feud flared up, I’ve lost several members of my family as well. Everyone is punished.$NEWLINE$(skimming the letter)

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$O brother Montague, give me thy hand.$NEWLINE$This is my daughter’s jointure, for no more$NEWLINE$Can I demand.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$Oh, brother Montague, give me your hand. This is my daughter’s dowry. I can ask you for nothing more.

paragraphs.original: MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$But I can give thee more,$NEWLINE$For I will raise her statue in pure gold,$NEWLINE$That whiles Verona by that name is known,$NEWLINE$There shall no figure at such rate be set$NEWLINE$As that of true and faithful Juliet.
paragraphs.translated: MONTAGUE$NEWLINE$But I can give you more. I’ll raise her statue in pure gold. As long as this city is called Verona, there will be no figure praised more than that of true and faithful Juliet.

paragraphs.original: CAPULET$NEWLINE$As rich shall Romeo’s by his lady’s lie,$NEWLINE$Poor sacrifices of our enmity.
paragraphs.translated: CAPULET$NEWLINE$The statue I will make of Romeo to lie beside his Juliet will be just as rich. They were poor sacrifices of our rivalry!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$A glooming peace this morning with it brings.$NEWLINE$The sun, for sorrow, will not show his head.$NEWLINE$Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things.$NEWLINE$Some shall be pardoned, and some punishèd.$NEWLINE$For never was a story of more woe$NEWLINE$Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$We settle a dark peace this morning. The sun is too sad to show itself. Let’s go, to talk about these sad things some more. Some will be pardoned, and some will be punished.$NEWLINE$There was never a story more full of pain than the story of Romeo and Juliet.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.
